Early Access Review
								Holy sh*t 29 hours already? I swear I just got this...I've been following Starmade since early early times and have much more playtime from a previous version (before steam) and then life happened and I stopped playing it for awhile.The more "recent" updates wrecked most of my previous knowledge of this game and I had to start learning anew, thank goodness this game is really great so I don't mind at all. Yes, this game is early access so alot of what you see is going to change and is changing with every update. BUT.. the devs are like the coolest people ever. Why? Well, they don't believe you should be paying for an early access game while bugs are still being worked out and the whole game itself is changing. They realize this is an unfinished product and being so have put the game up for $11, ONLY if you want to support them and what they're doing. This is totally optional because they've put the exact version as a demo for free so you can play it first and see if they are worth supporting. ~I do support the devs and what they are doing so I did buy it. Even though it is early access its great~+ Multiplayer Servers+ Paid players and demo players CAN play together on MP servers+ ALOT of content, like I can't even start to say how complex this game can get...+ I think I'm addicted to it... I put 5 hours on it last night alone...+ The devs are realistic people, not trying to steal your organs for an unfinished game.+ If you hate people you can single player this bad boy and even admin command yourself to creative play!-/+ Alot is changing and going to change, what you see now will probably not be the same(similiar in the next update) therefore your knowledge and playtime can become obsolete, but hey! More content ^_^-/+ Making money only takes forever until you can spend a few million to build a proper salvager. On the other hand this is stopping new players from building capital ships in an hour. Pretty balanced (sort of) economy- Pirates are♥♥♥♥♥♥♥br>- Trading Guild sucks at restocking shops- I think I'm addicted to it...I think thats it, at least for this current update. I know this game is going to change alot in future updates so I will try and redo this when it happens and I get some more playtime out of that!9/10 (Currently 2/17/15).

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								So, personally, i like this game, and i defenitly recomend it, but i am growing increasingly frustrated with the numerous problems to getting enjoyment out of the game. The problems that stuck out to me the most are- Setting *no enemys spawn* does not prevent enemies from spawning. Pirates will spawn no matter WHAT this setting is. This removes some of the fun from building stations, diging out a base in an asteroid and mining as you get no warning before you are attacked, and by time you can respond, you are already dead. which wouldnt be as much of a problem if the next problem wasnt there - There is no tool to restore your ship *completely*. You can go to a shop and pay for a repair, but this doesnt replace blocks you already lost. You should be able to point the repair shop at your ship, and the shop *should* detect what blocks were there before you entered combat. - Lack of AI factions: Currently there is only Traders (who you only see in shops and very rarely see their ships) and pirates (who ROFL stomp you before you have time to create a decent vessel or get your base established.) It would be nice if there was a police faction, and maybe two default AI factions that interact with the traders, the pirates, and each other. The universe seems dead otherwise. if you like multiplayer, this isnt as much of a problem, but if you want to try things out in single player you will get wiped out before you can get a decent footing. The enemys SHOULD be dangerous, but they shouldnt swarm you with 5 ships at once when you have the star ship equivelent of a dinghy.- sometimes removing blocks while on EVA is glitchy and you will remove blocks behind or under your charicter.However, the vastness of the universe is awsome and its invigorating to be able to construct a base wherever the hell you want. this game has a ton of potential and needs more features, In its current state its a mediocre time waster, but there is massive potential.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Saw a wormhole across multiple sectors thinking it was a space stationWent on an expedition with a friend to "Space Station"Got too close, realizing it was pulling us Tried to get out and add thrusters for escaping my doomBody gets sucked inFriend and I die to the voids of space10/10 Would wormhole again Real Talk Though But really, Starmade is something else. I went in believing it would be some kind of Minecraft clone or waste of 10$, I almost even wanted a refund at first. Yes it IS IN ALPHA, it IS UNFINISHED but god damn, 6 hours in and there's just... So much content already.This current version of Alpha is not worth 10$, it's worth 25$ at the  least  so much to do from making buildings and factories on planets to colonizing them or stripping them bare for resources. Pirates and robbers keep it new and the game continues to amaze me. For once I can make a ship, simply put down a gravity generator and have my friend walk around and do maintenance/man the guns/repair or stargaze as I fly around. He doesn't fall out and it's not laggy. You play Space Engineers and hope for smooth riding in your friends ship as he flies but in Starmade  you can do just that  Beautiful game, amazing graphics whether you want them simple or HD and all around something I will be playing for quite awhile Gameplay 8/10  It is still in Alpha but a lot is already on the table, I could see space fights becoming more engaging other than that basic mechanics on and off planets is great. Sound 6.7/10  Not any background music yet, it leaves a lot of atmosphere out but setting up a simple Chillstep playlist on YouTube makes it fantastic as you play. Graphics 20/10 ] If you don't like voxel based games, then you would obviously dislike the graphics here. If you  do  like blocks and cubes and such, you should love it. I play on high settings with ultra shadows and the realistic texture pack. On top of that my favorite feature is the procedural background image of the galaxy on the 4k resolution. Absolutely stunning. I can't express how amazing it is to be on a planet and seeing both sunset and the galaxy mesh together in one. Creative Level and Difficulty  This game does have a learning curve to get ahead of. At first you have no idea what the hell you are doing, it's very discouraging and hard to get through but once you have the basics, the rest will eventually catch up. The logic system (similar to Minecraft's redstone system) is very simple as with the ship building in general. You don't have to wire every bit and piece together, all you have to do is select what mother block you want your other blocks to be connected to and place them. Easy peasy. Once you get past the beginner phase a universe of oppurtunity arises at your feet.[h2] Overall in its Current State 8/10 [/h2] It's in Alpha. So much done right in such a little time span and release version. This game has the potential to uplift the "Minecraft Genre" and be a real successor in its own dominant space setting. 100% worth your 10$ if you enjoy space crafting, exploration, blocks and planet colonization. It's a really good game.Just get it.

								Dont let my hours played fool you - when i first got this game (2015 some time i think) i couldnt launch it from steam, so i ran it from the command line (yup, i'm on linux). i probably have > 100 hoursThis is a realy cool game. If you like space and building - just buy it.* constantly being updated - devs seem to care about this one* back to building - building a giant mining ship that could vaporise an asteroid in seconds was pretty cool* THE BUILD SYSTEM.  Yes its a little hard to understand at first, but wow, you can do a lot with it.  I havent seen such a build system in any other gameThe Bad:* yeah, the build system - it takes a while to master it. but like i said above, its amazing once you know what you are doing* updates break things. Yup. dont buy EA games if you dont like this.  hell dont buy any software at all for that matter. Or operating systems, in fact just turn your computer off and go outside :PI keep firing up this game every now and then just to see whats new, When enough has changed i'll prolly drop another few hundered hours on it. Havent really got into the factions thing at all yet. I check back on this more than any of my other EA titles. Personally i think the devs made a mistake making it free. its all ready worth the price

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Amazing sandbox game that lets you build the spaceship of your dreams. You can play the game as a astronaut in a nearly endless universe, salvage asteroids, ships, stations and planets and use the resources you get to make blocks with factories (kinda like crafting in minecraft but more automatic once you have everything set up correctly). You can either use these blocks to build ships or sell them to others for credits or other blocks through your personal store that you can put on your base. Or play in a creative mode where you use admin commands to get the blocks needed and make the most amazing ships.Its worth getting because:1. You don't need the greatest pc to play it.2. With enough skill you can make any ship you want. (check out other people's work and you will know what I mean)3. There are lots of modules that you can put on your ship. Making it possible to make almost any kind of ship you want with multiple functions.4. The game has almost everything you need for a space sandbox. (FTL!!!)5. A nearly infinite universe, so there is always room to build more and expand your faction territory!***Updated***6. Logic and rails: Make doors and entire compartments of your ship move and change with the press of a single button. (It might seem complicated at first but personally way easier to understand compared to redstone in minecraft which isn't too hard either)7. The game already has mod support and many content creator already made tons of texture packs and small mods to change the look and feel of the game.8 (Not implemented but will be out in the next update) AI factions are coming which will finally bring some more life in the universe of StarMade. Check out the StarMade youtube channel for a bigger explenation of all the upcoming features.All this is already available in the Alpha version of the game.With that said a fair warning to all who want to play:THIS GAME IS IN AN ALPHA STATE. Expect things to not works correctly and servers to crash often when playing multiplayer. Also download the demo on Steam if you are not sure about buying the game yet. The demo is currently the same as the full version but free. However the devs said the price of the game will go up the closer they get to release so you might wanna buy it now while it's still a low price.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS Introductory Review:StarMade is a voxel-based sandbox that gives you the infinite expanses of outer space to build, craft, and venture. Yes, there’s no way around it, this is essentially Minecraft in space.It’s not long been released on Steam Early Access where you can purchase it for $9.99 on Windows, Mac, and Linux. But it has been playable in its early stages before Early Access for quite a while. It’s actually been in the making since 2010.In StarMade, you can build your own spaceship block-by-block, customizing it with weapons fit to take on space pirates – you’ll need them. Once satisfied, you can then get into your spaceship in order to explore distant stars and galaxies.You’ll come across more than pirates too, as there are abandoned space stations to pick from, and the treasures you find inside can be traded to make a fortune. Or, you can use the materials to make your own space station, or a factory, all in order to make huge quantities of sellable items for a profit.In multiplayer you’ll be able to find other factions, which you can join or fight against, and I’m sure you’ll be glad to hear that StarMade has dedicated servers.The idea behind StarMade is to provide you an infinite space to make your own way within. As in Minecraft, you do as you please, exploring the various possibilities of the game’s intricate sandbox design.Abstract:??/?? (Awaiting Full-Release)Recommended for it's current state at $9.99, there is enough content to keep you occupied for hours. I played this game before I purchased it on Steam, so I knew what I was getting into.

number of helpful: 12 of 12 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								(written after the custom shapes update)[Intro]Firstly, before the content, many people may have seen outdated reviews and I would like to clear up some things. They have creative mode. They have slabs like in minecraft. They have teleporters. Missiles aren't the most powerful weapon in the game.This is one of my favorite games, not just because of its current state, but the timeline looks amazing. There are some bugs that appear every once and a while, but the devs are the best and always listen to what the community is saying.If none of the stuff below sounds appealing, remember that the demo is the same thing as the full version! You can even play on servers and stuff, however in the future they will limit the demo.[Description (longer)]You can do a lot in this game. It comes with lots of colors (teal and pink are somewhat new), weapons and details. And pirates to blow up.To start off, the controls take some time to get used too, and you can change them if you must. A lot of people gave this negative reviews just because of the controls, so ignore them. I prefer the default controls.In terms of building, it is the opposite of minecraft. (left click to build) They have all sorts of hull colors and decorations you can use to make your ships look realistic. With the new addition of slabs and "custom shapes" - which means models / 3D indented stuff - ships have gotten to look way cooler.Real quick, I also want to mention that the textures at their current state tend to look a LOT better and more polished than in outdated videos. The lighting is amazing right now too.In terms of weapons, they have a lot too. What's so special is that you can combine up to 3 weapons to make one weapon better. For example, cannons make things shoot a lot faster, but reduce the damage a little. Missile computers hooked up with beams make homing missiles. They even have modules specifically for modifying weapons like push and pull effects.In terms of factions, the player created ones work pretty well, however the devs are still working on the AI. It may take a while, however I am excited to see how they turn out based off of their posts. (https://starmadedock.net/threads/starmade-active-development-timeline.25541/)Crew really can't do anything right now, so don't expect the option to "hire crew" to do much. Like I said the developers have large plans and continue to update it every two weeks, so to me it sounds very promising.[Similar games]I have seen some similar games like this. First off, space engineers is aimed to be more of a survival and realistic game, FROM WHAT I HAVE SEEN. (it doesn't work on my laptop or my pc :p) So I wouldn't compare it. Blockade runner seems very similar too, however I don't know much about it. The pictures online tell be that starmade is a MUCH more polished game, however starmade has been in development a lot longer to my knowledge.[Short Description (for people like me)]A block-based building game where you can build the ultimate space ship that actually functions and blast pirates & things with it. This includes hangers for drones or friends and warp drives to get around. Stations are an option too; you can process ores from planets and keep your ships safe there. Multiplayer? Team up with friends for fun or fight to the death in a battle of empires.[Conclusion]So that is really all I have to say. Don't underestimate what this game is aimed to be; just look at the dev. plans. Don't base your opinion off of old reviews, especially ones that say it just crashes. (unless you have a bad computer. Read the reccomended system first) I hope you think this is good if you buy it. Schine is really serious about its quality and brings constant updates. (if 2 every weeks is constant for you)[Last note]I haven't actually played the custom shapes update yet; just came out like an hour ago. Also, try out the demo if you aren't quite sure yet.[Rating]10/10 you can build MLG mems (memes... get it?... no... ok...)

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								First of all I would like to say... WOW!Ok this is a space Minecraft style sandbox game but for a fresh release on early access on Steam... it's amazing !THE LAYOUT:After a quick tutorial (some aspects of the game are still missing...), you start near a "cotton bud" looking space station.You are an astronaut and with few credits and items you are left in a huge universe.First you have few blocks to build a basic spaceship. If you are smart enough, you will be able to go anywhere and enjoy the huge number of planets, asteroids and stations you can find (nearly infinite).THE GAMEPLAY:Ship and stations designs are easy. By pressing Space after entering a Ship core, you can launch building mode.The Ship core it some kind of box where the player can enter and control the ship. It's a strange way to use vehicles but the designer is enough well made to compensate this strange design.Like in Minecraft you use blocks, you place them with left click and delete with right click (you have tons of other contols by pressing left ctrl). For every ships, you have to plan it's energy usage and mass. The bigger the more expensive it will be for you: like the cloak wich needs more energy depending of the size  of the ship. The interresting aspect of this mode is the way you use weapons and tools.Every items needs a computer to be used. You put an appropriate computer and the weapon or tool block related, and you conect them. The funny thing is that you can mix weapons and some upgrade blocks to change their effects, like EMP or Shield Drain, ect... You can even place turret docking blocks with AI blocks to create an automated sentry capable to fire anything you want from missiles to beams.For tools you have less possibilities but you can put more blocks and computers to create massive Salvage beams (some kind of mining laser) or even create you own Antenna relay to scan your sector and spot anything that moves.You can even hold personnal weapons or tools (you have a basic mining laser) but you can't upgrade it much, like for the ships.You can also place a building block on a planet or a location you own ( with a faction block), to customize it.From the plants to the soils, being able to change a planet so quickly is excellent and gives you plenty ways to create.But you can't harvest materials by this way, you have to clear a path with the editor and go mining yourself.About crafting, it's not a good aspect of the game. Because you have too much materials and it becomes quickly too complicate to build nice recipes (bad crafting menus when you use crafting stations). In fact you will spare tons of time by harvesting raw materials and selling them to the Galatic Traders. These guys are the owners of the "space cotton buds" They are neutral npc that sells all blocks you can imagine and they buy everything you can bring !When you got the way to gather quickly, you get quite a lot of credits (the actual currency in the game).But space is a dangerous place...Players can be hostiles, you will notice that with a nice Faction system. By yourself you can create a faction, claim locations in its name and even conquer other players properties. Before doing that you need faction points with the help of other faction members and enough fights against enemy factions. This system is really good and surprises by it's quality for an early acess game.But your not alone because some pirates are roaming...They hide in somes big space stations with heavy turrets that does quite a lot of damage.But if you can manage to enter them... you will get tons of items !Be ware pirates are fliying in fast ships and dying is quite normal when you begin.Don't forget to buy enough stuff to build few basic ships when you first spawn.And find a nice planet to land.At this moment you will have time to study the blocks, the ways you have to earn money and CONQUER THE UNIVERS !TO CONCLUDE:Starmade is a real surprise. Quite impressive and cheap (the price will change), the gameplay it offers is amazing for an early acess.Ok i have to admit the game is rough around the edges: need some balance about the trade and crafting system. The tutorial wich is empty especially in front of game mechanics such as Factions or Logics. The physic for ship flights needs to be better because it's like driving in a "soapbox" or the punch of weapons wich are a bit weak especially on foot. Physic on blocks would be cool, like on some planets where lava "floats" in the airs.But the overall quality is really good for this kind of game, the developpers are even planing to add creatures (actually there is one alien spider you can see in the tutorial). And seriously, being able to build so much crazy things with turrets, landing zones, weapons, antenna and even warp gates...it's amazing !N.B: The game is quite stable, even if i had to play it on an old computer.You can also play alone on a dedicated server and set the difficulty of the AI. Life in space has never been so easy !

								I played this game before the rails, logic, and weapons update and it was good. Now it's awesome. Buggy sometimes, but awesome nevertheless. content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is sadly unplayable until they fix AI ship spawning (oh god especially the trader ships). I WOULD recommend this game, as I’ve been playing it since it first came out (before steam), but the frustration of constantly being rammed into by trader ships, which spontaneously acquire some sad case of severely impulsive autism when flying towards a shop, followed by the insane lag caused when they kamikaze into the trader posts (which probably contributes to their lack of any brain cells) makes this game heartbreakingly difficult to play. Not to mention, when they start overheating from the damage, the player can easily just strip parts from the unconscious ship, leaving an infinite supply of free stuff. But that aside, it's unbelievably frustrating to build a starter ship because in order to build anything without getting caught in the trader ships’ suicide missions, I have to entirely leave the shop sector. And if I run out of supplies, I have to fly all the way back to the shop, which is quite risky considering the obvious. But wait, there’s more! I don’t NEED to buy anything because I can probably just steal what I need from those mangled trader ships! See the problem? I realize that I can simply turn off collision damage, but that won’t stop the knockback effect. So if I’m out of my ship and it gets hit, it’s GOING to disappear forever. I also realize that I could turn inertia back on, but that would make flying long distances very frustrating because I would either have to 1, hold down the forward button for at least half an hour, or 2, sit here charging warp drives until I’m 99 and hooked up to an IV. I would much prefer to set the engines to max and let inertia take care of the rest while I leave to go get some work done for a couple hours.It seems to me that they rushed this update out the door way to quickly. If you're going to release a major update, at least take the time to stabilize it first. Making a game unplayable, even if only for a short while, is only going to deter incoming customers and upset those that already own the game. Rushing things out the door is literally what EA does.But other than that, excellent game! I will change my vote once this problem has been dealt with.Oh and also, I’m autistic myself. So don't think I'm attacking the disabled, 'cause I'm not. :P

number of helpful: 16 of 20 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok, I'll be straightforward: I almost gave this game up within 5 minutes. My first impression was horrible. But I'm glad I persevered.As for the long text review: there's a summary in the end.Also if you don't like text and prefer a video over text, have a glance at how powerful the game is and just how much cool stuff and creativity you can have with it in this example. IntroI got it as part of a bundle some time ago and decided to give it a try. The launcher was not the best experience. When I finally got in-game, the tutorial was broken. As if this was not annoying enough, without a tutorial I was *completely* lost and had no idea what to do. Oh, and the sound was bugged. It took me quite a while to find how to fix it. Then the performance was horrible and again it took me a while to find how to fix it (increase allocated memory, get Java 64x). So I ditched Starmade and was glad I did.By the way: The tutorial was quickly fixed, and a new launcher is underway. This sums up quite nicely one of the positives of this game: The devs. They're active, they're quick, they're good. But most of all, they are just part of the community. I started watching a few tutorial videos and whatnot on youtube and only after I had watched quite a few I realized at least two of the youtubers were actually devs. They're so helpful and chill it's unbelievable.After watching online some of the stuff people were doing with the game and how so many love it I decided to give it another go -- now with the knowledge of where to find solutions to the problems I'd certainly encounter: Youtube, and to some extent the forums. Oh and I'm so glad I didn't give up. MainThen onto something that might be a pro or a con, depending what you're looking for: This game is whatever you make of it. So if you're looking to hop into space and find everything done and ready... keep looking. Here you start with pretty much nothing, in the middle of the vast space and next to a shop. Go from there, good luck. It's up to you what you want to build or do. Where you want to go. With whom you want to ally and play. And so on. The big pro is that the limit is just your creativity. The possibilities are vast. If you like being creative, inventive, ingenious, and if you like to build not only your own game but a whole universe (ok, a whole "stronghold" in universe) -- then this is for you.The cons stay pretty much on the realm of the interface. The interface can be pretty powerful but many many aspects are really non-intuitive. Also the launcher is really barebones (thankfully a new one coming). The tutorial is also quite lackluster, so there's no other way: To learn tricks and all the power the interface has you have to dedicate some time to watch tutorials and whatnot. Thankfully there's plenty of good ones so no excuses there.Bugs exist, as well as some balance issues and whatnot. But it's a game in alpha so they are quite ok. And I know nowadays it's a bit old to put a half-arsed game out there and call it alpha as an excuse to have produced a crap game. But this is not the case with these guys: They're hard at work, and updates and content are being churned out quickly. All that with lots of transparency and community input. Just a couple of days ago I was in a Q&A session with them (and I'm a nobody!) that lasted some 3 hours, in which the replied to a ton of questions and played/had fun with the community. Thumbs up! So to sum it upPros:   Vast, both in terms of "map size" (pretty much infinite) and in terms of possibility;  Be creative, build your own world, your own ships, and do it your own way;  Very active, supportive, friendly and helpful devs;  An active community with lots of tutorials, general help, and content to download (like ships, stations, skins, etc.).Cons (bit hard to think of that many but I'll try so don't blame me for being a bit unfair):   Interface is powerful but somewhat bareboned and rather un-intuitive at times;  That includes the launcher and many "hidden" options that will give you a better experience;  Bugs. Yeah it's alpha, yeah they're to be expected, but they're there;  Among them I'm mostly bothered by the sound. Or lack thereof. It often bugs out and goes nearly silent;  The mp can be a bit spread thin, with many servers having just but a few people logged in each;  Balance can be a problem, and more veteran players have a huge upper hand upon novices;  You can bypass the last one by playing single player for a while, or by playing on a strictly PvE server. But doesn't that spoil the whole point of the game? Maybe. It's your choice.  There's not all that much "environment" as of yet (although devs say much will be added). So at this point the universe feels a bit empty and plain until people (and mostly you) start to actually build stuff. ConclusionIt's hard to give a note. On the one hand if you're expecting a somewhat "polished", "arrive-and-play" type of experience, you'll be greatly disappointed. On the other hand, if you're into being creative and being responsive for the creation of your own experience, then this can easily be an 8/10 -- with the potential to go at least up to a 9 once a few things like the sounds are sorted.I highly recommend it, if it's the kind of experience you're looking for and you are prepared to what's involved in grabbing it yourself.ps: And as time passes the game only gets better with frequent updates. The ideas the devs still have "in the oven" make me very excited for the future of this title.

Early Access Review
								Edit: This game was once really, really cool. And now it's just dead. Servers are barely populated, and there isn't enough room for modding. All the fun got sucked right out of it. It's a game about being a space trucker, Elite Dangerous lite. I miss the good old days of this game.A game with huge potential that has kinda just...sat there. Updates come consistently but very little has actually been added to enhance the fun of the game. I would say that fun mostly lies within PVE and PVP, as accumulation of wealth means basically nothing as of right now, since stores are frequently our of stock with even the most basic items on nearly every server. The blueprint system is also tedious, requiring you to add every single material one by one. The "buy-to-spawn" mechanic is now gone on any public server I can find, requiring the construction  of ships block by block or with the annoying blueprint system. I like the creativity the game allows, but sinking hours into a ship only for it to be destroyed in the first fight sucks and the blueprint system is godawful (Edit: Still godawful. Can't check blueprint list while you have the store open at the same time. Always minimizes. This problem has been consistent throughout development and makes buying necessary items for Blueprints a ♥♥♥♥ing chore)

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is everything one could hope it to be, and more, besides the obvious bocky rendering. I can already see many people comparing this game to No Man's Sky, and calling it a "No Man's Sky wannabe", and a "Pretender", but I feel obliged to point out that this game was around and being developed first. AS FOR THE PRODUCT, THIS GAME IS GREAT, IF ONE WOULD SPEND TIME FIGURING THINGS OUT. I say this, because I find a lot of people will get into something like this game, find the controls vast, and the very small amount of tutorial help given, and mostly give up right then and there, or else have some kind of computer problem running this game, blame it all of the game, and say it sucks. The reality is that this game takes some getting used too, even today I found something new, and this game never ceses to amaze me. The multiplayer servers too, are a balance that takes some getting used too. Many of them are very buggy, because all servers are run by players, however there are more than enough servers that run flawlessly. The simple truth is that this game is just as good, perhaps better than the current and near future competition (Space Engineers and No Man's Sky), however the majority of the quality is hidden just beneath the surface of the game, and just needs a little exploration to uncover.

content:

Early Access Review
								While this game can be hard to get used to, once you get past the clunky controls, and unorthodox UI design you'll realize this is a game with amazing potential and amazing features. The developers have done something that hasn't been done for a long time - actually let players try the game without hassles or schemes. Becuase of this, i was able to discover that StarMade is what i've been looking for in a space game for a long long time. I highly reccomended that anyone who loves Space Engineers or Minecraft give this a try, becuase this really is a great game. It's not the same, but it has some similiarities. In this game, problems are solved with blocks, and i think thats something to appreciate.This game is best played in a Multipalyer setting, however i DO reccomended that you play single player for your first 20 hours to make sure youre ready for a PvP setting. There are lots of little things that i had to discover the hard way, and while it was fun, some might not be as interested in tough love as i am. I really hope this game takes off. I haven't felt so much love for a game since i first tried minecraft.EDIT: Rail systems are a blast. I've already made an auto ship dispenser for my ship's hanger. I love this game!

content:
Posted: October 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								Been playing since before the steam addition with a buddy of mine.  Back in the day, he would be mining an asteroid while I would fly out to a pirate station, in hopes of getting close enough to take apart the turret systems without dying so we could salvage the blocks.  It took many tries, and I lost a lot of ship cores, but when I finally managed to get to the station and take apart the station block, we were set to fly out to coordinates of 100+, 100-, 100+ so we could build a giant cube of death lazers and homing missiles to wreak havoc upon any fools that would make their way out to us.  It was the size of 2 pirate stations, with 16 AI turrets attached, ready to destroy anyone we deemed hostile (actually just everyone since the AI wasn't that bright at the time, including myself). Becase of the physics involved in the game, turning was a hassle, so we just added more guns and literally shot holes through planets to get through them. TL;DRMy buddy was chilling, while I was dying and crying, trying to take over a heavily AI guarded space station.  I still do the same thing to this day, except I die a lot more.  It's a good game, please support :)

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has improved quiate a lot since my inital review a year ago. I can now recommend it. You can call this minecraft in space, bit it's now a lot more than that. It can be a MMO, but with built-in anti-greifing  to some extent (only your faction home is protected). Faction permissions have improved quite a bit to prevent bad faction members from stealing resrouces and ships.Also it's a lot of fun. Build whatever you want, build elevators, huge hanger doors, tiny ships, huge ships. The universe is big enough that you can find your own litte corner of the galaxy not to be bugged, or, fly off to a far off galaxy if you want.You can now have your own fleet of ships that will fight to defend you, mine, or fly off to whever you command them (in fact, fleet orders can be used as a kind of slow auto-pilot).  The role of NPCs are being expanded. If you're running your own sever, you can write your own NPC scripts and load them for custom game experience. When you first play this game, keep in mind that block placement matters for many system blocks (esp. power and weapons). Usually due to the coplexity of the game, young children don't play it as much, so it's generally a more mature community. If you've grown out of Minecraft, this is for you.  Also, you can play the game for free as of now, and can lauch it direclty wihout using steam (which is how I normally play). The only thing is, most servers WON'T allow you to connect unless you've bought the game-- so go buy it.

number of helpful: 14 of 18 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've only just scratched the surface to this game and from the initial concept I can see what it's trying to achieve. It's essentially minecraft in space with a good dose of space sim play like that in Elite and Eve online. It does have however it's caveats; The tutorials are clunky to the extent it's easy to miss key components, and the ship management needs to be drastically simplified. Such as connecting weapons to computers should for the novice user, be automatic and not manually mapped and so forth. It has a ton of bugs, yes I know it's early access I get that. But I understand this games been around for awhile prior to being released here on Steam. So you would think something as simple as sound would be a priority. I've ran this on two systems with it either silent or randomly loud repetitive fx's.If you build a ship, fly off then start the tutorial, forget about your ship. On return spawn you are back at the beginning with your ship lost in space. And without a core to build another ship your essentially screwed and have to wipe the universe and start again.Hopefully the above bugs get sorted out in further builds.You would think with the bugs and clunky ship building I wouldn't recommend this game. For early adopters who want to see this game develop, bugs and all, I would say go for it. And I'm keen to see where this goes. For those who expect the concept being sold here is what you'll get, taking into consideration that yes this is an early access game, then I ask you save your coin and come back later.

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								In short, it is an amazing building game with lots of potentialNow the long one. I was scrolling through games and stumbled across this game. Quite frankly i thought that this was just going to be another of the thousands of over-glorified Minecraft clone set in the future blah blah blah. But i got it anyways because some of the clones are pretty good... and it was only $10I am glad i did. You will start out on a small space station "shop" with some basic components that will allow you to build a tiny, but functional, ship (and yes, you CAN build your own spaceships block-by-block) as well as a weak gun and enough money to get you places. At this point you can start heading to smaller asteroids and even planets (Planets are VERY laggy) and start mining new materials to ether refine, use raw, or sell for cash for better parts. But it is not all easy, you will be attacked at times and you will need to defend your turf.Now for some cons:The MAIN issue i have with the game is LAG! LLAAGG! for the most part the game runs smother then a hot-sword-through-butter, even on some not so good computers. But when you enter planets, or even some space stations, you can encounter MASSIVE lag spikes, some even freezing the game. I HAVE been able to solve this by editing the "server settings" to make the planets smaller and that solved most issues. but it is defiantly an issue that must be resolved before it goes into finalIn the end:I give it a 9/10. it has great game dynamics, a good building system, and overall fun gameplay, with the only major issue that need attention being the "Planetary Lag", but the game is worth every penny

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								Starmade is by far one of the best sandbox games I have played, at its current stage of development it has far more features than I would expect.To just name a few, a fantastic and fleshed out system for building bases and ships, space pirates and derelict (ghost) ships, and a really cool system for combining the weapons systems to make different weapons (ie a shotgun by slaving a missile computer to a cannon computer). However this game can be very overwhelming and complex at the start it has a steep learning curve, but rewards you greatly when you start to understand how things work. And best of all while the game is in early access you can play everything the devs have to offer for free by playing the demo, so there is no reason not to take a little bit of time to just learn how the game works. (Though of course if you like the game why not give them your money to support further devolpment) GoodOne of a kind building mode that makes it easy to create even the largest of shipsAwesome combinations of weapon systemsDerelict ships and space pirate dronesPlanetsWide variety of ores and craftable blocksNeat factory blocks that can be grouped together to increase effeicency and speedEnemy space stations Space marketplaceThe blueprint system in the game is greatActive devsBadThe game can be difficult to learn due to various complexties (mainly the power system which once learned is actaully very cool)Java is pretty resource heavy and can cause slowdowns (they have been working to mitigate this)Planets have a lot of useless blocksColored blocks have to be crafted would like to see either some kind of paint gun or better yet the ability to select block color in advanced buildmodeI dislike having to craft the different block shapes as it becomes very tedious, would be awesome to see this added into advanced build mode (wedges, tetras, corners, heptas)

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Bought this game back when it was $3 on the website (maybe 1.5 years ago?) And I was in-love with it, you could build anything you wanted in space. Be an asteroid miner, be a fighter, cruiser, dreadnaught, anything. And with multiplayer, the RP scene is pretty big. I recommend this game for anyone who likes games like space engineers (It's like that but not as complicated or taxing on your pc), or people who enjoy minecraft, and anyone who likes space.The planets: When I bought the game they used to be flat round discs, now they're multi-sided (3d-octogonal?) You can land on them, get out of your ship, and explore them.The pirates: There are npc pirates in this game. They're fairly difficult at first, but once you get a semi-decent ship they're easy. You can set them to use your own ship designs if they become waay too easy.Stations: There are two types of stations in the game. Pirate stations, and Abandoned stations. The pirate stations have turrets and spawn pirates, these have loot that can earn you a LOT of money (Very dangerous with custom ships). Abandoned stations, they're just abandoned, they used to be completely empty, but now they spawn npc drones that attack you (Like a defense system). Mine the plexglass on the top to make lots of money too.Thank you for taking the time to read this, and hopefully I helped you with purchasing this game.

number of helpful: 162 of 293 people (55%) found this review helpful14 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Update: With all of the new bug fixes and updates, I'll be playing the game soon, and then revising this review as needed.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Currently the ONLY reason to buy this is to support the developer, which I have no problem doing, but based on the history of early access games on Steam - most buy an EA game, and then are upset at the lack of features, even though the EA concept is clear.  So, if you are one of those people - pass on this for now.For others, I'll state that while you can build some ships and travel through space, flying through space is very slow and as others have noted, there isn't really much to do - you can mine stuff and you can salvage stuff - oh, and you can sell stuff to the shop in order to buy stuff.  There's stuff, stuff and pirate stations...Despite the lack of other stuff, the game shows potential.  I really like the build aspect for the spaceships as it allows for lots of customization, but flying the ship isn't that great because of the overall control scheme - switching between flying and building shouldn't be so easy that you do it by accident and end up exiting and losing the ship in deep space.I didn't play this game before it came to Steam, so don't know how the planets were before, but the current design is...interesting.  They have a good size to them and I actually like the multi-faceted appearance, but travelling from one face of the planet to another is kind of weird (in both a good and bad way).  One thing I don't like so far is that there doesn't appear to be liquids - lava is simply a glowing non-flowing block - dig one out from under another and the hole remains with the other lava block just "floating" over it.Another thing I feel needs to be improved - space stations.  I know they pushed an update that changed the mix of abandoned versus pirate stations, but considering how long it takes to fly anywhere, it is still a pain to travel a long distance only to see you're being shot at by a pirate station or that the station is degraded, thus only good for scrap - and you'll need more than scrap if you want to upgrade your engines in order to fly faster.To summarize - unless you simply wish to support the dev and/or really like space games/sims, I'd wait until more of the features are added to the game.  At that time I'll revisit this review and hopefully change that "no" to a "yes!"

content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								     This game is really good, even at its early alpha stage. For the features that are in they are fairly well implemented as well as a whole, there are more features in so far then some games have at full release. Gameplay and look is similar to how games like Minecraft and similar 3d open world sandbox games where you make your own story. It is obviously in space, even though you can go onto planets.      The game at this moment is capable to being modded, with its Block Editor(which allows you to make/modify new or existing blocks). The server config which is also the configs for single player is fairly customizable, with the ability to toggle/change settings that are normally reserved for mods in other games.      Ships are dynamic in that they are all different based on what you built them with and what types of moduals you placed in them. Also the fact that you can mix and match compatible moduals together to create a new type of weapon or utility tool. The most common example is that by default a salvage(aka mining) modual will just do a burst beam, but if you connect the salvage computer to a cannon computer with just the right ratio of moduals you can get a constant steady beam for the salvage modual and mine/eat things to your heart's content.      Building is fairly straight forward for its most used functions, as well as for those who want more tools, there are more precise tools and options. Gameplay is very much like other games of it's genres. As a side effect though, with this game's many options and complexity, there will obviously be a learning curve. Where the player will need to learn how to setup the blocks and moduals, as some have their own placement rules. Thankfully there are many tutorials and Lets Play videos out there so learning will not be too difficult.     In all I recommend this game to anyone who likes; space games + open world sandbox games + lots of options, for its $9.99 USD price at this moment. As well as the developers currently have the full game for free as long as it's in early access. I bought it though, because it's pure awesome in my opinion, and I'll gladly pay the $10 for the game as well as the fact that buying the game helps to continue it's developement.

content:

Early Access Review
								When I first seen this game I thought ahh Minecraft in space with some EVE undertones and that is what it is. I totally give the Devs a salute for their love for this game. They are a small team so at times when personal stuff comes up you do notice a slow down but the care and love is there, If you are like me and tired of developers that just want your money and you wonder if one day the game will just be dead then have no worries about the Schine team. As far as gameplay goes It's kind of boring playing by yourself but so is Minecraft. The build tools are amazing and make up for that plenty as you can see from my hours played. You have 5 basic shapes of blocks which I think does make for a more Minecraft feel even though they could do more variety with the second gen voxel system the game uses. I'd like to see more but i can respect if it is to keep the blocky feel of the game. They do alot on making multiplayer very viable and there has been a lot of focus there.  It's private servers like Minecraft but there are public websites and people who run them that let anyone in like minecraft if you want a bigger server to play on. Google it and you will get a good list. So I say give this game a try if you want Minecraft in space and to take what you build into battle. The Schine team has accomplished a lot since I bought this as far as adding quailty into the game and it's gameplay. Plus they are always working on something so you can expect more from these guys.  This game is worth the price and you will not regret it in my opinion.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is really an awesome game. I waited quite a while to write this review. From the outside it might look like minecraft in space, but it is not. Starmade is a randomly generated huge universe, multiplayer or singleplayer, PVP, PVE, space simulation, sandbox game. That statement may seem like too much, but it does not do the game justice. I've been playing starmade for years. For a long time I played free via their website, but finally decided to buy it and support them. The game has gradually been changing, and is constantly being worked on. They are always listening to their forums for ideas in developing the game to better suit the players, but still keeping their core elements of the game alive.The most impressive aspect of the game to me is its builder or build mode. The build mode in starmade allows for players to do much more than just place blocks. It gives you shape outlines to use, you can set planes to create symmetry on structures, you can place blocks in many ways, and replace certain types with other types. The complexity may seem like a lot to get used to, but it is not you can hop right in, and the tutorials give you enough information to be building your own ship in minutes.The game also is constantly changing with great plans in place for future gameplay. Currently there are areas of the game that are lacking, but those areas are already being filled in. Even in the current state of the game, I find myself wasting many hours on it. It's definitely worth looking into if you like space exploration, combat, or even rpg elements. This game will have them all. Currently it's most lacking in rp elements, but there are plans to have quests and many other rp elements added in later. The game operates on a small server platform, so you can play online with friends or do local play to play by yourself. My Pros:Infinite Open Universe SimulationSandboxCompletely customizableBuild Ships, Spacestations, and Planet BasesBeautiful graphicsBlueprints to save created structuresMultiplayer or SingleplayerCreative or SurvivalInteresting Building MechanicsGreat combat with playersCons: AI is hilariously glitchy at timesCurrently in developmentSometimes can lag due to needed server optimizationPirates sometimes kill you before you can get established

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is one of those games that requires your attention as a Science Fiction game.This is not a game that tells a story, or has quests of any kind in fact. What it does instead is offer you the ability to create anything you can imagine.Yes, other games, like Minecraft, have done this before, but this game is exceptional in how it handles Starship building. Take a quick tour through any Ship Review on YouTube and you will see things that are not possible in any game. A 1:1 replica of the UNSC Spirit of Fire? Yup. A 1:1 replica of the Enterprise (several versions of it, in fact)? Yup. A scale replica of the Death Star? Yup.You can build anything in this game. Starships from your favorite franchise, Starships of your own design, space stations, ground vehicles, bases, cities, factions... everything.You can save everything you build as a blueprint (which also allows you to download other people's ships) and then take them with you to other servers, where you can join Player-Run factions and engage in PvP content in ships, or in capturing ships and bases. Or, you could just build a simple mining ship and sell your resources to players who need them more than you. And you can do all of this while exploring a randomly generated galaxy.The developers are very active and the game has received numerous updates adding new functionality, like FTL drives, NPC factions, and others.However, this is absolutely a game that requires you to make your own fun. The amount of content here is mind-boggling, but, like other games in its genre, it typically involves you building it.If you are a fan of starships, play this game. If you are have always wanted to build your starship/station/moon-like object, play this game. And finally, if you've wanted a game that actually captures the feeling of exploring the galaxy, play this game.As a final note, this game is 100% free to try. The demo listed on Steam is actually the full game, and will continue to be the full game until Starmade comes out of Alpha. You will not need to pay money for the game until it comes out in Beta or later.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very cool sandbox spaceship building game.I have both this and Space Engineers(SE), and what Starmade lacks in Physics and Graphics it most certainly makes up for in game play depth.By this I mean, Logic Controllers, the PvE AI, the HUGE Galaxy, the ability to support HUGE ships pretty well but in SE's defense Starmade has less to calculate with relations to Newtonian Physics which SE has.Putting them side by side, each is better at one thing than the other and they both cater for different crowds.This game is awesome in that as someone who does not really play on hugely populated servers there is something to do other than chase down 'drifting' abandoned ships with auto turrets that shoot you.Some features in this game I think are cool:- PvE AI that are both friend and foe.- Huge area of space to explore.- Land / Build on planets.- Shield generators!- Decently detailed component system(Reactors, Capacitors, Generators etc)- Logic ControlAll in all for the price tag, if you like Space & Sandbox builders this is an awesome game and would highly recommend it!

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								Starmade is amazing and almost limitless, while I will cover the current cons of this game I will tell you about how amazing and positive it truly is. So to start off the cons, sound. Sound is something that has been neglected for years with this game, although they are working on it, its put behind every other game mechanic. I understand why they did this but immersion is really key and would boost Starmade tenfolds. Second is NPC/ AI's another thing they are working on and are closer to completing but currently there are no AI's aside from silly pirates. When an update drops for NPC missions and AI's this will bring a whole new experience to the game.Onto some pros. The game is VERY addictive, I have been playing it for years now. I have to admit at times it can get dull, but when your friends are playing and you hop on its truly a blast. Creating anything you want is possible, the amazing work from Hull design and blocks to the sheer crazy logic work that people put into their build makes it amazing. You can download and upload ships/stations/logic from StarmadeDock easy to check out others work. Starmade has a great community from YouTubers/Streamers to every player giving advice. Lastly for now, Schine, these guys have worked their butt off on this game and it proves it with the sheer love they get in return. They listen to their players and deem what can and will be added, they love seeing the community post about ideas no matter what they are. I can only thank them for hours of fun.So I'd reccommend this truly, grab some friends, be creative and do whatever you please!

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								When I first heard of StarMade, I was excited, yet weary.  I have often let my emotions run amuck when I encounter a feature list as enormous and tantalizing as the one I read before I began to play this game for free.  To whet your appetite, here's a small portion of features already included in the alpha release. Build voxel spaceships/stations/settlements of all conceivable shapes or sizes using an absolutely enormous number of blocks.Easy-to-use interface and building mechanics which make construction an enjoyable experience.Full multiplayer functionality including factions, player-created economies, and servers which can be customized and modded to create a unique experience on a server by server basis.A nearly endless universe containing entire galaxies and solar systems all laced with an unchartable amount of planets, asteroids, space stations, pirates, wormholes, and intrigue.PVP and PVE combat, fight from the helm of your capital ship, cockpit of a fighter, or on foot using a huge and customizable selection of weapon systems against an enemy faction, space pirates, and crabsModding support.Immensely detailed crafting system.A full set of explorable, player created content and a community which constantly puts out a huge number of original masterpieces and recreations, from TIE Fighters to the UNSC Infinity.A development team which truly listens to the community and implements player ideas and creations into the gameA roadmap which includes programmable AI, AI creature support, a player-driven quest system, and so much more.You can build whatever you want, you can fly what you build through a truly endless world, you can do so with large amounts of people.I can't think of another game that claims to do this much and actually delivers.  Best of all devs consistently release new features and quality of life patches that constantly reinvigorate my interest in this game.If building your own spaceship and conquering the galaxy sounds at all appealing to you, I recommended you try this FREE alpha version of a fantastic game which is not even near completion yet.  You will not be disappointed.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a wonderful game with great potential.The systems that are present are complex enough, and with the latest updates of jump drives, rails, and shipyards, it's pretty much a space ship enthusiast's dream come true. There are plenty of customization options. The weapons system is probably one of the most interesting that I have seen as well as the power systems.The best part is that everything is MASSIVE. There is no end to it. There are pirates with suitable rewards for pve, entire planets to mine away, stars that will burn you if you get too close and traders who will sell just about anything. There is a strange mix of realism with fake rules that works really well with one another.The building system is easy to pick up, with more depth the deeper you go. The crafting systems could use some work, but the anaysis of systems is beautifully done. With regular updates and great support, I can see this game going VERY far.Also, do not call this Minecraft in space. The two games are similar on the surface, But they are in no ways alike.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								First off let me say space is awesome.  What a great setting to host this style of game. Inspired by Minecraft I believe Starmade is truly a new unique procedural sandbox experience.  The universe is huge, seriously...huge.  They way the game is developed is perfect for exploring star systems mining the planets exploring building factorys etc then moving into new star systems later.  I have 40+ hrs in so far and I am still learning new things. There are so many functional blocks in this game that do incredible things.  Its your imagination truly that limits you in this game as to what you can build.Building ships is the main focus, building with efficiency at first is very tough to do without doing some sort of research.  Power reactor design is vital, you can build a solid block for a power reactor but building it in different ways grants you more efficiency and more power. ;) I strongly recommend reading up on the game via wiki or other sources before playing, and play the tutorials.  Lots of you tube videos as well, this is a very large environment with lots going on.  It is amazing the things you can build and achieve in this game.  Just takes time to learn everything and patience.EDIT: always save your blueprints after or while building.

								I know a lot of people are hesistant to throw their support behind any early access project since it seems many of them never even make it to beta.  trust me, I bought Godus so I know exactly how that feels. number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Don't let my play time on steam fool you.I've been playing this game on and off since it was just a rough idea in 2012 and only shortly have bought it via steam.Things improved a lot over the years and are getting better and better.After a long way this game is for the type of people loving to be creative and invest some serious time in a game.There is not too much grinding but be aware, you'll need to mine and craft :)The game is voxel based, so everythig can be changed.Technical issues:Well there are some minor things but it does not keep you from playing and enjoying the game.The only thing, which is not mentionned too clearly is that this game uses java.For the people that are having issues with the game, be sure to install the adequate java version!64bit windows goes with 64bit Java!!! After installing the 64bit Java, change the memory allocation in the starting client to a higher value.For the people still running a 32bit OS I'll say that they should not expect too much and the game will not run too smoothly as it really needs some horsepower :)For me most issues like crashes and freezes or stuttering vanished after installing the right version of Java.********Graphics:Here we stick with nice clean graphics, not too fancy but it gets the job well done.*********Sound:Sound is OK, but I guess it will be better in a while.********Gameplay:The gameplay is really good and once you understand how to control things everything falls into place and you get accustomed very fast to the controls.********If you like building, crafting, being creative and many other things, this game really could be for you.There is no recipe mechanic, everythig is build via different constructors, so no need to wiki for this :)Yes there are logic blocks and yes there are a lot of other good ideas :)And btw, don't get overwhelmed by the shear scope of the game, start small, try some stuff and progress slowly.You can try the demo version at first to get a feel for the game and after you spend a lot of hours you'll probably, like me, buy the game ;)Run your own server and play with your friends, you'll see, the world is a big place and you don't have to be alone.

number of helpful: 16 of 24 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Update: I stand by everything I said.This is the best game I have ever played. Its more like EvE then minecraft. Better crafting the Minecraft. I can not stress how cheap this is for $10 bucks. Still in alpha and is already better then EvE Online. Let me say that again........ ITS BETTER THEN EvE Online! Let that sink in.The crafting system allows you to create anything you can imagine and its very well balanced. For instance you can make any ship currently in EvE, and if you don't like there design you can tweak it to your hearts content. The primary gameplay focuses on taking and hoding sectors of space. Your faction claims them and then gains faction points based on how much they currently control. You can make turrets, drones, titans, all with AI control so you can gurad your systems while offline.You can create space stations, and colonize planets. You can board and hijack ships and stations. The game is simple to understand and learn, but would take a lifetime to master every intricicy. Bigger is not better in all cases. A small covert ops ship can decimate and unpreppared titan. I could literally talk about htis game and compare it to EvE and Minecraft for weeks. But I would rather play it and leave others to make there own choice. I still have an EvE account and activlely play, but there has been more station spinning and Que rolling since this game come out on steam. Its free to try, demo is the full game and you can join a server to see what its like. Its hard in the begining but some basic understanding of EvE will help you adapt quickly. It is more of an RTS then anything else, gameplay wise.-The best way to play is online with other people. There is no feeling like flying around exploring.-Finding a huge base, some sick player created ships, and then realizing none of them have faction modules.... So its all yours for the taking. -Creating turrets to protect your bases and watching someone warp in on top of it and immediatly exploding.-Creating a large troop of Drones, and releasing them a couple of sectors away from someones base.-Blowing up someones planet as they beg you to stop.-Camping someones homebase while offline... with your turret monster.It just Keeps getting better as I play. At first you are trying to figure otu the mechanics of all the blcoks and how to accomplish what you want to to do. But as I go along I am coming up with really complex ideas and then, overtime testing them. Magnetic mines, Shotgun turrets and stop effect Lasers, oh my.You are sleeping on the next great game. All space games will be compared to this in the future.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is a tough one for me, I'd not recommend it to casual gamers yet, but do so for those who are more technically inclined and enjoy being part of a games development cycle.Buy this game if you like arcadey SpaceSims and building ships and are prepared to deal with lots of bugs and a long and slow development cycle.Despite it's Minecraft like roots this is not Minecraft, do not expect "Minecraft in Space" or that if you can run Minecraft you can run this game, it is pretty resource hungry and begs for a decent gaming PC.Do buy if you like tweaking things and have a good understanding of PC's. You'll need it to get the most out of the game.This game is the very definition of Early Access despit it's 3+ years of development. You are buying to play test it and report bugs, to help the development. If you are expecting a complete and optimised game look elsewhere.Do not buy this game if you own a Intel HD GPU, have low memory or just a basic desktop or laptop. You'll just end up playing at 5fps and crashing everytime you see a 1km long ship. Also avoid if you expect a fully functioning game anytime in the forseeable future and are easily frustrated and have little to no technical knowledge with computers and are not willing to learnPros:Massive Universe. Too many galaxies than you'll ever hope to explore.Decent and customisable Mechanics. Want newtonian physics? Turn them on. Don't like them? Turn them off. Most of the game can be customised via config files. Planet sizes, sector distances, ships speed, and more can be set to your liking.You can build virtually anything you can think of. From a tiny X-Wing fighter to a 1:1 scale 1.7km Battlestar. Despite it's blocky voxel nature you can create some really detailed ships and stations only limited by your imagination and PC's hardware specs.Fun PVP. Active servers and community, you can always find a server with people on it. Player battles can be fun and (now) drawn out affairs when ships are evenly matched,Great for Roleplayers.Great deal of content to work with and weapon/system variety. You'll always be finding new things to experiment with.Can that weapon maybe be used as an engine? Players are always coming up with new ways to use items.Persistant Universe done right. Dock your ship at your home station and log off. It's safe, unattackable and will be there in the morning unlike other games even though other players can still visit it. No frustration of days, weeks or months of work going down the toilet in 5 minutes to some a-hole griefer like you experience in games like Rust and ARK.Still while invulnerable there is a mechanic of faction points, allow your points to get too low and you eventually can be attacked at your home base.Makes you become part of the PC Master Race for real. No seriously, you will need to make your PC beast and up your PC gaming hardware and techical knowledge. No more 'I haz PC, so I iz Master Race' because you own a 13 inch Intel HD notebook with Windows, You are really gonna need to be Master Race material. XDCan for now play the full game free. But hey it's $10, don't be a tight♥♥♥♥♥and support the devs. If you try it for free and like it, BUY IT.And no doubt a bunch of other stuff I cannot think of right now.Now sadly onto the.....Cons:Uses Java.Game is Alpha, bugs and stability issues a plenty.Beefy system requirements. Forget where it says this game is scalable and designed to run on older computers. You'll be wanting powerful modern hardware to run a server or even play single player with a decent frame rate. 4GB of memory, 1 GB dedicated GPU or better a must. 64 Bit OS and Java, 8GB memory recommended. Even then large ships, stations and planets all at once will make your computer and probably you cry.Requires know how. The game defaults to very low memory, you'll need to know how to increase it, you'll need to know how to force your Java on your laptop to use it's AMD or nVidia GPU instead of the Intel HD crap it defaults to.You'll need to know how to tweak game settings. If gaming for you is turning on a box, inserting a game and little else, you're gonna have a bad time.Confusing interface. Options on the two different launch screens and options in game. They can all differ. What is available in game may not be available on the launch screen and vice versa. Some features may not make sense to you or may be ones you've not encountered before. e.g draw distance here works different to most games.Great for Rolepay. yeah, because there is no gameplay as such outside of building and mining. You have to make your own fun. Don't expect quests or epic battles with AI. AI pirates and trade guild are fixed one patch and broken the next.Speaking of which, patches, often they fix one thing while breaking another 2 or 3 things, and often you'll have to wait for the next patch (often months) for the issue to be fixed, just to find out it is actually broken more. No idea what the play testers on the test server are doing. It's clearly not play testing when things like the broken AI gets through to a release after just being fixed the previous patch. Hot fixes for such game breaking problems are extremely rare.Massive Universe, which will often feel more dead than alive due to lack of anything to do other than build and mine. Only life is the odd station with respawning space spiders.PVP: If you hate PVP and prefer PVE, you might hate this game, with nothing to really fight or kill at the moment other players will come looking for fun. Which will be seeing how fast they can blow up and loot your ship.Single player spam and lag: Be prepared to see a "Server is under heavy load contact a server admin" message in a big red box every 2 seconds even if your game is running fine. Experience random lag for no obvious reason even on a decent machine.Discriminates and punishes Left Handers. Yep that is right, if you're left handed like myself and rebind the WASD setup common to games these days to the Numpad as many of us lefties do, you'll find your controls conflict with building debug keys that are also bound to the Numpad and cannot be changed right now. Go into build mode on a entity with no systems press 8 (e.g forward) and POW your game crashes. Left handers be warned. :p (only affects build mode, regular play is fine.) Devs have no intention of fixing this yet.Stupid and uneccesary updates: Pirates broken? It's okay here's a patch that changes a perfectly fine block texture or renames an ore.........Who cares about the gameplay, we need to give the 2D artist something to do....... O_oUsual game forums based bad decisions. Space whales? let's add them to the game, because some forum junkies like the idea, forget the other million people actually playing the game who have no idea space whales are actually a thing being considered and feel they're completely stupid. Schine ignores the majority of players actually playing just like a real AAA studio. :pSeriously how about updates on the launcher or voting option so all are aware of what is happening? If we can have a "email bug to devs button" surely a "vote on stupid decisions button" would not be hard?And no doubt a bunch of other stuff I cannot think of right now.Summary:StarMade is a great game with a lot of potential and fun to play with friends if you're willing to make your own fun. Sadly though it often goes 1 step back for every step forward it makes.If you're patient and a space game fan who knows what is inside his/her PC and how tech works, and have a full understanding of what Early Access is and how it works I recommend you try and buy itt.If you're 12, love minecraft, think a 500 ping is great, love space whales, have no idea what a CPU or a GPU is, and expect Early Access games to be complete within a month of release, then please go away and stick to Wii U or Xbox.

content:
Posted: April 15
Early Access Review
								After a few false starts, I finally got this game to run and, I have to be honest, I AM ADDICTED.It is that simple.  I love sandbox games and while I will acknowledge that this game is not for everyone (since it does not have much in the way of prepackaged plotline or specific goals for players to accomplish), this game does a superlative job of providing an immersive, open-ended, do-what-you-want-within-the-constraints-of-the-game-engine type of experience.Want to start a faction?  Do it.  Want to design starships?  Do it... and then build them.Want to take on the pirates that just started attacking your Factions bases and are trying to muscle in on your territory?  Make that happen.All of these options and more are ripe for the enjoying.Go forth!  Create your own adventure and take control of your destiny!In StarMade, the Universe is ripe with potential experience and you are in the pilot's seat, so now it's time select a destination, chart a course for the Stars you have chosen and MAKE YOUR OWN STORY instead of relying on someone else to tell their story to you.

content:

Early Access Review
								First Impressions:A bit overwhelming at first but I'm slowly getting the hang of the interface and constructing ships.  I love the idea of being able to build a ship and travel to other planetary bodies.  The idea of building around your "core" block is an interesting one as you'll need to come up with designs that protect it from enemy fire.  There's a lot here for ten bucks (though the price will increase later on as development continues) and is an easy recommend to those who enjoy open world sandboxes.Edit: After some more testing, I am getting some really nasty lag.  My guess is that the single player mode still connects to an online server of some sort.  If this is the case, I'd really like the ability to play offline to eliminate the lag.  Hopefully the devs will address this and the server issues in a future patch.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'll start this review off by pointing out that i have played this game on and off for over a year now. This is one of those rare gems of a game that keeps you coming back for more forever as it is constantly improving through its passionate and dedicated dev team and community. But more then that. This is a game that has a nearly infinite depth in its mechanics and advanced build modes, logic systems, weapons systems..etc..etc which leaves you with nearly limitless possibilites in which to build whatever ship, base, station you can imagine. The mulyiplayer aspect is often quite engaging as well with its caring community, factions and moderators that always have interesting events planned and fun things to do, ranging from huge PvP tournements like Blood and Steel where you bring the deadliest machine you can build to wage war against other teams. Along with server bosses or christmas events..etc..etcOr even something as simple as taking a noob out to fight the pirates for the first time to hear them get excited when they get there first kill in their newly built fighter ship. Or even having to save that same noob later because he jump driven his ship into a star because thay havent learned that they should chart there course a little more carfully when traversing the cosmos.All of these things add up to a game that is absolutley satisfying , so long as you can muster the patience to overcome the admittedly steep learning curve required to understand the workings of this game competently.I certainly recommend this game to all who love space, sci fi, sandbox and voxel building games. But must say that it isnt for the faint of heart or those without much patience. But is for those who want to build the baddest mutha of a ship this side of the galaxy has seen
