content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Admittedly I will be a bit biased in this response as I am helping in the development for this game. However I will give the most honest answer I can.It's been far too long since I should have made this post. I have been playing StarMade consistently for over a year and discovered it far before that. (There is a good chance I have hundreds of hours but I don't use steam to launch the game so that is surely incorrect in my hours played) Since then it has undergone massive changes and very much so in a positive direction. Visually and gameplay wise it continues to become an amazing game. This review will be from the perspective of an experienced player around December 2015Graphics: This isn't any Star citizen, nor is it Space Engineers (a game it is often compared to) when it comes to graphics. The universe is cubed. It follows the trend set fourth by Minecraft (despite being planned long before MC made it's debut). I must say however, I never had such faith in the graphics of a voxel game. Even with shaders installed and a great texture pack, Minecraft can hardly come close to the visuals of StarMade. This is due to the use of built in normal, emission and specular maps. Additionally it has some very decent shadows as well. Like much of the rest of the game, a lot of this is configurable.Scale: The universe is massive. Often times I will hear new players remark on how large a ship is. To me the same ship may be small. The feeling of walking around a kilometer long spaceship is awesome and getting to that point in the game is worth the money alone. Space itself is split up neatly into grids, which allow this universe to exist at this scale. From sectors to systems to galaxies, you could spend your entire time flying and never see the same stars again. The only area where scale is lacking is planets. These objects often sit under a kilometer in radius. That said, I know it is intended to bump up the scale where possible. Despite pushing a java game beyond what is possible, we will eventually reach it's limit's. At least for now those limits have yet to be reached.Setting: The game is purely science fiction based. You can if you want turn on options for a more realistic experience, however the idea is that creativity should flourish and it should be fun to play. The universe is a bit empty right now, however rest assured. I myself am personally working on various assets that will be in the game and additionally we will see mechanics introduced that turn this into a bustling dynamic universe. Aliens, flora, space derelicts, cosmic anomalies. All of this is planned. Some of it is already in the game!Building: Building has never been simpler. All blocks and materials are 1 cubic meter. I think this is the advantage this game has over similar titles. There is no need to build a large chunky machine that serves a specific purpose. Or to place it in a way on your build so that it actually functions. You can have a ship that makes just about no sense, but it will still work. If you like it, why should the game punish you for that? Additionally there are crazy awesome build tools. Templates for shapes, copy/paste, undo/redo, and symmetry planes just to name a few. All of this easily accessible from your ship.Crafting: Crafting is simple and complex at the same time. There are 24~ resources that produce just about every block in the game, most of which you will eventually find a place for on your ship. These resources are fed into factories and can be automated and made more efficient.Combat/gameplay: There is a lot to learn here and it will likely be where a new player will get stuck. Combat can be exciting, however I expect balancing as well as new features to be added till release. There are multiple approaches though; shield tanking, armor tanking, dps based. You can use missiles, lasers, cannons, or turrets or combinations of all of this. You can install jump drives to escape, you can install jump inhibitors to prevent escape! No idea is too crazy for StarMade and a lot of science fiction based features have made their way into the game simply because they are awesome. I imagine learning how to play the game will be the hardest part for any new players. Learning to play is worth it however. The game's demo is free but will not be updated beyond beta or public release. As the game approaches full release the price will increase so now is the time! Take the time to learn and see what is possible and you will be getting your money's worth!TLDR; Easy building with great tools. Simply yet deep crafting system that makes sense. Massive universe and massive scale. Anything in the realm of science fiction is a reality and may become a part of the game as it develops!

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
  This game was gifted to me by a friend who purchased a 4 pack.  Game is still in active development.Minecraft meets Space meets Eve Online (sorta)It's a space voxel game with, currently, some faction elements, soon to have many faction elements. The game can be difficult and intimidating starting out. Lots of little things that aren't always made clear without some trial and error and some reading/watching online. But the event horizon is the limit when it comes to what you can build. Build your space ship or station out of blocks, and fly around space or set up a fancy docking ring. Mine astroids or planets, fight pirates or trade with others.Some of the features currently include (not all just some highlights):*Shipyards - Build a station and make a shipyard that will pull resources from containers to assemble ships from blueprints or your own creation.*Logic Systems - Ever play with redstone in minecraft? Than do we have a logic system for you! Build password protected doors, initiate launch codes for nukes or go to red alert!*Seamless Universe - See that galaxy over there? You can fly to it, or warp if it's in range. Wanna fly into a systems star? You can do that!  (Caution not recommend for health reasons) *Active Multiplayer - There's a fairly large array of populated servers with varing rule sets, but if that's not your thing there is singleplayer. There are player ran servers and some Dev servers.*Player Factions - With the current faction system you can join up with your friends and share with them or don't. Customizable rank system and faction alliance or war declare war.*Spaceship Fleets - Want to make big @$$ mother ships and have X-wing fighters escorting it? You can do that too.There's a lot of difference aspects of the game that I can't list all and the ways you can use them. If you've played it before long ago I'd recommend checking it out again, many new features have been added in the last year alone. If you're on the fence, know that Demo is currently the full game and FREE (until the end of alpha and/or beta/the game goes live). I'm considering purchasing a 4 pack to share with some other friends as well.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have mixed feelings for this game so don't bash me for the negative review when I write things I enjoy about this game, thank you.Overall the game is well built, however I have seen some people having crash issues and I think that is caused by Java having a lack of memory,or something else but I won't discuss that here. ANYWAYS the game is quite big, on some older servers I've joined to♥♥♥♥♥♥around on, I've seen serveral galaxies explored and on top of that the galaxies themselves are quite large, solar systems (even with a fast ship) can take roughly 20-30 minutes to traverse, longer if pirate infested (which in my opinion there needs to be less pirate stations due to the fact that heat seeking missles dessimate anything that touches them and the pirates and their stations have cannons for days).With that in mind if you have a well built ship which will take ages due to the credit and resource cost if you're crafting (more on that later) getting a ship that can not only hold its own, but fight back against a pirate station is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to get.Again, if you have a strong ship that goes fast exploration is enjoyable as you watch the planets and stars go by but can get boring after a while and one starts to resort to the use of jump drives more and more. And for crafting/getting resources, its tedious and grindy especially if you get a large ore haul and try to sell it but can only give each store around 4.5k ore before its completely stocked on it (if this happens sell until you're annoyed and then keep the rest for crafting use) I won't call crafting necesarily fun, its moreso a process of gettings components/ resources together, going afk or mining for a bit, and then coming back to check up on your factory.However building is truly the highlight of this game, there are several blocks to choose from each of these with their own colors and set shapes (there are 4 i think,being the cube,hepta,slope,corner and maybe something I missed?)With all the shapes and colors available allows for many designs and chassis shapes for ships and allows for one, if given enough time, to make their own unique ship but this is the only thing ,aside from making your own station, that there really is to do since exploring isnt too fun if you ave a long range jump drive and just hop over to a point of interest look at it and go back home. I wouldn't recommend this game to too many people I know but this game does have a great potential and would like to see where the devs take this game (I'm aware there might be a few things I missed once I get something decent together in my head for those parts I'll write it in) As of now I give this game a verdict of 4/10 but there is a present potential there and I can't wait to see what will be coming up in future patches.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Starmade, the game that killed my social life.10/10 It's ok(The demo is the full game until the beta comes out)But if you want a full review...Don't let my playtime deceive you, i have well over 1000 hours of pre steam play time.Starmade is a infinite 3D sandbox set in space with an infinite number of planets, stations, asteroids, stars, galaxies and pirates.You start off with enough blocks to build a small salvager and set off into space. (Well you can also make a nice big gun and attack other players) Then you need to mine asteroids and pretty much anything you find and upgrade your ship. May seem easy but its hard as hell. Pirates will be a constant threat. Teaming up is very important if you don't want your new shiny ship to be blown to the next universe by pirates.I could go on about how to play but wheres the fun if you already know everything?Just remember this game is in Early access and its going to change. Better or worse? no one knows. But with the current developers this game is going to go far.=Here is a little story about when i first met the dev=Turned starmade on one day. first time in a few weeks. There was a new update message talking about the offical testing server and the new improvments in the prebuild (dev build)I download the prebuild, join the server, fly into space, and get stuck. on nothing. my controls just didn't respond. about 5 minutes of laughing away in chat and others trying to help (only to glitch backwards, there was a horrible teleporting bug back then) Schema (the dev) joined the game.so i then asked him for help. He teleported in to see what was wrong and after a bit of silence "im stuck aswell..." Minutes later he said he found the bug and updated the prebuild.And that is the story of how i broke his game and caused one of the first (I think it may have been the first) updates since the test server went up

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Get. This. Game.It's easy to get into, and deceptively complex.  For example, they have logic blocks, aoe triggers, effects (on pretty much everything from lights to weapons) that you can do all kinds of  things with.  Those are  just a few examples.The game is freaking huge...not sure if it ever ends tbh...so many sectors in a system, systems  in a galaxy, galaxies in π and you have 42 (Gorilla math was used).The exploration is like a box of chocolates.  You could find a random shop to buy and sell  things, you could find a pirate station with turrets and ships attacking you, or asteroids, and I even hear you can find  a city but I've yet to find one.  There's planets and asteroids to mine, stations to build,  ships of every kind to make.  There's cloaking, radar jamming, scanning, jump drive (warping / long distance travel), push / pull weapons (tractor beam anyone?), drainers of all types, cannons, missiles, you name it, they probably have it.You can save your ship designs locally and on servers (multiplayer) and load them onto  another server using blueprints.  Think template that you fill with all the components and when the blueprint has all the parts it  needs you can spawn it.  You can build bases and outposts, or repair undiscovered /  unclaimed stations and  claim them as your own  / build on it.  There's factions (corps  / guilds) and every faction gets to claim 1 home base which is invincible to damage unless  they run  out of faction points (hard to do unless you claim alot of systems or die alot), Very customizable server settings so each multiplayer server you play on is probably different from every other.  You can customize your singleplayer server.cfg as well if you so choose.The cons:This is more on the servers you play on but when there's alot of people it tends to lag / warp.  (It's Alpha).  The initial RAM settings for the game is 1024  which  is really low.  If you are on a  64 bit OS you will want to download the 64 bit Java and change the RAM settings.  You can do this by going to the menu in the launcher > Options > Memory settingsI have 16GB RAM so I changed mine to 8192 1000 1000  and I stopped getting running out of memory errors  in game.  You will also most likely want to disable procedural background if you get alot of lag...caused me several seconds delay getting out of my ships in high pop servers.  All these options can be changed in the launcher, there's also advanced settings in  the launcher.All in all, this is a very fun game I would highly recommend it and I would buy it again.  I figured sooner or later there wont be a free demo and the price will most likely go up so why not support the devs now and not have to worry about it later on.Get in a faction with people or with friends as this amplifies the fun factor 10 fold.11/10 would buy again.

Early Access Review
								This game is good for anyone who likes a simple but expansive type of game. while the only complaint I can make is that the tutorial tends to lag a lot, the game makes up for it with its enless content and detatched and lonly vibe. Starmade starts off by dropping you into a sector with a shop, some money, and very limited resources for building a ship. While building a ship is fun, resources for a new ship are needed if your going off to fight pirates or raid a friend's base. The game essentially forces you into the depths of space, where you only have your crew. Starmade is a game that lets you mold it into what you want it to be, and I highly reccomend buying it.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Starmade is a crossover between Minecraft and Eve Online, although only on a very basic level. I'm not a big fan of both of these 2 games, but Starmade is just right.Whereas Minecraft mostly focuses on construction and survival, Starmade focuses on exploration and expansion. You are thrust into a huge world, and can do anything. You can build your own ships and starbases, land on planets and search for resources, mine asteroids and fight pirates. Much like Minecraft, Starmade is very focused on construction as well, but in a much more practical way. Upgrading your ship is something you continiously strife to do, and getting the resources required is a job needs doing. Building a ship might seem complicated at first, but a decen tutorial is added in the game, which will guide you through the basics.In short, this is my experience of Starmade thus far, and im eager to go on and grow. And best of all: It is free. Try the demo (i bought it) and get access to everything Starmade's got to offer. Whether you'll like the game or not: Not a penny has been wasted. I can really give no reason for you not to try.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								My favorite part of Minecraft was being able to build complex redstone creations to automate all sorts of things. If that's what you liked most about it, then this game is definitely for you. You can set up factories to automatically refine what you collect into pretty much any block in the game. The stack sizes are huge and you can expand the storage space of a "chest" as large as you'd like. So if you were into collecting large amounts of stuff in Minecraft, then you'll appreciate how much easier it is to manage here.The best thing about this game to me is the design/blueprint system. When you have a shipyard, you can create a design using creative mode, and then it'll tell you what blocks you need to construct it. You can save off that design to a blueprint and import it to another server or single player game. It's like having WorldEdit built into the normal course of the game.Pros:* One of, if not the best, building systems I've ever seen.* Ability to create huge ships and stations.* Lots of potential for automation.* The ability to save/import blueprints.* Good assortment of blocks to work with.Cons:* High learning curve.* Wikis are sparse, meaning you have to hunt through youtube videos to figure stuff out.* Pirates are devastating for new players. I had to cheat (ie. use creative) to get that first decent ship built. If I hadn't I would have given up on it. Could probably do it now without cheating, but it would take too long.* Some of the controls are inconsistent. Like shift slows you down, unless you're in build mode, then it speeds you up. Sometimes you use Q to go up, other times space.* Ran into a few issues getting it to run on Linux. Almost gave up (glad I didn't).Before this game, I was playing a lot of Elite Dangerous on a Vive. Better graphics and virtual reality were not enough to keep me entertained like StarMade has so far. I wish it were a little more popular, but it has enough for me to play for years, just as it is now. If you can make do without a large multiplayer community (I play SP), and you like building, then I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you want Minecraft in space this is your game. It has thousands of block planets randomly generated in many block galaxies you can fly around in your block ship. You can also build stations or directly on the planets themselves if you would prefer to get into base building instead of ship building. I had a lot of fun making my own mini starport on my first playthrough and launching into space.In multiplayer it has a faction system for claiming home bases and planets, you can build ship interiors and invite friends to fly around with you. Or you can sacrifice interiors to fill your ship with more modules to make them more powerful. Compared to games like Space Engineers its much more fast paced, you can mine enough materials and build huge ships pretty fast in a creative mode like editor.And the game is free with no restrictions if you want to try it before you buy it like I did, I was happy enough with it to want to support it and buy the full version which is no different from the demo version at the time I am writing this review. I have to give the developers a lot of respect for doing that, such a bold move.

content:

Early Access Review
								Great concept for a game but when it comes down to it but it seems as though the developement is snail pace. From what i understand this game has been out for years and hasnt really progressed. The community has been waiting over a month since the last update for bug fixes that are killing gameplay.While indeed the game is fun it is not particularly stable. Servers are a whole other story entirely. Server support seems minimal or just poorly done, either or. This game is only fun with other people, there is no real single benefit apart from unlimited blocks, but even then that kind of kills the point in my opinion. I would stay away from Single player and join a multiplayer server but that obviously brings you to encounter the above.What devs dont seem to realise nowadays is people would prefer a stable game over faster released additional content. People are ditching this game for purely this reason. Its like trying to put together a new desk while standing on your head..overall you're creating more problems for yourself in the long run.When it comes down to it I paid the money for this game so i'm going to stick with and hope for the best. I do enjoy the game and have played a lot of hours but everything above causes so much frustration. I do of course understand this game is still in Alpha but if given the choice im not sure I would purchase this again. Summary ~ Great concept, shoddy execution.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								First things first...  in my opinion) this game is amazing, but far away from being flawless:Starmade is a voxel based sandbox game in space. A game where the player is able to build massive objects like a fully functional(!) Deathstar or a Viper from Battlestar Galactica or anything else one can think of. The only limit is ones own imagination. But thats not all. There are plenty of different things to explore, like space stations or ancient ruins on planets. Or you can just adventure out into deep space, to find asteroid fields to mine. And as an nice addition, the map is gigantic!That said, getting into the game can be a bit rough, because the tutorial, while it is very helpful and offers plenty explanations about everything in the game, is buggy as hell and pretty boring (although, that opinion can differ from person to person) .The controls are easy to learn, but a bit, well, I would say underwhelming. You cant decide how fast you fly. It is either maximum thrust or nothing. Also, the menu system is far from perfection and very confusing at first.And please dont even speak about the AI-quality. So, what is it, that makes me love the game, as much as I do?Well, here´s a list:- Starmade is very configurable through some easy to understand config. data- Huge fleet battles are possible if your rig is strong enough, that said, Starmade runs pretty smooth overall. Even on low end systems.- Dogfighting is super fun. - Weapon systems are pretty in depth- Starmade looks astonishing beautiful, if you`re into that kind of voxel based textures.- Multiplayer runs very smooth, as long as your ping is manageable-And most important, the overall mixture of building, fighting, exploring, mining and more building is just fun That said, I DONT recommend this game, if you plan on playing Starmade purely for the singleplayer experience. because, the lack of (good) AI and nice NPC ship designs is kinda meh.On a server with dozens of people on the other hand, this game is amazing. (Or even a small one, with just you and your two or three best friends). You can even upload ships or stations you've built in singleplay onto the server. Personal rating: 8,5/10

content:
Posted: December 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								The good:- A tutorial - as in there actually is one and it's moderately useful- Various texture packs built in to the client so it looks less Minecraft-like- You can build *massive* ships and there is a decent selection of utlity modulesThe middling:- OK build tools - far better than Minecraft, maybe worse than Space Engineers- The star systems are basically all the same - pick any one and you can find every resources you need, no reason to explore- There are NPC enemies, and they will pester you, but don't expect to be challenged by cleverness.  Tenacity perhaps...The bad:- The crafting interface.  Yes it has a filter to search, but no categorization.  Browsing a small list is painful.- The UI elements.  Ok, this is early access, some of it is likely developer art.  Recommend these guys go look at Space Engineers for a better example of UI.- The flight model.  Flight games *scream* for a joystick and rudder system - this system only supports one controller at a time so unless your stick does everything, it comes out to be much less useful.  Using a keyboard and mouse to fly anywhere near a planet is basically an exercise in frustration - get a gamepad at the minimum for when you step inside a ship.This game is like Minecraft in space, but without so much grinding trying to find resources (they are in fact very easy to get once you build a salvage ship - you will spend more time waiting for the resources to process than actually acquiring them.)  If you like *building* things, you will enjoy this game.  If you like *fighting* things, your enjoyment will probably be short-lived.  If you like *exploring*, you're enjoyment will also be short-lived.But it's still Early Access, so give it some time.  It will no doubt improve (just see how far Space Engineers has come along.)

content:

Early Access Review
								I've been a player since pre alpha, the game has an awesome UI. The ship building is fairly simple to get started. The game shows you how to make a basic space clunker, and how to mine the environment, and you will find it is easy to get moving.The problem lies in how spread out some of these planets and resources are, ESPECIALLY in multiplayer.The second main issue is the clunky launcher and massive memory/fps issues. I have a very respectable gaming setup, and I am always crashing, you need to have 64 bit java, and the correct memory values input into the game launcher, the one before you actually start the game. Why the game has essentially two launchers is ridiculous. The game online suffers from the same problem Minecraft does online, you have to hike 50000000000 miles/galaxies away to get started because everything is claimed or you will get ganked. So if you are looking for a fun space sandbox, look elsewhere. If you are looking for Minecraft in space, look elsewhere.I cannot recommend this game at this time.Edit: "At this time" Meaning I am AWARE its not at release yet.

number of helpful: 14 of 23 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								Ahhhhhh, Starmade. Where to start?First off, I have had this game for a long time, I only recently linked it to my steam account, Don't give me any of that"You've only played one and a half hours" Also, Just because a game is in early access/ beta doesn't make it exempt from critisism. The Good:-Looks fabulous for a block based game. Shadows, bloom, all of it is great and I love it.-Intresting in a way that not many othe games can pull off. This means it is stable, works, and has good content.-Frequent updates. This game gets new content often, and I genuinly beleive the people at schine are working hard.-Building is fun. In some games, building is a chore. You can be delighted as ideas fly through your head, and possibly your left foot, such "Should I put escape pods?" or "Should I put a turret here?" and so much more.Now, the bad:-It gets boring, theres nothing to convince you to build, and after a while, you just get sick of it. What this game needs is a story that gently prods you in the right direction, like  the one in the game Rodina. The proceduraly generated worlds dont have much variety.-Multiplayer is a cut-throat tedious, and rage inducing experience. You can be a newbie in a server and be killed instantly, or be a pro and griefed to extinction.-The community is dieing. Servers used to be full of people, hundreds, but today you'll be luckyto find 30.-It's going to take you  a long time to be able to build the stuff in the screenshots.In conclusion:This game is a great concept that hasn't really been driven in the right direction. Some updates and a story would make this game my favorite ever easily. Back to Star Trek Online for now.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								I full heartedly support this game. I've been playing it since learning about it, about .4x release or so, back on Minecraft when i asked a few of my buddies about any other games like it. And by far this game TRUMPS Minecraft when it comes to sheer size, exploration and sense of seclusion.The game itself is a massive sandbox for those wondering about it. It allows you to build practically *anything* from houses,  hovercraft and mining vessels, to fighters, gigantic mining stations and factories! The game itself requires a very good computer to run (a 400$ Acer like me, cannot handle the newer patches to the game for instance. I'll be able to play the game in February in earnest when i build my new gaming rig :) )This game also supports exporting projects from 3-dimensional tools like Blender as blueprints! which then can be implemented into the game and 'purchased' with in-game currency. This helps when you see a 3D model and think "if only i could fly it" ;) Combat is heavily based upon your ability to protect your 'baby' (your ship or creation) and it gives you a VERY wide variation in weapons and protection possibility! From mobile sentries to stationary defense platforms you can protect worlds, sectors or even entire quadrants! The game is literally stagnated only by YOUR creativity. YOU control the fun. YOU control the environment for the most part. And as the game says in the description, it is YOUR universe.Personal experience with the game: I first started up on a mini-server called Illusive with 4 buddies of mine. we made a faction called "The Fringe". We hung around the spawn for a couple days, learned how to build basic ships and began an adventure out into the void which lead us nearly a THOUSAND sectors away! it took us nearly an hour to reach our base... what started out as a derilect NPC shop out of supplies. We branched off, made 7 massive combat vessels over the course of 2 months and made 6 sentries capable of holding off the average A.I pirate (special made ships which turned out to become more aggressive over the years.) Our three flag ships....The Leviathan: a massive Dreadnaut carrier (blender model i made) designed to carry 120 small fighters with 2 lasers. With 1k engines and a little over a million shield the beast didn't move fast.. but it could take a beating.  Leviathan picture[thesurviver.deviantart.com]The Liberty: A smaller ship, designed to be made in bulk as carriers, support vessels, combat cruisers. These were going to become the backbone of an A.I based defense fleet of about 15 ships. Lead by my buddie's "Shadow" Liberty shown here.  Shadow Liberty[thesurviver.deviantart.com]The Behemoth: A project i was working on for nearly 2 months and ended up halting because the size was killing my frame rate (at least until next month ;) ) And at nearly 18million it was not going to be something i could simply spawn in. With that in mind i made this beast a floating battlestation. With 6 guns capable of a mind-boggling 1mil damage output per second, a shield of nearly 100million and a battery chamber that engulfed the inner body of the ship, it wouldn't be going down without a fight Unfortunately my computer couldn't run ascreenshot without crashing the game once i got the second 3 barrel cannon on the ship, so here it is in the prototype stages Behemoth wrapup part 1[thesurviver.deviantart.com] after the first month this is what had been made.... Another ship, which i unfortunately do not have a picture of, is an even BIGGER ship that a member of the Fringe we picked up later had built. It held 18 turrets on either side, with a gun that lined the middle of the dual hull ship with a damage output that made my ships sound like a laughing stock. He spent 7 months building it up. The ship was called the Keldon. I have a partially damaged blueprint of the ship personally saved and will hopefully be able to repair it. However sitting at a whopping 128million to spawn it? i'll be working on it in singleplayer. lol

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Probably one of my best game purchases ever. I played it for several hundred hours before finally buying it, and still play it at least 10 hours a week, usually in one session.The best thing I can say for the game is that I keep forgetting it's early access. It's an amazing game already, and so much is coming still. I think it will eventually fill the promises it made, as well as all the failed ones that most, if not all, space sci-fi games made.Pros:-Ships are super-fun to design and build, and ship building is quite in-depth.-Multiplayer is unbelievably smooth, even with hundreds of ships, small or large, all fighting. That said, your client might need the settings turned down if the ships are big enough. Some people (myself inluded) build ships larger than planets.-The universe feels alive. They've redone the map, and it is glorious. We have blackholes (wormholes) now too, and a wide variaty of stations, planets and astroids now.-Despite the above, it manages to highlight how big and empty space really is, which is something i enjoy.-Docking is quite impressive and flexible, allowing for really cool effects to ships (Such as moving parts).-THE DEVS LISTEN TO THE COMMUNITY-Beautiful Graphics (if you like cube games)-So many awesome features, Im not going to even attempt to list them-Excelent Configurability-Good Community-Good mod support (never tested this, but I've heard no complaints about it)-Procedurally generated, and absolutly HUGE.-Probably forgot lots-Most importantly: The game is always improving, very quickly too. The devs push large quantities of bugfixes and updates every 2 weeks. It's similer to Space Engineers in that respect. Does not feel like an alpha game, really.Cons:-They're missing the inverse-corner shape D: I should get around to suggesting this. But I'm too busy playing the game.-AI still needs work, though it's getting better-Factions need work as well, though that's coming in a future update-Very large systems cause non-negligable client lag (negligable server lag though) (I mean multi-thousand block doors, etc)-Very large ships cause some lag (500x300x300 m3 + on my craptop, but easily 10 - 1000+ times that for good laptops. Virtually unlimited for a solid desktop.)-Alpha game. Lots of balance changes, content changes, etc.-Tutorial needs a lot of work - it's outdated. Again. Mostly because of the update frequency.Very addictive game, good if you like designing spaceships, or space combat. The game also fully supports mining, trading, etc, however, I stick to ship building, because that's my favorite part. This means I can't speak for those systems, but I've heard they're good.If you want a good example of the game currently, get the demo - it's the full game, and it will be, until the game leaves Alpha. If you want a good idea of where the game is headed, and how it's changed/is changing, check the website, and look at the "news" tab.For some of the best reviews about why I (and many others) like the game, read the funny reviews tab.Edit: Forgot to mention the learning curve. I joined back when the tutorial, buggy as it was, was plenty. At the moment, however, the game has become so complicated that I'd recommend starting in MP and asking a player to teach you, or watching a youtube video.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game caught my eyes while I was browsing games to buy in the steam shop.  I saw the trailer and I bought it right after that.I have probably spent 95% of my playing experience in singleplayer.  I didn't have any help from real players so this review will be in that perspectiveFirst, I'll go with the cons.  You can get pretty lost in the launcher for the game.  Also, if you don't set your memory to a good level and don't set the graphics to a level your computer can handle, you might not even be able to run the game at a good speed (or at all).  There is also a bit of a learning curve to the game.  For the first few days you play, you will probably spend just as much time playing the game as you will watching youtube videos trying to figure out how to make things work properly.  As for the youtube videos, a lot of them are a bit outdated, and finding a recent video can be difficult.  There's also not a lot of content when it comes to singleplayer, but that's because this game was built more for the multiplayer experience.  Although there are many planets and systems, they are very similar to each other so the only thing that makes you explore is having to move to the next system to find more resources.  For where the game is at, I think the build mode is pretty great, but it could use some tweaks to make it faster and easier.  For example, I find it a bit tedious to have to go into 'advanced edit' and having to press an arrow 5-10 times and look at a tiny picture of the selected piece, trying to find the right orientation of the block you're trying to place everytime I switch to a different part of a ship.  And I find that most of the time, I get the wrong orientation because in some lightings it's very difficult to tell which direction the block is facing in the tiny picture if it's all one color.  I think a system where you could click and hold the mouse button then move your mouse in different directions to change the orientation would make building 1000% easier (maybe they already have an easier way and I don't know about it).  That's all I really have for cons.For the pros, this game is just amazing.  If the thought of building your own ship and scavanging the galaxy for resources excites you, this is the game for you.  If you want to build a ship with a ridiculous amount of salvage modules so you can mine to the core of a planet in the click of a button, you can do that.  If you want to build extravagant space stations where you can store all your ships, you can do that.  If you want to kill pirates and plunder their stations, you can do that.  All this I'm explaining is still only scratching the surface.  Once you get into multiplayer, there are factions you can join and wars you can fight.  This game is so fun and is only going to get better with every update.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ok, after I fixed the game thanks to the superb support staff at Starmade, I must say I am exited for my future endeavours in this huge universe. If you are having the player drifting problem, follow these steps.unfortunately it looks like your installation is broken.The best and easiest way to fix it, is to create a new folder and start with a fresh automatic installation of starmade.To do this,browse to your hard-disk (C:) and create a new folder.I suggest using the path:C:\Starmadehowever, any path not in a protected area from windows will work. ('Programs', 'Desktop', 'Download' and 'My Files' are places that can cause problems. Antivirus scanners block access or scan every file-access and slow down your game without a good reason.)Now place a fresh downloaded launcher from the official download pagehttp://star-made.org/downloadin that folder and start it.Now select the correct path in the Launcher:enter the correct path into the opening dialog:Hit OK andlet it install the latest version by clicking on:in the Launcher.Your starmade should work now.If not please add log from that installation.Open:C:\Starmade\StarMade\logsand send in all files you see in that folder.We will check for the source of the problems then.(Yes it may sound like a fraud, but this is the only way we have a reliable log, where we have a good knowledge about the load orders and events happening.)- Andy Püttmann^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ This guy rocks

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Do you like 4x RTS games? Well this is essentially a 4x RTS played from the perspective of a single minecraft astronaut.When you get past the ship creation and crazy engineering aspects of this game, it feels like an MMO 4x RTS where you build an empire (faction) and claim entire solar systems for resources.This game is insanely good if you can get over the minecraft graphics and bugs and experience the game for what it is, a crazy genre bender of MMO/voxel sandbox/Space Sim/4x RTS.I HIGHLY recommend this game to anybody who is even remotely interested in building ships/space stations, open world corpse looting hardcore PvP or space RP.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing! The graphics can be as good as you choose, so you can run it on almost any computer. It works amazingly well, no matter what you want to do.This game has too many features for me to explain in one review, but I can definitely say it's way better than any game like minecraft, or terraria. The only ideas it shares with those are using blocks, mining, and being a sandbox, and they doesn't just copy it, they make it their own way.There are shops where you can buy whatever you want, and a shop acts like a real shop does, having it's own money to buy your stuff, and having limited stock.But there are more ways to get stuff than just buy them. Some things you can mine, some things you can make with the things you mined and some can be found from the loot of destroyed ships.I admit, they still have features to work on, glitches to remove and inconveniances to fix, but I definitely reccomend getting the game. They fix glitches you report insanely fast, they consider all suggestions, and they just make a great game. 10/10

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you love minecraft this is pretty much the next step.  Still needs alot of work but the devs are keeping up with updates and what there working on.  But if youve always wanted to build your own space craft and fly arcoss the galaxy this is it.  Construction consists of more than your basic square block, theres several tetra shapes and wedges to give a craft or object a more round apearence.  Collecting blocks (mining) is very easy and quick depending on how you do it.  Lots of cool stuff to play with like missiles, sheilds, automatic turrets and AI's.  Graphics arent quite there yet.  Lowest setting some blocks have more detail than they do on the highest setting but it should get fixed(i would think). But ive had alot of fun just playing in single player but it can get boring by yourself.  But thats why theres multiplayer.  Overall its a really good sandbox for the stage its in.  If it follows the minecraft dev line there will always be new content and fun stuff being added and worked on.  Well worth the cheap price!

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is so close to being an absolutely amazing game. Currently, without a more complex/dynamic NPC faction system, my biggest problem is that there isn't enough to do in single player. I don't have a ton of time to invest in playing on servers, so I think that solves that problem, just not for me. Another problem I have is that there are a TON of systems and mechanics to learn, and perhaps they're not the most intuitive. I haven't played in months, but the crafting system was a bit confusing for me back then, and more stuff has come in since then.Now, done with the negatives...This is a great game. Open world? Not good enough, try open space. The building system is fantastic, and you should check out some of the ships and stations people have made- they're absolutely stunning, nothing short of spectacular. The combat mechanics are fun and exciting, and there's a lot of room for ships of different combat and non-combat roles.I can only say GET THIS GAME. It's a ton of fun, and the progress made over the past year is phenomenal. The devs are doing a great job and like I said- this game is just a couple features and improvements away from being something truly special.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've only played a little over 8 hours so far and I'm simply floored by how cool this game is. The game's Minecraft like take on spaceflight and spaceship/station building is simply fantastic. While my current ship building ability is akin to a 3 year old drawing on the wall with crayons, I'm simply in love with the full gamut of things available to build with. Looking on Youtube you can find users who've built fleets of Titan class ships that look absolutely gorgeous and wonderfully showcase what this game can let you build.The first ship I built was simply a small cube. It was hideous, but after a run in with a pirate station (which chased me for a fairly long ways) I had to rebuild. I landed on a planet and mined the only thing I could see: lava. I wondered what I could do with lava and found out that while it's useless for crafting, it makes a seriously bright ship. So I built a ship out of lava. After watching some videos on youtube I realized that I'd just wasted a significant amount of time doing nothing, and I built a better ship purely for mining. It's ugly as sin, but it can demolish an asteroid in about 2 minutes, so I'm happy with it for the time being. After I mine a bit more I'm going to dive into crafting, then I'll make a really big ship. (Currently mine doesn't have an inside) I'm also hoping that (since I know how to use Photoshop) I can possibly contribute to some of the texture packs on http://starmadedock.net So far I haven't recommended any game to my friends as much as I have this one. I already bought the 4 license pack and hope the developers keep on chugging away on this, it has so much potential.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								The only thing that'll turn most people off is the fact that this isn't really a pick-up and go type of game that people with an attention span of a gold fish are so used to these days..   You really have to sit down and figure out what kind of ship are you going to make, and that is where the real fun of the game begins.    I made a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ transport-looking shuttle that I use for construction and stuff, and even added a door on the side so i can get out and come back inside, and even placed lights inside the ship so i can see where I'm walking to go sit at the cockpit and fly the thing.   Once you figure things out from the tutorial menu, things will begin to make sense.   The Menu UI is cluttered, but at the same time helpful once you look past it.   Best feature of this game so far?  You can start a single player mode right away and mess around with the game and learn how to play it before going online and even importing your saved ship in a blueprint file so you won't have to waste time building before getting blasted by other players, something like that piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥ "Rust" doesn't do!Some online servers are "PvP" so, it's a good idea to save your blue prints and gather the materials you need to make your ship right off the bat so you're not empty handed.Think of minecraft and star citizen mixed in together.   Do whatever you want.  explore derelect ships, mine resources, fight people.  I heard the universe is very expansive, so there's that too.   Oh and if you want to build the millenium falcon, it can happen as long as you have enough resources.

								+400 hrs minecraft+150 hrs empyrion+30 hrs space engeneerhi this is more a WARNING than a review , this game has a lot of potential but, in it's state it is very incomplete, unpolished and with a very steep learning curve. Try the demo to get an idea for yourself. i hear they are working on the game but i have notice they are puting more new stuff in the game than polishing it. And to finish this review THANK GOD i'm ok in computer trouble-shooting this game is not user-friendly to start or debug, good luck with that. hummm. great potential i tell you so i'll check back in a while you never know.Todo list:A very intuitive tutorial.A very easy level for new or extreme casual player.A few  limited blueprint to start the game.A factory guide ingame.A way to tweak the world you play in.

Early Access Review
								Hi everyoneI was bored and in search of a new game and i came across this diamond.When i frist started the game i didnt know what to do, but it was not too difficult to get into the game.Mastering was a bit more diffucult. Then we had a dedicated server.It was great fun to climb the learning curve from a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ship to planetary harvester and doomstar which can kill a planet with one shot. My gaming time was before buying the game -> just 11 hrs. Now we dont play much because so much new stuff is added  (which is very good) and we want to wait a little bit. I thought about cons alot. i hatet the non newton flight model (->i like it when things are floating through space forever) but now we have it in here as well and i love it.So it is pretty hard judge before the game is not finished.My conlusion -> Play the whole game for free (DEMO). You can not do wrong. And dont let you scare off in first 5min.You will miss a lot of fun.

								Very good sandbox game i watch over the years. Build Your ship, stations, bases with blocks. Very nice customization of weapon types. Game still under developement but every patch is big enough. Constant update of mechanics/content/graphics etc. Only disadvantage i found imho are "planets" - too small, too strange, not realistic. content:
Posted: October 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								StarMade is ruining my life but that is okay :P played about 80h so far (in about 5 days cause the game doesn´t let me sleep very much) and finally start to understand the basics...this game is extremely difficult to start with....the tutorial is almost a 5 min videotalk followed by you being lost in space with a shipcore and a couple of credits. There are some good tutorials on youtoube though which you will need cause some things are too techy to work out yourself without being a bloody electrical engineer or something^^The design options are infinite and with the logic modules etc you can (in theory) build semi automated fleets. However, you better be prepared to spend 5h on making your first logic circuit work....or 15h on designing a turret to dock to your ship...or ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s of hours to design a rail docking system for your mining drones.One real hint to take away: Create blueprints of your beloved ships to be able to rebuild cause pirates turn out to be rather strong and can easily rip your ship apart with a few shots.Back to building my carrier...over and out ;)

number of helpful: 13 of 22 people (59%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 17
Early Access Review
								Originally StarMade had wonderful promise as a spaceship building and survival game. A comparison to Minecraft in space could have been made, but honestly, StarMade had surpassed in regards to building. Being able to build a salvaging ship and compacting it into your cargo bay was pretty awesome. So was being able to co-op an entire side of the planet and turning it into a mobile base of operations.But the game felt clunky. Little explanation, if any, on how to get started. Survival aspect never was really fleshed out, though a lot of cool progress was made in that direction, but has now seemingly been abandoned in the interest of turning the game into a RTS. Which might be cool in a Unity system, but due to the engine being built on Java makes no sense. Both the community and developers have also seemingly turned hostile against any criticism, which is disappointing.

number of helpful: 20 of 36 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17
Early Access Review
								Theres no content and very many preformance issues. Devs keep saying they will add content and things to do after theyve built a solid base but its been 4 years now and this game is still a laggy bug filled mess. Absolutley not worth $20 and the price is still going to incrementally increase. It has alot of potential and I feel bad leaving a bad review because I know the devs are passionate and work hard with the limited resources they have but the game still suffers. Planets dont ever fully load, weapon graphics bug out and I can only se them half the time, theres no survival aspect: no hunger/sleep/enemies to fight other than generic pirates. Basicaly the biggest problem with this game is that there is no reason to get out of your ship core EVER. Also there are so many game mechanics which are not explained in game or at all. You have to resort to youtube tutorials made by gamers who dont always explain things right. If you havent been following this game from day 1 you wont know what any of the blocks do at all. Like how is a new player supposed to make a basic salvage ship without resorting to online tutorials? Theres no information at ALL for the game functions. Not an exaggeration. I still play this game though because hopefully one day it wil get better.

number of helpful: 16 of 28 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24
Early Access Review
								Don't be fooled by my playtime as I usually play without using steam.Pros:* Excellent ship building. This game probably outshines many other games when it comes to building. It has many tools to make building a lot faster and easier* Multi-player. Even though it can lag in larger ship battles, starmade probably provides the best multi-player experience of all space building games out there. It's especially fun to build and explore with friends on a server. It also provides to ability to run dedicated server for both linux and windows.* Scale. No other game provides this kind of scale. The biggest ships in other games wouldn't even be considered medium sized ships in this games. There are also some extremely beautiful ships made my the community from all kinds of franchises * Great weapon system. Weapons can be combined and used in a lot of different ways. It's very fun to play around with it. It's however a bit imbalanced at the moment for PvP, but that is to be expected of a game in alpha* Logic Systems and Rails. This feature is one of the best. You can virtually build anything. The rail system allows for complex doors, elevators, and countless other mechanisms. The logic systems lets you control you build things from simple light switches to password protected doors to even crazier stuff like space monopoly.* Fleets. Although a bit buggy at the moment, the fleet system allows you to bring your own carriers into battle.* NPCs. The new update provided lots of gameplay for single and multi-player and finally made the universe feel a lot more aliveCons:* The game is still in alpha and that shows at several points in the game. Some features need polishing or more work and there are some bugs. However the devs have announced they will address these issues.* Depending on your playstyle there is not much to do after a certain point in singleplayer. The NPC update did help with that, but there more is needed, and it has been announced that there will be more.* Some ex-community members are extremely petty. Some got banned for insults and trolling on the forums. They like to spread conspiracy theories on the devs, like this game becoming an RTS, even though the main dev explicitly said that is absolutely not true and the claim is pretty ridiculous to begin with. They also post bad reviews from their little group and delete any comments. Another guy keeps bumping his own negative review, also removing any discussion. Keep in mind that all these people got at least 500 hours of playtime on their accounts, which makes this all the more laughable. Some like to discredit java with their nonexistent knowledge of programming languages, which is easily debunked.EDIT: Since redalert is suggesting I'm not on the forum let me insure you, I've been there for a long time, but not with this username.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing (Currently in Pre-Alpha), the map is so intelligent, it is sorted by Solar Systems, then each system has a lot of sectors, so it's not hard to find places (though it can be due to the vastness of space). Even though the space in this game is not realistic (it's in the km distance ranges) it works 100% due to the way everything looks and feels. Jumping through space is freaking awesome. Designing ships is awesome.IF I COULD ADD ONE THING TO THE GAME, IT WOULD BE THRUSTER TRAILS THAT CAN HAVE THEIR COLOR CHANGED WITH THE ROD LIGHTS (the same way you change bullets on weapon modules, place it in front of the barrel) =DDIf the trails were like 1-3 blocks in length, that would be awesome, and would add incentive to actually having thruster blocks in a visable part of your ship, instead of "fake" thrusters that most people make with Crystal blocks to show glowing plasma / hot turbines. This works and makes a ship look great, but I would honestly love trails to see some distance / speed. It would also be helpful to finding other ships when they're moving fast (some servers have +speed mods). It would also be awesome if the trails extend for a very short period of time when a ship jumps, that way ships that stay behind can see a "thruster ghost" of all of the light left behind from the thrusters. :3Also aminals. Not really super important, but it would be cool to see some actual life forms in the game aside from pirates and shops. :3 just sayingBUY THIS GAME EARLY ACCESS, OR WAIT TILL RELEASE, EITHER WAY IT'S EXTREMELY AWESOME. =]

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has lego style blocks, starships, stars, warp drives and BLACK HOLES! That ^^^^ right there is enough for me to recommend this game. HOWEVER: Note that this game is still incomplete, and it shows. As much as I love what's going on here and the raw potential this game has, note that there's some issues, read: many issues, yet to be resolved. For example, Travel is unbelievably slow. You can easily change this by editing a text file (google "How to increase Starmade speed limit"), but this is not something a noob like me would even know was possible, let alone standard. Also, the planets currently have no mobs that spawn, so apart from gathering resources here and there, selling them, building a ship, travelling about, and I suppose fighting pirates or joining a server, there isn't much to do. At least it feels that way after awhile. Other stuff needs to be added to make it more engaging. Also, I do not like the crafting system at all, and find that I have much more fun just using console commands to acquire items and building my own ship creative mode-style.But all-in-all, yes, I recommend this game. I'm having fun with it--just know that if you're the type who doesn't like building things.. this game is definitely something to reconsider.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								I love the possibilities with this game, and I recommend it to any sci-fy fan. There is a learning curve with this game, but I consider it a game worth learning.Some things you can do in StarMade...You can mix and match weapon systems and support systems for cool useful effects. You can save the ship you just built as a blueprint, build a ship yard, and have it make more ships. You can design functional turrets.  The logic system in the game is stunning, and with it you can make moving platforms, combine logic systems, and do other amazing things. You can explore massive galaxies, connect star systems by warp gates, raid pirate bases, mine asteroids or entire planets.There are many things I am still learning about this game, and some small details I want fixed, but I am loving StarMade as it is, and look forward to its continued development.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								StarMade definitely has a lot of elemnts of "Minecraft but in [blank]" syndrome going on. It's true. However, it has enough complexity, unique block shapes, and sheer /content/ to make it very much stand on its own. This complexity, though, can also be a bit overwhelming, especially if you want to make a ship that "does everything." As of right now, it's not the best at explaining what a lot of blocks do, so you may find yourself on the wiki alot. Despite that, StarMade is still an excellent game. The visuals are pleasing, the mechanics are ultimately as complex as you want them to be, to a point. The sheer amount of ship customization is jaw-dropping, and allows for making truly unique, awesome ships that are tons of fun to use and play in. Like Minecraft, it doesn't particularly have a story, and so you find yourself making your own narrative, which is a bit of childish fun missing from a lot of games. Overall, StarMade is a fun game, and if you're willing to stick your head into the wiki a little, the potential it has is mind-boggling. It could use a bit more explanation on certain mechanics and blocks, but finding them out is often its own reward.

Early Access Review
								TRY THE DEMO, THE GAME IF FULLY FREE WHILE IN ALPHA, THE DEMO IS CURRENTLY THE FULL GAME CLIENT AND NOT PURCHASE IS REQUIRED TO PLAY THE FULL GAME AT THIS TIME. PAYING IS FOR THOSE WHO WITH TO BACK THE GAME DURING EARLY ACCESS. EDIT 16/5/2016I love this game, i originally played it from their website when it was much more primative, and i loved it then and i love it even more now. The developers for this game, are doing a fantastic job, i love this game for the ship and base building, i have not dabbled too much in the MP aspect, but the PvP battles i have seen can become pretty epic. Think of this as a Sci-Fi minecraft style game, you have a full galaxy to explore, you can land on and build on planets and take over space stations and even claim solar systems for your faction. The games main focus is the building your dream structure and ships and hunting pirates and possibly other players. The game has bugs but it is very solid, but none i have found so far really impact gameplay.like mentioned above you do not need to pay to play this game during the alpha phase, so there is no harm in trying it. The game does use java and can get pretty heavy on system resources, but the video options are huge. If your interested give it a shot, the downloader is only a few hundred meg and thats it. This game is perfect for having other friends playing with you.--------I see a LOT of reviews of people with sub par machines who still seem to think 8gb ram is still a lot and 32bit OS is still ok, or a dual core processor is still viable, and complaining that this game runs poorly, DUH you machine sucks, the game is a BIG ram and CPU ♥♥♥♥♥, its the nature of the game rendering SO MUCH at once, you cannot expect the game to be 100% optimised, as it is still in heavy development, and much is changing over time, it run a lot better then it did a few months back, and its only getting better. Updates are rather slow, but they are meaningful.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								I like this better than From the Depths and X3.  X3 has great space-flight, and From the Depths has great ship-building, but StarMade mashes both together flawlessly.  Also it's easier to build a spaceship that doesn't flop over more than it is to build a boat (for people familiar with From the Depths).I was originally turned off by the crappy little Lego-headed space-man, but that was misleading.  I haven't tried the multiplayer yet, but just playing the demo for about 13 hours straight until 4 am this is a very good gameplay experience.It's a combination of brain-dead mining grind, exploring the endless universe, and exploring the technologies required to put the components together to make a good ship.  Tuning the ship is great and very challenging in early game as mass build-up is hard to compensate for with engines, so maneuverability is very difficult to achieve while still having weaponry, armor and shields.  I paid full price and have no regrets other than I know I'll never have enough time to play it very well.Try the demo - it is 100% the real game with nothing disabled.  I have to run the original launcher - the new one crashes.  Then update to the latest version and play.  Then ask yourself if you enjoy it.  I did and it was a no brainer to buy the game.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								With the advent of the modern voxel adventure title, StarMade may slip past most gamers radar as just another Minecraftesque space themed pretender. Unfortunately for them, they're missing out on a gold mine of entertainment. I haven't been 'addicted' to a game for a long time now, and StarMade has definitely flipped the fun switch for me. If you're a fan of voxel games, it's definitely worth checking out, and if you're a fan of space exploration, you'd be an idiot not to. StarMade has many elements that make the game fun; the building, the vast reaches of unexplored space to cruise in, the challenge of facing unknown enemies, making alliances, resource gathering to gain power, and far more. All of these elements gel very well into what many people are referring to as an EVE experience. Though I don't like comparing StarMade to EVE, there are many resemblances to it, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. The game is just really fun, especially if you have goals and friends to play with. Once you get a firm grasp on how to build ships (or just figure out how to search up blueprints on line and gather resources in-game to build them) the game really starts to kick off, as you'll find yourself making different classes, arming your planets/stations, and really just being a force in the galaxy. The only negative I see is the building itself, it can be a challenge to master the concept of building up an entire ship from a single block, but the mechanics are simple enough that most should be able to figure it out. Additionally, adjusting to movement and gravity mechanics can also be a bit of a challenge for the unexperienced. There is a lot of work that still needs to be done with adjusting the UI, adding a proper soundtrack, and various other elements that make a game complete, but it's still in early access after all and you really can't complain for the amount of content you're actually getting at the moment.Considering this game is still in development, I am quite eager to see what else awaits us in the future of the great black yonder.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Really amazing sandbox game.  One of the best early access games I've tried and well worth the money.  The scope is very ambitious but even in this early state it's a TON of fun to play.  If you like the building elements of Mincraft and don't mind a similar rough art style this has similarities in the building aspects but it stands apart in scope.  Explore hundreds of planets.  Build buildings, spacesports, starships, space stations, mine asteroids and planets,  and combat pirates and loot their stations and ships to make yourself a fortune, make friends trading (or enemies).  There is a simple but broad crafting tree (lots of possibilities for more and a ton in already)  Full instrumentable logic elements and basic animation capabilities (eg open/close doors, elevators etc) Automated build via chained factory systems with upgrades are in.  Weapon and mining systems for ships are customizable (down to color and damage effects eg. explosions, EMP etc)  Cloaking devices, jump drives and shielding are all customizable and craftable for your fleet.  There is a faction/claim system for most entities (ships/stations/planets/sectors)  The universe feels massive with lots to explore including derlict ships ripe for the plundering if you can keep the pirates from one shotting you.   Multiplayer servers allow combat and/or cooperation.  Private server support and hosting services are already established and work well.  There are a few graphical and sound bugs that are an annoyance but no showstoppers.  The Dev's are clearly passionate about their work and have posted several videos/tutorials.   You'll definately get your money's worth.  The learning curve for the interface is a bit steep but there are a number of in game tutorials to get you in the right direction and after a bit of a rocky start I'm feeling very comfortable and can quickly spin up new ships, turrets, stations etc with relative ease.  I expect I'll be spending a lot of time in the starmade universe!Oh and full Oculus support (head tracking and 3d)  WOOT!

								I bought this game the day I tried it, before it was ever on steam. It has so much potential as a sandbox space game that I can't help but get a little excited when I see it in my library. Now that it is on steam I have a lot of faith in the development.I do have the occasional bug. However, the game is solid. The physics are pretty good around planets and the multiplayer aspect of the game can be pretty fun. The AI turrets are a solid part of space combat but the AI ships have something to be desired in terms of how far they will go away from where you start them when AI enemies come for you.The combat itself is pretty straight forward and can be pretty entertaining, there is nothing like hiding in your factions home planet or station while your AI Turrets take out the enemy while viewing it all through a glass wall. BTW when you are running a server you can have the game spawn as many ships of any saved design as you want. The game is neat-o.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Yeah, I know, I have not played it much, but this game is amazing!Over many years I kept searching for an endless space sandbox/survival game where you can go fly around galaxies (That are actually really, really big, not just a few star systems thrown together that is called a 'galaxy' by a game).StarMade truly delivers. Make your own 3 block micro ship or make hundred thousand block ships! You will spend hours exploring a big sector of a single galaxy, when there are around a hundred big sectors in each galaxy, maybe even more!Yeah, also, unlike those other modern space sims, there is no loading screens between transitions to other places. It is all physical space that you have to go through. Only the visuals are buggy slightly (but very rarely). The game devs are heavily involved in the community (from what I have seen) No waiting 3 months for a bug fix update! To find a game that I described above, that also has regular updates and a helpful dev team is extremely rare...10/10!

Early Access Review
								So far for what the game is, its pretty darn good! Not that much to do other than build ships and  mine resources. Should be played with friends or multiplayer for sure though!The Goods:- World size- Ship building system is awesome, build anything and fly it- Wide variety of ship building blocks- Blueprint sytem allows you to build saved ships by collecting the required blocks. number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14
Early Access Review
								Cons: (fairly minor and remember this is still Alpha)====Pirate stations - Systems are generated with way too many Pirate stations currently (expect this will being to change as development continues) .The ability to switch versions (if playing on different servers at different releases) requires it to re-download that release.Ocassionally exiting ships and getting stuck within blocks of the ship you just exited.Not enough people know about this game...and they need to!Pros:  ====Can build and equip any sort of spaceship(s) you can design to fly, fight and/or explore - or just have sitting there looking pretty.Fleets.NPC faction AI.Trading system.Logic blocks.Huge procedually generated systms and galaxies.Quite stable considering this is still Alpha.Regular content and bug fix upodates.Dev's listen to the community.Build tools (mirroring, block replacment etc)Space...the final frontier...Star-made even in Alpha hs been very enjoyable to play.  You build you basic ship out of the blocks given to you when you initially log into a server.  The blocks you get can vary depending on the server setup by the admins but generally there will be plenty to make your first basic ship to start exploring and mining asteroids and planets for raw materials.  As you go on you can expand your ship by refining the raw materials and using these to build other components.  Eventually you will be able to protect yourself or fight back the ubiqutous pirates that roam the galaxy.   There are plenty of player hosted servers to chose from - some are PvP, some role playing and others PvEMost I have tried out have been a friendly and any griefers I have seen have appeared to been dealt with fairly quickly.  You can protect you precious ships by docking to your faction home station before logging out and they are safe from pirates and any griefers that may slip past your server admins watch.I personally have not encountered too many bugs or crashes - definitely not any that stop me from wanting to play.  The game has been playable through Alpha and as I enjoy the building side I have really enjoyed it.  Recent updates introduced NPC factions with AI who have there own goals and are dyanamic - logging on my server today I found the NPC 'Outcast' faction has expanded it's claimed systems to right next door to mine! Also there is a trading system now which means you can search for and buy components from other player or AI shops and put up your excess or manufactured products for sale.  This has made the galaxy feel more alive.  Previously all there was was pirates and pirate stations everywhere and players and due to the size of the procedually generated universe you see another player, unless you have really annoyed them, or gone to war with them :)To summerise, if you like block building, sandbox and space this game is definitely worth looking at.  This game is progressing in leaps and bounds and already is meeting a lot of it's potential.~Ryakna~

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have played this game for quite a while before steam accessed it. I stopped playing for a while and then when browsing through steam, wallah, StarMade. I was like, Uh Mah Gerd, I have to get this. So I bought it and relearned what they changed.Starmade is a space sandbox where you have to pretty much build your ship from scratch, build up resources, build another, bigger, better ship, farm pirates, buy supplies, build another bigger, better ship... get into crafting, realize it's better to farm and sell pirate loot, etc. etc. Your ships can go in any direction you want them to, they can be the fastest, the ship that packs the most punch, a healing ship, a power regen ship, whatever your imagination can design within the confines of this game.If you can get a group of friends together you can make a local server fairly easily, FOR FREE, or you can join one of the many official servers that, from what I've seen, are well populated. On these servers you can hold grand battles, roleplay, whatever you can come up with. I personally like building ships, host a game, and have some of my friends build ships as well and see who has the better vessel. The game also allows you to save and upload ships to different servers, which can be handy when your 'Baby' gets blown to smitherines.If you don't like some of the options for your hosted or singleplayer world you can change it easily in the game files, like how many credits shops have and can recharge, or the universal speed limit. I would recommend looking up some of the options before changing, because at this stage in the game you don't know if changing a certain option will make that specific world unplayable, but the developers put a warning in the options notepad stating whether or not the option is safe to change, and they do tell you the min. and max. variables that are allowed for that option.As of now the game is in it's early stages, there are much to fix and add, and fix again. So don't be expecting the most perfect game, that has a lot of content. It is not as buggy as when I first started playing, so I am glad for that.I would reccomend this game to any sci-fi, space building, crafting, co-op loving, kitten adoring... did I mention space, gamers out their.9/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's minecraft with the following exceptions:It's in space (space that has planets you can land on), angles, factions, more (but more visually similar) resource types, better lighting, steeper learning curve, vehicles, and more.Basically, imagaine if you were to draw a line connecting EVE online and Minecraft. This game would sit about in the middle of that line. I defiantely suggest it, after getting past the learning curve, I think I'm enjoying this more than minecraft. The four biggest downsides though1. Early game, things take much longer than minecraft. Travel distances can take a long time, and jump drives only go so far. 2. There's a lot less secrets. No nether, no real dungeons buried down deep (at least not that I've found)3. Many resources are a bit spread out... space is very empty.4. Community sizes are still small. However, this is something that will hopefully change with time.
