content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Minecraft in SPACE? Are you KIDDING ME?... ok, seriously, don't say this on the Star-made forums. They get really pissy about it. But let me tell you about this game. Star-made is a space exploration game where you're able to build and fly your own spacecraft. There seem to be no limits on what you can build if you can afford it. And you don't need to be able to buy all the parts, you can salvage from derelict space stations, or mine asteroids and planetoids. You can craft any part of your ship if you have the tools and knowledge. Your ships can be simple runabouts all the way up to galactic cruisers. Shaped like anything you want. Want a classic flying saucer? Build it! Want the Starship Enterprise? Build it! Too lazy to build it? Download the blueprints from the website and buy it prebuilt!In Star-made you play a captain of your own ship. You can start or join a faction, work with the trade federation (or against it) and fight pirates who want your juicy juicy cargo. So blow them outta the sky and take their cargo instead! Salvage their wrecked ship and build up your own ship's defences. Heck, build a whole FLEET of ships. Build a space station! Or take over a derelict one and build your own version of Jabba's Palace. Too small minded? Take over a whole planet as your very own. Heck, a whole STAR SYSTEM. Just be sure you can defend it... because... pirates.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Truly a great building/space exploration game. As an early access game, you would expect it to have lots of glitches, bugs, or flaws, but surprisingly, StarMade has almost none, except for one where at certain angles players and npc's appear invisible. The only thing really that makes this game an early access game is that there are some gameplay mechanics and items that havent been implemented yet, such as certain items not having implemented fuel usage, but they are going to add that in future updates. All I can really say about this game is that i trust the developers to make this game even greater as it is now, which I am sure that they are going to do. I r8 9/10Pros:+Doesnt seem like a minecraft rip off at all, except for the obvious blocky and pixely design of the game+Huge amounts of variation, you can make almost any ship you can dream of, big or small+Nearly infinite universe, There are thousands of things to discover, you can claim entire planets and solar systems for your faction (a clan of sorts)+Tons of suff to do, you'll almost  ever get bored, as you can mine, build, travel, hang out, and have huge faction against faction space battles in huge space battleships+Friendly community, many players will help you if you have questions and dont know what to do+Modding, I haven't really done this yet, as I only got the game several days prior to writing this review, but i have heard from several other friends there is some great stuff you can get from mods+Lots of servers, there are only several more than 100 servers, but with an infinite universe and high player caps on most servers, all you'll really need is one (One good server is Freaks R Us, there are several players that play on that server a lot that will help you if you need itCons: (Will not be listing stuff not implemented yet because it's in early access)- Long distance between planets and shops, making it a drag to go to a different planet or space station-Space Pirates, the main enemy NPC, is pretty overpowered unless you have a massive ship armed and ready. DO NOT approach pirate stations soon after starting the game in single or multiplayer-kind of a grind to salvage and sell natural resources for credits to buy ship/building partsThats my review of StarMade, the space exploration/building/pvp, I bought this game out of a Humble bundle for $1, so you cant really go wrong, and i recommend that you do the same, its still on the humble bundle website for 2 more days at the time of this review, so if you want to, go get it for $1.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Not your usual sandbox, it takes a bit of understanding to actually enjoy this game. First of all it is recommended to finish tutorial as it covers the basics of game. Secondly, have patience and try to understand the simple mechanism of computer + modules, which is the core mechanism to build systems on a ship. Once you are done, you should be able to build your self a basic ship with basic working systems. With time you will discover more like how to make efficient systems, use logic to create complex systems and more. All in all its a great sandbox and it can be your go to space sandbox, sci-fi rpg (if you have a couple of your friends with you) or can be your space ship design simulator :P. There are alot of servers available for multiplayer and most of the community is supporting with exceptions of few jerks. With my more than 700 hours (80+ hours in purchased one & 650+ hours on demo) I will definitely recommend this game but also will suggest to try demo beforehand.

content:

Early Access Review
								OK so i first started playing back in 2013 back then their was not alot to do in the game the planets were diffrent textures were difftrent and the Computers were diffrent, i took a nice three year break after ive done everything i could in the game and when i returned, i found a COMPELETLY diffrent game the game mechanics were more advanced new systems were added they added a main menu that showed you a list of servers to join and i spent over 80 hours trying to learn all that is added this game became Epic they added a Fleet system and a Crew system which is not yet complete but they are working on them adding new features to them and expanding the systems, if you must compare this game with other games then this game is what happens if you merg Spacengineers to Minecraft. the best thing about this game is the fact that if you build a ship you can save it in the Catalog to you can easly regenrate it if the ship is destroyed which is a very awasome feature, the only problem i have with it was the Pirates Generate their ships from the catalog so if you create a Grand Exreamly Powerful capital ship expect a Pirate Fleet of about 10 of them somewhere their might be a way to turn this off though. the game has alot planned but the game now if you join a faction and fight a war agenced another faction, the game feels complete and because of this ill give it an 7.5/10 and if they add thoes features and KILL some of the bugs in the game which i have yet to see any major bugs than it could very easly be a 10/10. the game does seem to not have that much people of the game server the most ive seen was 25 people, with fleet system it did fix the issue that there is not alot of peaple on the servers even though its not the games fault it just means that the game is not well known use to this the Starmade community is small and is mostly on the starmade forms but hopefully the community grows because this game earned it. i can't wait to see what the game evolves into next XD

Early Access Review
								Whether you will like this game will be very dependent on what you are actually looking for.If you want to realize an envisioning of a spaceship with lots of functionality, you will love this game, because it does not only allow you to build huge monstrosities but also outfit them with any sort of functionality you could dream up once you mastered the rail and logic systems. content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Im loving this game!, i like to sit down in my planet look at the sky (which in this game is superb) and choose between thousands of stars the one i will go explore next, or mine, or just destroy it if i had a bad day at work XD.Never have had a such sense of freedom in a game, you can do everything! from destroying planets,  build bases, ships or whatever you feel like wanting to create,  The game has its own rules which makes building more interesting, ie. to have the best power performance in your shiip you need to  put blocks in different specific ways etc.. so you do need to set up your own strategy when buiding something, and there are no limits you can build ships as big as planets if you feel like doing so.Also the developer is (in my humble opinion) leading the game to the right direction, i would like see when the game is relased a bunch NPC factions, trading between themselves, securing their trading routes with armored ships, starting wars and more interactivity in that direction along with more brand new....BLOCKS !. I definately strongly recommend this game. it´s worth the money by far, and its still in Alpha!,11/10(This is one of my first posts in steam and i have steam for years now, have many games but really felt like wanting to recommend this one, also sorry for my english).

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								To sum up starmade, imagine an endless universe with no limits on anything (except small planet sizes but oh well) like minecraft block style, with more detail. You can build anything ontop of this you  can build up your own faction in a persistant (probs spelt that wrong) universe. want to create the federation from star trek and explore the galaxy in the uss enterprise? yup and you can probably build deep space 9. want to be a space pirate in a steam punk style pirate ship? yup, want to have an emperor class battleship and create the 40k imperial navy? that will take a while but yup. what you can imagine you can create, ive put 600 hours into this game, mostly offline creating ships and space stations to use online. with the new features they have added like rails and cargo this game is just great the only complaint i have is i would like to see larger planets, alot bigger. there really is nothing i can fault this game on, you really can do anything you want, the trailer doesnt do this game enough justice for the true scale of this game. belive me its awesome

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								true Sandbox that give you a lot of blocks and with them almost endless posebileties. you can spend hours building. and perfecting massive ships.would you enjoy playing the game? for now, it relies on a couple of things in my opinion. 1 how much you enjoy building, and thinking of cools systems for your ships, bases, carries and Fleet.i know i could be thinking up cool new way to build things all day and rush home to go try and make em.2 community in my experiance playing starmade the most content and goals are set up by communities, it can be the server, or factions. basicly groups of people that enjoy the game and like to interact show of build build togeter and make  event you can partake in. i have had 1000 hours of fun with a couple of different groups. the down side being those groups can be temporary. and with them goes that part of the fun. and posebly relocating to a new server can be a real bummer if you had build up a good thing on the server you where on.so some players now burn through starmade they go and build different type of ships and systems and mine and set up fleets and think, whats next. where others will enjoy thinking up new ways to do things, or perfect ships to the last detail. or even have fun makeing more and more ships, bases, warpgates ect. the players that burn through starmade need goals and events. well i believe the more this game develops more and more of what they are missing will be added to the game, it wont be overnight, but for as long as i been following this game its being worked on with passion and care. so i have no worries about it not getting there.so in conclusion: i think its a great game and it is only getting better.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								I currently have a love-hate relationship with StarMade. It's a fantastic game and concept, but as an early access game it is very buggy. Three hours of work going into building a huge battleship could be lost because the game crashes due to some miscelaneous error or some glitch occurs on a planet you're landed on and launches your ship 3 sectors over while you're still on the planet, stranded.I have thus far rage-quit twice due to these errors, swearing I wouldn't waste my time again by playing this game. Only to come back home from work dying to play it again because of all the ideas you'll get thinking of ways to arrange your hangar, or what weapons you'll place where, or what station or faction you'll attack next. I can imagine them fixing many of the bugs and creating an amazing universe to explore in the future of this game, there's just so much flexibility they have with it.It's a fun game now and can only get better with time as the bugs get ironed out. I definitely recommend this to anyone who has a creative imagination and wants to have big epic space dogfights.

Early Access Review
								I recently saw this game while browsing steam and it immediately caught my attention. Now I have always felt there was something missing from most block building games, that being the ability to create my own moving vehicles of any scale. Starmade ,on the other hand, alleviates that need by giving a very massive and complex building system. It can be confusing at times and navigating the galaxy map can be a chore, but overall I highly recommend this game. That's why I give it an 8/10. p.s. If you are considering picking up No Man's Sky, take a look at this first. It has way more features for just a quarter the price and without as many bugs.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
Early Access Review
 10/10	, would lose a night's sleep saying "one more ship, one more ship......" againReal Talk: I highly recommend this game if you enjoy sandbox games, and I say don't be discouraged about how long it may take to build something because the beauty of sandbox games is that you can put as much time as you see fit into the game and you can do whatever the hell you want. One thing I can say about starmade, is that it has by far the best build system I have ever seen in any game. There are symetry planes, copy/paste, build boundry and remove/replace tools. Aside from the many tools the game gives you, there are many cool features such as the way weapons now work (with all of the primary and secondary systems to make any combination of weapon), logic blocks and the relatively new rail system.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								One of the best voxel based sandbox games I have ever played. Despite it only being in Alpha state currently I have put in over 700hours into this game. Pros: Build anything you can set your mind to. I have seen ships, space stations, ground vehicles, and works of art from nearly all the sci-fi brands out there. Star Wars? Yes, Star Destroyers, CR90s, X-Wings. Star Trek? I have witnessed the makings of various interations of the U.S.S. Enterprise. Doctor Who? Time And Realative Dimensions In Space type 40. I have seen battlestars built, UNSC ships lauched, even the odd earth based ships floated for space. But it is not limited to just replicas. There are hundreds upon thousands of brilliantly created content made by the community.Cons:The game as stated (as of currently 11-26-2016) is in Alpha state. A lot can change update to update. But if you stick with it you can see something truly wonderful come to frution. I have been with StarMade since its early stages of Alpha, and despite the sometimes game changing updates, I learn to adapt and utilize what the developers have crafted, seeing the bigger picture reveal itself with each update. So far the game has been focused more on allowing users to create what they want, but with upcoming updates, more and more focus is being driven to role-playing and survival.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								First impressions after a short play session...I like the overall idea. I like the concept of flying literally great distances to planets I can SEE in the distance and get there and land on them. I like building your own ship and I also really like the overall look of the game. I do not enjoy the controls. I do not like the many crashes involving my java. I do not appreciate the sound issues. If you have windows 8 the sound probably isn't going to work unless you do the workaround (which the devs put in the launcher for you). I like that. Don't like the fact that it is happening and I have to fix it myself though. Although being so early in the development I understand there will be things like this.I did not play this game before it hit steam but I've seen and heard the stories. Planets used to be rounder and gravity was less goofy. However that wasn't overly noticeable and it is MUCH easier to land on planets when the sides are hexagonal and flat.My BIGGEST issue comes from having to tweak my game settings drastically do make it work. I put everything up on ultra and the draw distance was massive. I have I think 16gigs of ram right now and a GTX770 with a i7 processor. The game lagged hard during some of the loading phases. This isn't THE top of the line, but it's at least in the top 10-15%. I can run anything on ultra with no issues right now and seeing this game come to a crashing halt kinda sucks. I haven't googled this or anything so there very well may be something I"m doing wrong   =)    if anyone knows you can comment on this but I might find out by the time you do. Overall through the glitches the game is pretty damn enjoyable. Being able to construct a spaceship in game is super easy to do and the controls are listed right on the screen unless you disable them which is a big help when you're new.Please bear in mind that the game is still pretty early in the development phase and it WILL have bugs and it WILL feel incomplete but I as of right now I kind of like it as a way to get my exploration fix in.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Like minecraft melded with space engineers. Still in developement, and due to an awesomely devoted development team, updates come out often, and there impressive. When they say they have an epic feature planned, they mean it, and like, couple months later mean it. Still has a ways to go, but it's getting there fast. Also, the game has a great community, with people making helpful videos for all the logic stuff.Game balance is a bit unforgiving, you spend all your time building your ship, and it becomes to special and unique, but know that are is probably someone who has built a much larger, way more powerful ship.Logic blocks are epic, and you can do pretty much what ever you can think with them! (Think redstone in minecraft, but waaaay more advanced and powerful.)Planets need work, but thats not to urgent, and the devs have already touched on this.PvP is mainly ship based, so at least for the moment ship boarding with an NPC crew isn't a thing.Overall, and great base game, but on top of that one of the most devoted and productive dev teams out there; this game is going places.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've been testing for this game for what seems like forever (plenty more than the lame amount I've played with Steam so far), and I can't explain how glad I am it FINALLY got into early access. That said, some parts aren't as "streamlined" as other voxel-based games, StarMade brings the gritty, complex aspects of a space dogfighting game to something comparable to Lapito's Galacticraft mod for Minecraft. Once you get the hang of connecting ship/station elements and managing a faction, the game truly feels totally immersive. Some of the better RP servers go to show this. Final words: Buy the game. Even if you don't like how it is now, TRUST ME, the devs like schema are without a doubt the best at always pushing progress and killing bugs. In a month or so, whatever made you leave the game will likely be fixed.UPDATE: Yes, good things are still happening.PS:Ran my space-mech into another space-mech on the surface of a desert planet. 10/10

content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
Early Access Review
OverviewAt its current state, I must recommend this game. But before you stop reading, there are a few things you should hear from me.1. The tutorial is not very helpful.This is the main reason I don't have many hours on this game. I played the tutorial over 3 times, and am still confused on many things. I have mostly been guided by the wiki.2. This game is FREE right now.Until the final release, you can get this game for free on their website. However, you will have to buy it once the game exits Early Access.3. The sensitivity is VERY low.I turned my mouse sensitivity, from my mouse, all the way up, and it was still hard to move. The only way to fix this is by going into options and adjusting the sensitivity from there.Pros‣ Gigantic Universe‣ Multiplayer‣ Diverse Ship Building CombinationsCons‣ Lacking Tutorial‣ Poor Sensitivity OptimizationFinal ThoughtsWhile this game may have a steep learning curve, it is very fun to play, and over time, it will become more fun the more you learn about it. There are countless things to do in StarMade that make it worth the price.

content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								It is hard for me to find anything bad to say about this game. The building system is intuitive, the physics in space feel believable, the building possibilities are endless, unless you wanted to build a perfectly spherical ship, and it is pretty satisfying when you destroy a pirate/player station. Your experiences in the game will vary from singleplayer to multiplayer in the following ways...Singleplayer  As long as you are a person that enjoys building for its own sake, you will have a good time building in peace at a leisurely pace. You may be attacked by pirates randomly, however, so do not be surprised by seeing the red arrows on your screen, and possibly getting sniped.  Building and testing out ship designs that could be anything from a starfighter to a cargo ship, a mining ship to dreadnought, a beautiful piece of functioning art to a hideous agglomeration of nonesense. Only you can see it, unless you import it to a multiplayer server. To make it even better, now you can make entire fleets of ships!  With your warships, destroy all the pirate stations you come across, or tradestations.   Eventually the NPC system will be expanded, giving you new things to interact with, or destroy. Currently, the only non-ship NPCs are Space-Spider-Things (hostile), traders (Passive but creepy), and a mercenary type NPC you can hire (also creepy).  Singleplayer is like a space loneliness simulator with an ominous wind sound in the background, but if your ship or station is decorated well, it doesn't feel as bad.Multiplayer  Just like every game, some servers are full of PVP players, and others are role-playing PVE servers. My experience with both have been largely positive, however, as I was rarely attacked in the beginning by more settled characters. Until I had a large ship and homestation, the only characters that were solely KOS were other people who just started. Once you have a base and ship you put a lot of work into, you become more reluctant to be openly hostile to everyone. When everyone hates you in a server, life becomes very stressful.  When you get the chance to see other characters' ships and stations, it is interesting to see the different designs people come up with. I have seen fleets of ships from Star Wars, Mass Effect, Halo, Star Trek, Eve, and countless other series. There is nothing like seeing a Star Destroyer fighting a Borg Cube. In my favorite server I built a space strip club that other players could dock at for a visit.  Eventually you will fight another player, whether you attacked them, they attacked you, or it was a challenge in chat, you will have to approach it in a completely different way than battles with pirates. You will see different combinations of weapons and uses of logic systems you had never thought of.  Showing off the complexity of your work is really fun, but mastering the logic system takes time. I still know very little about the logic systems.  The universe is so vast that you might not see your neighbors unless one of you is actively seeking the other out. Some people might not like the emptiness of space and the distances between everything, but that is just how space is.  The number of griefers in multiplayer is fairly low from what I've seen. Griefers usually want quick gratification, something this game does not offer, and will try to steal from established players. If you build a few systems away from spawn, they probably won't make it. Have some turrets ready just in case.  Get ready to mine a lot and build yourself a proper factory. It is too expensive to buy everything from the shops.This game is fantastic and is still getting better. The Devs are incredibly talented and hardworking, just not as vocal about what they are working on as some others, for example, the Rust Devs, who post about everything they work on. The Starmade Devs are always working on something and it makes a difference. The game used to run really slow for me, but now my frame rate is excellent. I'm excited to see what they will add in the near future. To sum everything up, I recommend buying this game if you like both building and Sci-Fi, and also have the patience to get into this game. You could also try the free demo to determine if you are willing to pay for the future of the game. I'm done.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game can be very fun, however, it can also be pretty boring, depending on what you are into. I'm going to say it now, if you don't like the idea of realistic space travel and realistic distance between planets, stars, stations asteroids and your friends, basically what we gamers call "open world games", a game concept that doesn't get kind feedback from being mass produced, AKA like 3 games of the same franchise in 2 1/2 years (*cough* *cough* CoD) and has vast open spaces rather than very closed-in corridor-type maps, THEN DON'T GET IT! We dont need you guys to come in here, buy this amazing game and spit♥♥♥♥♥♥out all over it because you can't comprehend the reality of being able to do whatever the hell you like, I'm sorry that you love people telling you what to do but it isn't our problem.anyway, as I said, this game, being the type of game it is (voxel) allows for hours of fun. you could dig out a planet or a solar system, Set up a base, salvage lost space stations and take out pirates, you can even start your own pirate gang with the ingame faction system. This system offers 4 ranks, of which you can assign permissions to and rename. There is fifth rank which is able to be renamed and only applies to the faction owner. Overall I think this is a very good game and that anyone who enjoys open world games as much as I do should deffinately try this out!

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								Okay to start off, this is a really fun game! It's like Space Engineers and Minecraft fused together. You get to build awesome ships and spacestations, fly around a huge galaxy filled with wormholes, planets, asteroids, and your common space pirates. Pirates can be very annoying due to their massive amount of space stations and ships. Their space stations, if not discovered, will appear unknown on the map, but once you find one, you'll want to turn tail and run... that is unless you have a great ship.In the game, there are shops to buy parts for whatever build you're making. Though if you have a lot of loot from asteroids, pirates, or whatever, you might make the merchants go bankrupt... But don't worry, there are plenty of other shops out there.Also I forgot to mention you are able to mine things! Asteroids are filled with minerals that you could craft or simply sell. Not mentioning you can mine planets, and get mega butt ton of awesome stuff!I bet you're wondering about wormholes from the first paragraph. Do not go towards one! If you are in the sector of a wormhole, it will suck you in, and spew you out into a part of the galaxy. They don't as much hurt you, they can just get really annoying.Finally we have Pros VS Cons:Pros:-Awesome Universe-Buld Awesome stuff-Many things to do-You don't need a awesome gaming PC to play (Unless we're dealing with planets)Cons:-Planets are very laggy and in some cases crash games-The Pirates don't play fair and auto-aim to the most important peices of your ship-If you don't place your turret or ship core right, you could get out of your ship (Like outside your ship)-Some players are trolls and will mess with you and your stuffBut in overall you can have fun with friends, make a faction, work together, and maybe hyave a war with another friend! This game is great for people who like to have fun, Sci-Fi fanatics, and people who love to build reall cool things!

								I've been playing Starmade for two years, now, and I can honestly say it's held my attention and been more enjoyable than most others. 								I think I've played enough to throw my perverbial hat into the ring.This game is in effect Minecraft crossed with a successful space sim game. This is a gross simplification, for it is simply it's own entitiy.You are able to creat in effect any spacecraft, space station, or even ship should you desire under the sun (thnks to various wedges and such) as well as pages of materials to build from, including many aesthetic blocks. Weapons too are able to be customized to your combat style, be it a close up shotgun or long range explosive sniper cannon, you have the ability to make it. It even has a stealth system. (I myself am working on a modified Normandy from Mass effect) The galaxy (or depending on the server, galaxies) are massive in scope, and even on a fully populated server you can find a place to set up your base.Crafting is also fairly straightforward. Collect ores, pop them in a refinery, combine them by connecting factories to create a manufacture line. Very efficient. The building aspect even comes with a build mode, as well as an advanced version that allows you to place/remove alot of blocks on your creation quickly.It does however have it's share of teething issues. Lighting glitches occur quite a bit, and the mini-radar is very ineffective in detecting threats until you're already space dust. The new rail system also has a few operation glitches, especially when creating hatches and large doorways within ships and space stations. (nothing crippling, just annoying on occasion) In the build mode there can be issues when palcing alot of blocks if you are not careful, and the "build helper" which assists with making circles is flat out useless. (cirlce is not a circle, and is not symmetrical at all. Making a sphere with it is impossible I tried)I know nothing of the communities, but the servers can be very dangerous. Pick a remote area and high tail it there if you wish to build in any sort of peace. (I play on Red-Shift, a large active server which gives you alot of credits so you can quickly make a defendable ship and starbase in a remote area)Overall, for the price this game is a bargain. The ship/station building system is the best I've seen, and space combat is challenging but fun. (especially with missles. BOOM) It has glitches and bugs, but given the scale of the game they can be ignored with relative content. (not that they shouldn't be fixed, obviously they should) The forums could use some better policing for trolls and "neo-nazis" harassing people who only wish to see the game grow. And this is just the Early Access! Imagine how good it will be at 1.0!My rating for this game is a solid 7/10. Amazing in scope and execution, however has a few issues that could be annoying to novice players of survival and space games.

								I had played this game before it came out on Steam when it was still on the official StarMade website and loved it. I have tons more hours clocked in on this game than my Steam hours say, as I just got around to hearing that StarMade got onto Steam a while ago.Otherwise I love this game, its a fun space version of Minecraft without the screaming little kids, has a bit more interesting things to do, and promotes exploring. There is no random "night time" where the big bad pirates come out, instead, they fly across the universe with you, looking for each other, and each encounter can have different things happen, as the pirates can take your own self-built ship and use it against you.11/10 This game is fun as hell.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26
Early Access Review
								POSITIVES:~~~~~~~~~You can build anything from a tiny little drone to a massive bohemoth that annihilates everything in its path... a little outpost through to a monstrous city station.Your creations can have jump drives, jump drive inhibitors, several different types of weapons which can be customised for different effects (punch, pierce, explosion, etc), different colours, rate of fire, range, etc by connecting them in different ways.Your creations can fly, they can mine, they can repair, they can destroy, or any combination.Drones, fighters, bombers, corvettes, destroyers, carriers, battleships, alien creatures, force fields, seriously this game gives you a massive choice of toys to build and play with.Role Play / PVP / combo suitableGreat communityGame constantly evolving and changing and improving.Almost every part of it is fully customisable - you can even create your own set of blocks and textures with unique behaviours and crafting ingredients and resource trees.  It's not easy to customise some of the features, but it is possible to customise pretty much everything, and most of it is super easy to edit.NEGATIVES:~~~~~~~~~Block based.  Seriously blocky.  They're bringing in LOD blocks that break this up a lot, but it's still seriously blocks blocks blocks.Bugs galore, but to be fair the devs put a great deal of effort into squashing them, and they're doing an outstanding job of it.Physics are limited.  For example if you blow a hole in the middle of a structure both separate bits are still part of the same object and will spin together as though they were attached.  It's not a big deal but it does destroy the realism of it.  Also space friction.  Uggh.  I think that can be adjusted in server settings like most things, though.Missiles are points, not objects.  But you can make actual torpedo objects that fire and explode on impact (but they're basically ship entities by themselves).Explosive warhead blocks need serious buffing to be effective.Very Memory and CPU intensive.  Optimisation needs a lot of work.Unrealistic resources.  Forget gold, carbon, oxygen, and hydrogen.  Bring on a bunch of random♥♥♥♥♥resources that you need to remember in order to gather for your desired crafting goods.OVERALL:~~~~~~~~~This game is tidy.  It has a lot of freedom to build what you want without the clunkiness of similar games like Space Engineers.  It does however have a less refined finish especially on a smaller scale, and is a real RAM and CPU gobbler.  Don't even bother unless you have an above-average computer.The devs are keenly focussed on improvements and bug fixing, and the game is in a constant state of improvement, giving it a constant supply of new parts to play with.If you like space building sand boxes this is one of the giants.  Enjoy responsibly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Me and 2 others played this on a server for a while.  It's really fun, and has a lot of potential.  The building of ships is awesome but even beyond that you can build space stations and land bases.  Really almost anything you can think of.  Some of the features I found hard to use like the games own version of red stone.  The game uses logic modules that I found a bit rough but then I didn't spend a ton of time on it either.  Also the lag was bad, this could have been the server I was on but I have a feeling it's the size of the galaxy.  As people move further out and more and more is generated the game slows down.  Oh and that brings me to the final issue.  Space!  There is so much of it you almost never run into anyone.  If not for the chat you might as well play it alone.All in all it's an awesome game that I have no regrets buying.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Not gonna lie, this game may or may not have been my life for the past 3 years or so. Judging by my hours of play, I have seen a fair bit of this game, however even to this day I still get a sense of awe and hope for the future while peering out of a starship's plex window into the great unknown. Whether I am overseeing docking operations in a shipyard, letting creativity take over during construction, forgeting to take a breath while sitting on the edge of my seat during combat, or just relaxing and having fun with friends, this game always has the power to amaze. The dev team is the hardest working I have ever seen, pumping out a high quality update every 2 weeks or so. And Im not talking bugfixes every 2 weeks I'm talking fleets one week, living economy the next. The only thing negative I can say is the lack of sound, but it is space after all. Seeing this game grow from its infancy to where it is at now is unbelievable, and I have had many unforgetable moments in this game. After all this I would gladly Recomend this game to anyone questioning it. And come on, what a dev team, they put their game up for free and dont even require you to buy it! 9.6/10 Would not go outside and see the sun for a week to play this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I enjoying this game so far had it for a longtime and found the controls really confusing and i set it aside. i was scrolling through my games collection and remebered this after a quick watch of the trailor on steam (love that music such a great song). I just can't stop playing it i thought for me to learn it and focus it would be better to do singleplayer.Which yes it was looked up some admin commands when pirates turned up and lagged the game out alot after learning some controls i actually find the quite easy to play now. To me the game is a great mix of Eve online and minecraft. it runs really well on my couple of generations ago pc. I let it load up watch the FPS to see it stablize then play the game pretty much lag free apart from approaching planets to mine them. If i travel in space the game is always lag free. Building spaceships is really exciting to me as you will spend many hours working out a ship design thats works best for your style of play. Then of course if you play multiplayer it's all about building bigger then all the other players which some ships i've seen are getting upto 6million blocks taking them weeks to months to finsih with very interesting designs and variety.Then you have logic blocks for well doing logic. watcvhing videos on youtube people have made semi automatic ships for mining which i am absolutly amazed people worked out. (planning on working on it myself). I wish there were alot more players playing i think with a bigger community that put the effort in it could become as popular if not more then minecraft. the ideas are great and the game overall is to me excellent it just need some more to make it feel more alive, some fixes in lag for loading planets and some better ai in the ai block. Which are all things they addressing in the future from what i have been reading (dont quote me on it though).overall atm 8/10

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Imagine No Man's Sky, if No Man's Sky was basically intergalactic Minecraft. That's what this game is like, essentially. You get to custom-design ships, and a lot of the decisions you make matter-- do you want to put a reactor here for more power, or a computer to get your weapons systems working? Of course, they do stop mattering if you do what I did and jump smack dab into the middle of pirate space then get decimated by said pirates or fly too close to a star and lose all your thrusters leaving you hurtling toward a planet with no means to stop or change direction, but when your ship is actually intact, it's worth feeling proud of. Since the game is also available for free, I think I'm gonna go out on a limb and say that if you can't afford No Man's Sky, get this until you can.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								GOOD GAME!! Simplified version of Space Engineers.  Concept is almost the same, but simpler and not as great graphically, but creativity wise, its great. Would recommend it. I am more of a detailed Space Engineers player for complex systems and programming, but even though StarMade is indeed simpler, it can get quite complicated depending on what you build and how you place those blocks! A game for days when you need to get your creativity flowing and the brain some exercise -  with some actual need for thinking and problem solving. Not as in-depth as SE, but still a great sandbox game with a lot of room to grow!

								I'm addicted. So many things to do, to understand, to master... A real feeling of progress in design, efficiency, power... Starting from a 5 blocks ship, going up to 50, 500, 5 000, 50 000... number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok....I just bought this game with the mind-set that it's going to suck and I am going to get a refund, honestly I wouldn't have bought this game weren't it for steam's refund policy. That being said, as you can see, I did not return the game, infact as soon as I started playing I didn't stop for 13 hours. Not ever have I spent 13 hours on one game, in the course of 1 day, not even that, half a day. If I had the whole day it would have been 24 hours. Alright, so let me tell you how I first saw the game. The graphics are crappy, the npcs are horrible, the tutorial is buggy and crap, the chat system is bad and the ui feels like that of a prototype. Notice thats how I first saw it. In all seriousness the tutorial really isn't good, I actually reccomend you don't play it and instead you watch youtube videos to learn what to do, thats what I did. Anyway, I was damn near convinced that this game was just a minecraft mod made into a game....untill I joined a server that is. I have no idea why or how but when you build your first crappy ship, and fly it a little bit and learn a little more, fix the crap of your ship little by little. Finally find a planet, land on it, start colonizing it, build another ship, learn about jump drives, learn about weapons and shields and cloaking devices and credits and so much more, the game opens up into this vast universe of many many many things to do, and did I mention there were factions. Basicly, if you like minecraft, or space engineers, or star citizen, or eve, or star trek, or star wars or sci fi in general, you will like this game. The only thing of any concern, is that this game's learning curve is steap, very steap. But trust me if you stick to it, gruel through the unknown of learning the game, you will find somthing worth alot more then 10$. Also, I have just played 1 game for 13 hours straight so I am tired and this review might be a bit excentric, but no matter. This game is amazing and I only see it getting better. This game is DEFFINAITLY worth the 10$ price tag, and honestly I would be willing to pay 60$ for it when it is complete. So hopefully this helps you to realize that you need this game in your steam library, and happy wasted lives to all! And to all, a good yi, (Error: #404  Steam has run out of memory, please ask your doctor if this review is right for you, it may cause dizzyness, drowsyness, sleepyness and overall excitement for this game. Do not read this review while operating heavy machinery, do not read this review while pregnent, as it will force your baby to never stop playing this game. This review, the only review for you. notresponsableforextremeragefromdeathbypirate,pleasedonotsueuswehavenomoney,thisproductwillnotwork,youwildiefromthisproduct.)

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								So if you couldnt tell, this is very much like Minecraft but better. You arent confined to one planet and can do all of the geeky sci-fi stuff you ever wanted to do. I've been playing for a few days now but will continue to invest multiple countless hours of my life I will never get back. My first day, I saw the enterprise, and her captain was as friendly as you could ask for. Sure, theres a couple pirates out there but the universe is Soooo vast that they are a non issue. There is also the AI mobs but if you steer clear of them then they dont go out of their way to bother you. Great game and HIGHLY reccommended. Best you could wish for in an early-access beta. This might as well be the full release, im excited its not!

Early Access Review
								GOOD GAME!! Simplified version of Space Engineers.  Concept is almost the same, but simpler and not as great graphically, but creativity wise, its great. Would recommend it. I am more of a detailed Space Engineers player for complex systems and programming, but even though StarMade is indeed simpler, it can get quite complicated depending on what you build and how you place those blocks! A game for days when you need to get your creativity flowing and the brain some exercise -  with some actual need for thinking and problem solving. Not as in-depth as SE, but still a great sandbox game with a lot of room to grow!

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Three  years ago, two of my friends were talking a game called Starmade. I thought it would be a game found under the "Absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; catagory, as i imagined it being about having the primary star of a solar sytem be the maid to the citizens or something. I then saw them play it, and decided to get it myself. Starmade is an infinite sandbox like Minecraft, only a thousand times better.This game has flaws however (this one 2), being both about hardware. The first flaw is that the game takes up a crapton of ram and processing power, and cannot be run on a laptop. The second is that Intel graphis is known not to work with the game properly for whatever reason, but once you get past these two hardware problems, the game is great.You may be saying to yourself "This review hasn't been helpful at all", so im going to tell you what you can do in starmade. As i said earlier, Starmade is like Minecraft, only in space. You can build spaceships, fight space-pirates, play with your friends, build space stations, race spaceships, hollow out planets, explore the vast cosmos, and much much more. When you compare this game to Minecraft, you must find an equally proportionate comparision, like comparing a kindergardener to a college senior, being that this game is much more organised and sophisticated compared to Minecraft.

content:
Posted: April 4
Early Access Review
								So I love this game, LOVE IT! With that being said TL:DR Great space voxel/building game, lots of lesser issues.Story: Well there inst one its an open world (really open) survival style game. Note that I stated style, there really isnt really a lot of surviving. 2/5 Really need some sort of driving force, a 'reason'. Graphics: So lets get the bad out of the way first. This all depends on YOU. I personally don't mind the block, pixel look of star made. But That depends on the user. Perhaps just as much on the content your viewing.  (seen lot of bad ships/stations) So 2.5/5 For the possibility of going ether way.Sound:Only like 3 sounds and up till a few days ago I thought there was only 2. 1/5 This is really neededPlay-ability Value: HOLY #@##$ This is were its at! If your imagination is decent and you can spend some time learning the building curve. You can spend crazy amounts of time building all sorts of crazy things. 5/5 No doubtA final note: This game doesn't  pander to everyone, it is built around building ships/stations. Suffer no delusions, if you go into this game expecting 'space Minecraft' your gonna be disappointed.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Great game and just because it looks like Minecraft, it doesn't mean it sucks like most other games that look like Minecraft. Such as Minecraft for example! But thats a different game, this game has cool features while Minecraft is... Minecraft. StarMade is a space game where you run fly around space in your... hey... where's your ship? When you first spawn you ain't got jack♥♥♥♥♥♥other than some starter equipment for a tiny, tiny, tiny ship. But you do have 25,000 bucks to spend on equipment. Spend it wisely, and dont just die and lose it. While building, please for the love of god don't ♥♥♥♥ing press BACKSPACE. It will delete what ever you are currently holding in your hotbar. It says "drop" but since this is space and all, space does you a favour and just eats it so you don't have to see junk everywhere. Neat right? Well so far the only things bad about this space builder is the clunky controls that take a while to get used to, and the "drop" feature. Oh yeah, dont forget the GRAPHIKS THAT SUK!!! The graphics aren't bad. They're blocky and why the ♥♥♥♥ does it matter? Some of the amazing things that everybody needs to know before buying is that 1. You can purchase a crew. 2. Singleplayer (should've already known that) 4. (because ♥♥♥♥ 3.) multiplayer. 5. You can create big spaceships. 666. There's space stations that could be even bigger than the space ship! 777 (won me the lotto!) Pirates and Storeowners to spice up the experience. 8. Easy to create servers. 9. SPAAAAAAAACE!!! And the big 10 inch♥♥♥♥♥♥ 10. Weopons... and lots of them.If you like Minecraft, buy this game. If you hate minecraft, buy this game. If you like Space Builders, buy this game. If you like to instantly have everything at the start, don't buy this game. If you hate getting used to controls, don't buy this game. If you love space games and/or beutiful games, buy this game.TL;DR?11/10 Would SPAAAACE again.You still reading? Good, reading makes you smart. Now read this with the testicals in your head.I hate Minecraft as you have obviously read, but that's my opinion. Hating me because I hate a Minecraft just shows how bad your "community" is. If you don't know what the Minecraft community is look up, "Minecraft Original Song". Prepare to lose hope in humanity.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Its funishPros: Its original.Ship building is way fun.The weapons system on said ships is unique.it's a charming game to play.The new UI looks very nice and clean.Cons: Player controls are ridged and funky, theres no momentum in Zero-G.ships roll WAY too quickly, to the point you cant rotate small ones to align with docking bays.Tutorial is annoying and has numerous gramatical errors.Minor nitpicks:The mining decal on blocks will not reset if you imediately start on another block, I've gotten the grid to look like solid blue.You start seeing the starlines at way too low speeds (Moving your character outside a ship makes them).Planets are REALY REALY close.The galaxy map is too uniform, stars should be in more random positions inside of the cubic sectors.Conclusion:It needs refining, early access is not an excuse for a half-baked product, stuff like movement should be perfected as soon in development as possible. I have faith that this will become a great game in time but it is a bit underwhelming at the moment, buy if you realy think you will love it

content:

Early Access Review
								I've owned this game for close to 2 years now (back before it was available through Steam). Updates have been frequent enough to keep me interested, but there is still a bit left to desire. It's an alpha-release and it's obvious sometimes that more features are needed. I enjoy the creative aspect more than battles, and the scale of constructs is mind-boggling sometimes.I've had pleasant experiences with the community and other players - some of the ships and stations in-game were created by players and uploaded during contests. Unlike other Pre-Release games, you can get free access to this one (as of the date of this post), which goes to show the developers are more focused on the product that the profits.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Where do I begin...Honestly I don't like space games simply because they have great graphics but they don't let you build your ship block by block. You have to do it in presets that cost to much in-game money it starts feeling like the junk guy from Star Wars 64 racing game. This game lets you build ships, space colony ships, and even planets block by block. This game takes time to understand the fomula but if you love minecraft and space this game is for you. This is defenitly not for players looking for hardcore PVP and amazing graphics, but it is for those who are extremely creative or die hard fans of star trek, star wars, or star fox, hell just be a fan of stars period.In my time I made my single player be about a woman whos possibly the last survivor of a space colony that blew up and she crashed landed on different planets then let my friends play it and see the story out. The game also lets you make factories so they build units and store them into a box while your out "please note that going to far from your galaxy or logging off a server will pause the units being made" and you can make complicated systems using the in-game tools. Want an R2D2, you can make it, want an arwing from StarFox you can make it. Seriously you can build like crazy here anything you want but I'm going to warn you about servers and enemies in a sec.Servers can be really empty I mean even if theres 16 players online most are already in a faction or doing their own thing so if your like me and you made a peaceful little space bar/club and you advertise it, players might raid it or blow it up for fun. If you built a huge base on a planet far from everyone and even got rights to the planet dont be serprised if that server is down within a month of you playing. Servers either die off or restart everything due to updates. Personally what I did was test out a server, build a few things and add to it but not get emotionally invested in my creations. I also want to point out you can save all of your designs and copy/paste them in your game files! Lastly Enemies in the game are lock on killers. Seriously no sound as of yet to let you know your #$% is getting attacked and that motha@#$% gotta a cannon the size of godzillas dammmmmmn! Enemies lock on way to robotically and fast so when you see the sign [respawn] you realise what happened and cuss your screen off. BTW if your ship blows up that it... no more ship unless you saved the blueprints and build another one.If your just starting the game a huge tip is to look for a server that gives you a lot of [credits] and has a high "mph" so you can learn to build and explore faster. Also if your completely new to the game I highly suggest looking for a quick tutorial video on youtube. The tutorial ingame is so wall of text you'd reread my reveiw 5 times and still wouldn't complian. Basically to sum up my review its a good #%^ game moth!@#$ buy this @#$%!!!

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL;DRDemo is the full game right now. Download and play. Decide for yourself./TL;DRCaution: If you're creative minded, you may lose more time than you realised. I keep going to sleep at 5AM, thinking it's about 1AM when I FINALLY check the clock.For the massive scale constructor in all of us. Game can be played for free though you can buy it now cheaply before they scale the price for release and get patch support after release (demo won't be updated). Literally "Early Access" I suppose.Not sure what the hell a voxel is? Never played Minecraft?http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VoxelSo basically, this game is a giant sandbox where you do as you damn well please. Mine the materials, put out factory complexes, refine the materials...build an Imperial Star Destroyer?! You can be as imaginative as you want - build your ship in any way, shape or form that pleases you and hurts other people's eyes if you wish. Or as uncreative as you like - build famous ships straight out of sci-fi from X-Wings to the Enterprise to B-Wings to the Voyager, the Yamato, the Sunrider*, the Galactica...the list goes on. Hell, someone's building a Death Star space station. You can do that too - then host a server, get friends to join and wait for the "That's no moon..." quotes. For the reference, your character is a 1x2 figure. Now imagine the 10,000,000+ block ships some people have floating around. Yeah. Welcome to Starmade.Currently no music in game. Might I recommend FTL: Faster Than Light's* soundtrack? xDWhat I'd kill for:- Assuming I haven't missed it, the ability to move entire planes up and down. Think of the X-Wing's attack and speed modes. Yeah, this would probably kill memory and likely will never happen, but I can dream right?- Better optimized lighting. Preferably a gamma setting. Current lights are a serious drain, especially in large numbers. Simplified lighting setting basically removes lighting altogether. (AFAIK, devs have said this is on the todo list)- ...less confusion. Oh granted, the game teaches you the basics well enough - mine this, refine that, build and laugh, but there's no advanced tutorial. Good luck to you trying to figure out how docking or turrets work.- 'Destroy' option for inventory. Assuming I haven't missed this too, can only seem to drop blocks. Can't destroy them. The game will happily solve this based on a timer by removing things from memory after a certain time/distance.- Control sensitivity options. It's beginning to annoy me that I can rarely (if ever) get my ship to be level with the hangar it's being constructed in. Can never seem to roll 'a bit' to the left or right to be level. >_>*Check Steam's store for these games. Sunrider is a (free) Visual Novel. FTL: Faster Than Light is an indie...RTS/RPG/Roguelike mashup? Can't describe it properly, draws from a lot of elements.Do I recommend it? Hell yes. If you're social, there's a ton of servers out there, albeit sparsely populated. If you're like me and like firing up sandbox games to get those creative neurons firing, you're not in this for the combat, you're here to make a giant spaceship. Besides, if you're in it for the combat, you'd want to play on a multiplayer server against other players anyway.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is awesome and has a ton of potential, but it is clearly lacking a ton of features.Now of course you can say that it is an early access game. However, the team of developers is small and despite trying to keep to a two weekly release schedule of updates, they don't make it as often as they make it. In fact, they haven't released anything in a month and the last few updates only consistent of small bugfixes and the updates before that consistent of a completely buggy "Fleet" system that makes my ships rubberband like crazy and has extreme limitations. Schine claimed to be done with the fleet system over the course of several updates, but this is ridiculous.I could wholeheartedly recommed this game if it had regular updates and felt like it comes closer to at least the beta (after being years in the alpha), but as it stands, you are better off not buying it.

								   I am glad I got the game at $3 before it came to steam. When this game came out I thought it was going to be another minecraft rip for a while. It was just another minecraft rip off then they uped the anti with jump Gates and ship building Stations. So it is just a Minercraft and Eve Online Mixed into 1 game witch I like.       I love! EVE online one of the Best MMO's i have ever played for only $130 a year that is good. But this game said here you can have your 2 of your most Favroit games Smashed into 1 with no monthly CHarge! I love it but I still play eve cause I Have 5000 People to play with instead of like 0-20 witch Gets boring after like 1-5 hours of playing.This game can become it's own Style of gaming if it wanted to instead of taking almost everything form Minecraft/Eve Online. Now Now I know what you are going to say BUT IT IS DIFFERNT. In a way it kinda is and Kinda is not. On one side it's Building and Ore mining is Good and it is hard to get those ores you need to make the stuff you want or you could Trade. But the building is just like Minecraft but you can build more then 1 block at a time. and it's Diverfity of ores and ingerdents is almost as good as Eve's but it falls short some times. In Eve you can at least mine 1 kinda of ore and get 3-6 differnt kinds of metle from it instead of 1 type of metle. {If this has changed a lot since the last 2 months tell me please.)  I am not Bashing StarMade it is over all a Awsome game but I think they can do a MMO or a 1000 player Server for it that is a main Server instead of leting players do all the work cause some servers do just hate New Players. I  have been in severs that some people are just Butt holes that will shot anyone who gets away from spawn.  I would recommend this game if you have ever wanted Minecraft or EVE Online I say get minecraft and EVE Online play them for a bit and then come back to this game to Understand why they did this I played both of these  games before I found Starmade and I just love this game but it needs a lot more players to Enjoy it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5
Early Access Review
								Many have describe this game as Minecraft in space. While I respect such an description, I daresay that it is not the most apt way to describe Starmade. Many of the limitations of Minecraft (no such thing as entire structures that can move, a lack of symmetrical building assistance, voxel shape outlining, to name a few) are not present in Starmade, making this game, in effect, superior to Minecraft is many aspects (though subpar in others).The most alluring aspect of Starmade is the ability to build what you want. If you want to make a small shuttlecraft to simply explore space, that can be a viable option (as long as you stay clear of pirate outposts). If you want to take as much time as you need to build the most massive ship with the best defenses and weapons the game has to offer, that is, not only within the realm of possibility, but highly likely, given enough time and effort. If you want to simply screw other players over by making a one-person faction and claiming systems left and right, then yes. You can be "that guy" on the server. If you want to make a huge space station that can accommedate any size ship and have a shop to make money hand over fist, then go for it, Mr. Ferengi!I personally love the approach Schine used in building. The ability to place an ENTIRE row, column, or chunk of blocks down in one click makes the ship/station building experience much more enjoyable, as you don't need to spend tedious amounts of time building something, one-block-at-a-mind-numbing-time. The symmetry grid also helps to alleviate the grind of building. I myself use the symmetry grid very often, as it saves time when you are building one side of a station and want the other side to be completely identical.The block system works out quite well for the game, though there are some flaws with some of the blocks/systems. A few of the blocks have outdated descriptions (shield capaciators, for example), while others have incomplete descriptions (punch-through module block does not state what effect it gives a weapon). Power blocks can be somewhat tricky to use as their benefits are greater when placed in a straight line rather than grouped together in chunks. For some (not all) players, this causes builds to be very long or have awkward shapes. Schine is currently looking into the current power system, and pitched a proposal on a revamp. We will have to see how that plays out.Which brings me to another point: Schine listens to their players and interacts with the community on a regular basis on their website. They listen to their complaints, compliments, suggestions, etc. and are very professional about it, taking everything in stride.However, by far, my most favorite feature in Starmade is the blueprint system. After you have spent a week working on that ship of yours, and you have it exactly how you want it to be, you can then save it as a blueprint. Then, take said blueprint, and upload it to the Starmade Dock. There, others can download your ship and use it in their own game/server. They can rate it and suggest to others to get it, as well. But, the fun doesn't stop there. Schine every now and again hold contests for builders, and the winner of the competition can get their build added to the base game, making it so it appears in-game without the need to have the blueprint downloaded (one perfect example is a derelict medical station created by a player that was added to the actual game). And, with the right tools, players have even created 1:1 scale models of famous space ships, such as the Millennium Falcon from Star Wars, or the USS Voyager from Star Trek.The one thing to keep in mind with Starmade is that it is still Early Access and in alpha testing phase. There WILL be bugs and glitches. There WILL be changes to how some of the blocks work, as well as new ones added and others removed. Change is inevitable. It's the nature of game development.All in all, Starmade is well worth the price you'll pay. It's still in development, so there will be many more features that will be added, as well as something that will be changed or removed. If you haven't bought the game yet, then do it. If you don't want to buy it, then keep an eye on it, as something may be added that will turn your head and changed your mind.In Starmade, the stars are not the limit, only your imagination.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								Like No Man's Sky, but actually good and the devs are lieing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, it even has MULTIPLAYER FUNCTIONS THAT ACTUALLY WORK. You hear that Hello Games? Maybe listen to Schine before you release a ♥♥♥♥♥tain of a game onto Steam and then price it 60 bucks. I played this ages ago and with all the hype of NMS I decided to return to Starmade. Its a solid game, a bit hard on my computer, but I can still play this. I thought NMS would destroy this fanbase, I was really sad, but when I heard how bad NMS was, I realized something, Starmade will stand the test of time. With so many larger and much more hyped games coming out, Starmade has withstood all of them. Space Engineers, NMS, EVE Online, Elite Dangerous and countless other space exploration shooty games. Starmade has something none of the others have. True creativity. Sure in SE you can build whatever ship you want, but you were restricted. You couldn't make a dirt ship that has nukes strapped to it (Last I checked, anyways.) Starmade allows for more insane creations than any other game. It may not be as polished or as feature-filled, but this is much better than anything else on the market.

content:
Posted: March 4
Early Access Review
								I tried to like this game.Like From The Depths, this game is a weird, garish almost incomprehensible mess from the start.  Though unlike FTD, I was able to actually figure out the UI (for the most part), but it still requires tons of experimentation and wiki-reading.There's a lot of stuff in this game, but I found it totally inexcusable that it had no working sound support.  (Aside from, what I could tell was just a single laser beam sound effect.)  It's also completely written in Java and runs pretty clunky.  Imagine the performance of Minecraft set in space with infinite procedurally generated planets, and it plays about as well as that sounds.The constant requirements of digging through forum posts and wiki pages in order to learn how to do the most basic of things, and the clunkiness of how everything controlled/felt, just turned me off from the game and I've stopped trying the infrequent updates.

content:
Posted: February 14
Early Access Review
								It's a sandbox game atm. You can build ships of every size from 5m to 1000m length. And then you can blow each other up. And it works. It's not like in Space Engineers where your server crashes as soon as 2 mid sized ships battle. Here you can have 20 ships of 100m length (1m=1cube so 1 Starmade meter equals 1 cube in a big grid ship of Space Engineers) battle each other and it actually works smooth. Ofcourse playing battles with very big ships or letting them crash in each others kills every server. Get some brain guys we are only have intel processors and not quantuum ones. :DSo it's definetively a better sandbox as SE is!The other competitor Empyrion is nice too (I played all 3 games), but has zero logic and only one or two stations that are created in the universe. In Starmade there are thousands of stations and asteroids generated in the universe and they have like 200 station templates and also AI controlled fleets get generated (pirates, traders, aso) and they are also selected from a ... I think 100 big ship pool atm? Ofcourse Empyrion has some nice bases on planets and the PVE part is great there. But it does NOT have LOGIC. Without logic you can't create own stories and adventures like you do in Minecraft.Its definetively harder to learn as SE or Emp, but for me, it's fun. =)

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								I had no end of problems with the Steam version of Starmade which required removing it from my library and then deleting it via steam entirely. Reinstalled in the C directory and now it runs.Having said that...Starmade, the not-minecraft-in-space-which-looks-alot-like-minecraft-in-a-way. If you don't have trouble with Java, if you are one of the lucky ones who doesn't have constant issues with stability and if you're right handed, you'll probably develop a love/hate relationship with the game.Fully keymapping isn't implemented so any left handers like me trying to use the numberpad for your controls find out that the devs don't recommend using it cos it's still being used for dev work. The build mode is fiddly at times, graphics are okay if rudimentary, planets eat your fps and as ever, getting resources is a grind. The problem with the build mode is trying to create ships one block at a time - yes, the advanced build mode allows placing of multiple blocks, but it's ghastly to use and unnecessarily annoying. You can't manipulate shapes, you can only place blocks which can dry up the creative juices rather quickly.On the other hand, if you like building spacecraft, this is currently the leader in the woefully under-represented spacecraft building genre. There are a few other similar-ish games (for the building part at least) snapping at it's heals though, such as Interstellar Rift, Avorion (currently on greenlight & demo available), Empyrion and Starship Corporation to name a few. If you want an alternative ship builder, go with Interstellar Rift, if you want survival, try Empyrion.TL;DRIf you're patient, overflowing with creativity and have luck with java, you'll be okay for the most part, otherwise research alternatives.I still give it a thumbs up though as it has a lot of potential.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								While there were... minor difficulties in actually starting up the game for the first two-three days, this problem was surprisingly easy to solve. Other than that, this game is just packed with content, and endless possibilities. Imagine Minecraft, with what I shall fondly refer to as "The Macross Missile Massacre", and you may get something similar to this. Truly exhilarating to play, despite the counter-intuitive controls in some sections. Still, it's surprisingly good fun.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								I really really like Starmade. It's like Minecraft- but in space. If you've ever played Minecraft with the Carpenter's Blocks mod, the one that adds all the weird angles and awesome stuff, you'll like this. While content is a little lacking, it makes up for it with spunk.Pros:Easy to learn how to play and fun to work with.Ship design is very flexible.If you're good at Minecraft or Roblox, you're gonna have an easy time playing this.Neutrals:Scrolling through your hotbar is reverse that of Minecraft/Roblox. Takes a little getting used to.Can't remove items from Creative inventory. (Unless I'm just missing something obvious.)Not toaster computer friendly, it renders AI ships that are outside of the player's range and FOV. (Please fix, devs.)Cons:Needs a sort of beefy computer to run.Pirates are really hard even on easy setting.Needs a really beefy computer to run smoothly.Overall, 6.5/10Since it's early access, I assume/hope they'll fix some of the player issues and hopefully provide some support for toaster users.My specs. (Provided by Speccy.) number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Figured I better redo this review. Game deserves better. It reminds me a lot of the way minecraft came to be. Not only because they both rotate around squares but they game development proccess. This game started with a lone developer and stayed in alpha for centuries. I played the alpha  in 2013 maybe? and a lot of the things there worked the same as they do now. Not saying that things havent changed but the game had solid ground in alpha and is still improving a ton today. Minecraft was in open pay to play beta/alpha for a long time. You can play this game for free with the demo and it feels complete. I reccomend buying it and supporting the community and developers.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Starmade is a fantastic game. I've played it for hundreds of hours for free, when I found it in 2013. Since then, it's only gotten better and better. After a very long hiatus from the game, I've come back to see so many wonerful features added and ironed out, making this a wonderful experience to discover.Thousands of planets, asteroids, and things to do.Giant ships, limited only by your imagination (and CPU specs, I suppose).Dedicated servers meaning worlds for you to play in that you actually matter to.There's so much to like about this early access title, and I'm betting we have a lot more to look forward to.Buy it if you've played Minecraft and thought "I wonder what it would be like if I could go to space", while playing it.
