content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								I like the idea, but the execution leaves a lot to be desired. There are lots of bugs. The tutorial locked up on me, and I was unable to quit it, and thus, was unable to move. I had to wipe everything and try again, skipping the tutorial right from the start. Realistic graphics are obviously bugging out, because textures were cycling. Turning on shadows turns the world into a dark, muddy mess with characters becoming creepy silhouettes. I ended up just having to put everything on simple graphics because the "realistic" options made it look terrible. No improvement in preformance from doing that, either, but at least it didn't look high definition posters glued on to a bunch of cubes.Ship building is easy, but early ship possibilities are unimpressive and ugly. Controls are rather simple but the physics are wonky. My ship got tapped and was sent into space, with no easy decernable way to get back to it. Larger planets constantly load and reload, bogging down the server.I decided to uninstall since I wasn't having any fun. Maybe I'll revisit it later, but for now it's just too buggy and underwhelming.

number of helpful: 14 of 31 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game has been slowly getting better and better, the rail system added ALOT of new fun possibilities. It's VERY early beta/alpha and I don't expect much of it right now. But I have high hopes of this game. The in-depth system's and territory system couple lead to a massive community when given the chance (MMO maybe?)-Right now the weapon's just don't feel right and you don't feel like you have the power to wreak havoc upon a ship or destroy it quickly with major caliber weapons. That being said this game needs a quick overhaul on some graphics and some music (music is something I think every game needs and it's a lil bland without it)-There are some bugs that don't help the game out, like when I logout inside a ship that ship disappearsAt this point I don't have much to say about the game and I wouldn't recommend it. But I've seen alot of promising things and I'd defiantly keep a eye on it ;)

number of helpful: 14 of 31 people (45%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Updated Review: I let the game develop for another six months and then wanting to give it another go.  Few other games offer the incredible deep space, minecrafty expirience that Starmade promises.  The game currently has reworked its launcher and looks much nicer now.  The sound issues I previously ran into are nowhere to be seen and the game didn't have any technical problems starting up (other than desperately needing vsync to be turned on by default). Gameplay was immediately impeded by getting stuck in the floor of my ship and being unable to free myself despite a tip suggesting I press "up" to get unstuck (didn't work for some reason).  Then i set to customizing the starter ship.  The cannon/salvage/weapons system is opaque and has zero documentation.  Even after browsing several out of date wikis I could not piece to gether why the cannons were doing what they were doing.  Having played an earlier version where there was a full tutorial, I understood the master/slave computer system but I still was unable to get anything working the way I wanted.  And hour and a half later i gave up.  This is still a solid "Don't Buy" for me.  The game clearly underwent major changes and the documentation just hasn't kept up.  There is no way to learn how to play this game without someone who can just answer all your questions.

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is confusing.  You will not know what to do when you first turn the game on & it will take you some time (hours or longer) to figure out exactly how to do things.   Also, ignore the 0.1 hours played since I've not been playing the game through Steam.The game starts you out near a shop in the middle of space.  The tutorial broke for me so I couldn't use it.  I had to figure out everything by experimentation & through guides online.The first thing you need to do is build a ship & you have no idea how to do it.  I spent 4 hours figuring out how to build a ship with some long video showing me only to have it vaporize once I went into a warp.  Not only did I just waste 4 hours of my time I ended up pennyless with no ship stranded at the starting area.  After a lot of frustration I ended up making a smaller ship after selling what little materials I had left & went to my first planet which was kind of cool in a way.  The planets aren't really planets in a sense.  More like, several pieces with their own gravity stuck together.  If you walk around you'll see dead drops & if you jump over the drop you'll be pulled down by the other sides gravity.  Sort of like a janky Super Mario Galaxy.  Only half the planet had any atmosphere & it was always the half facing the sun which I didn't understand why they did this until I realized the side with atmosphere is supposed to be daytime while the space sky is night.  I guess it works but it's wierd looking up & seeing half day/night skies.  Later, I relogged in to find my ship was gone.  Then as I searched around for it I realized it had spawned in the middle of the planet I logged out of which is kind of funny.  Here's a video of the experience.


YouTube™ Video: Starmade - Dig out your ship! 

			Views: 43		

			Starmade is an interplanetary exploration game set in the depths of space. Now watch as I dig out my ship from the core in this mind numbing glitch!		

Been playing the game a bit more & harvesting asteroids with a new ship I made which seems to be the easiest way to make money.  Harvest & then sell what you gather.  Managed to build myself a half decent ship as well even though it's unfinished.  The whole thing still rather confusing.  I don't really know what I need to get hyperdrive working properly so my ship doesn't vaporize. I'm probably not gonna be trying that again for a while. Exploring that far away might not be worth it yet anyways.   This game also has performance issues.  Being an Alpha build I guess that is to be expected because the game runs badly & locks up on me at random moments.  Usually it locks up during the first loading sequence or when I shoot something for the first time.  If you're running a lower end machine I really don't recommend running anything on high settings.  I tried having shadows on High & it dropped my FPS down to single digits.If you do decide to buy it, do it to either support the devs or to see it through it's development cycle.  If you do plan on playing this game expect to spend several hours trying to figure out how to do anything because it's currently very confusing.  Hopefully the tutorial won't break for you like it did for me.  There's a lot of potential here & I'll probably end up playing this game more in the future & when it gets better overall.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Game was broken unplayable, after trying to contact support and doing every possible trick I could possibly try, going into the forums and reading pages after pages of possible solutions, I gave up and requested a refund. I couldn't even get the game to start. Here are my specs:  System Model: G750JM               BIOS: G750JM.206          Processor: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-4710HQ CPU @ 2.50GHz (8 CPUs), ~2.5GHz             Memory: 8192MB RAMAvailable OS Memory: 8074MB RAMNVIDIA GeForce GTX 860M Display Memory: 4020 MB   Dedicated Memory: 1972 MB      Shared Memory: 2048 MBIntel(R) HD Graphics 4600       Manufacturer: Intel Corporation          Chip type: Intel(R) HD Graphics Family           DAC type: InternalI blow past the minimum requirements, but the problem seems to be a conflict with my internal intel graphics. Internal graphics lowers my energy consumption when Im not playing games, which i require as a truck driver, but even after disabling it I could not load the game, or get enough help from support. Most games I can set the settings in nvidia to automatically switch to nvidia card or to internal intel. But this game does not get detected and setting it manually in nvidia does not do anything because the game will still try loading on the internal graphics regardless if you force load the nvidia card while the game plays. And disabling the intel graphics just mean you get new problems loading. It looked like it tried loading on a graphics card that does not exist, and removing and reinstalling does not work. Then I just gave up.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game gets boring quite quick. I would expect that a space sim should be made for exploration but the slow speed does not help with that. You also have no ingame mechanism for speeding up your ship except for the jump drives. You have to resort to hacking the config files. Would have liked it if I could rather add more thrusters to gain speed or at least build different kinds of thrusters. You are in constant search for the right kind of minerals if you want to make anything advance. You cannot place factories on your ship which means if you wanted to explore and get equipment at the same time then you're screwed. I cannot recommend this game to anyone. Rather play minecraft.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
Early Access Review
I really think this game has a huge potential.Would state this as mostly neutral with a touch negative, as controls are not perfect yet, but this is a huge issue for me in games.Also thanks a lot for fast help for another issue I had, @AndyP.There are lots of features + ideas that might make this game awesom and which others don't have.Still so far it still feels a bit to Alpha-ish. And yes, I know it is in Early access.Just saying this for people who look for a game more near to final release. "Keep an eye on this, it might become really good - just not recommendable enough YET" So far it's mostly some smaller things - but as said, especially controls bugging me* Mouse wheel direction for scrolling through action bar cannot be reverted* ... also does sometimes "jump" back instead of forward when scrolling too fast* Sounds stop working after a couple of minutes, only ambient stays on* Having several mining beams does still seem to be buggy, as only one of them actually mines, both in individual and combined mode* When flying around, ships gets slower. But there is no friction in space... (or just make counter-thruster toggable in general, see SE)* UI is improvable and like making it scalable and more readable font. Also stuff like available (and direction of) gravity would be helpful. * Button to switch "jetpack" on/off would also help.

								Update: I got it running on my Nvidia GPU laptop.  I verified local files and then it ran.  I'm still not recommending the game at this time but at least I can play it.Won't start on two different computers, one dedicated Nvidia GPU and other is Intel. And I'd say the 1.0+ hrs on record it shows is me trying to launch the game because it uses a launcher.The developer needs to stop what they are doing and write some exception handling during startup that at minimum tells the user why the game didn't start.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								Kind of an unplayable mess, even on a beefier computer. Strange error messages constantly bombard you in single player about "contacting an admin" and "failure to connect to server". Said messages are impossible to toggle off, and will dominate the screen every thirty seconds, just in case you've forgotten about them. You won't, no matter how hard you try.The tutorial, it doesn't even fill that basic capacity. Vague, confusing item descriptions.Shipbuilding, if you manage to get that far without crashing or lagging and then freezing, is extremely vague, but I will concede that might be part of my frustraition in even getting that far. It usually gets to about that point consistently in the tutorial, and then the game lags, freezes, and crashes, or just generally freezes for fifteen minutes and dumps you on a barren asteroid in bumble**** nowhere, should you decide to abort the tutorial, out of concern the tutorial might be the problem. Eats up RAM, regardless of settings. I mean, 8 gigs is PLENTY to work with. This isn't Fallout 4 we're playing here.Apparently, there's quite a bit of fun to be had in this game, according to other reviews and videos I've watched, but I haven't found it at all. Extremely frustrating. Here's to hoping it gets better in the future, because from everything I've seen, there's so much potential here. I want to like this so badly.

number of helpful: 6 of 17 people (35%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 26
Early Access Review
								There are alot of very good ideas behind starmade. But as far as the game development has progressed, I have been disappointed about almost every aspect of this game. When you start playing this game, and somehow keep playing, although the game is going to make it a really hard time for you with all the bugs and crashes and issues, you believe for a while that there is so much potential for what you could build or do, because it does seem to have so many degrees of freedom. But it is an essentially empty experience, since you can have all those nice forms within the game, when you are ready to spent hours in building them by getting the most out of the few building blocks you have, but there is only very little function, that could give those forms purpose. There is also very little going on, in the whole universe. The technical limitations of this game do not allow the amount of objects, the complexity of the objects and the amount of players in a online-multiplayer-setting, that is necessary to make up for a vast, but also rich and interesting universe, where you want to spent your time in.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								There is a lot of good to be said about the game, especially that the demo essentially allows players to play for free, but it feels like that is  only there because of how broken this game truly is. I am writing this post on 12/20/2015 and the game was launched over a year ago via Early Access on 11/27/2014. Over a year later and the core mechanics of this game are still completely and utterly unstable.Java simply can’t run everything these developers want to do. Beefed out servers hold and run a nice small set of players mining and building, but as soon as it is time for anything more than that get ready to have even the most technologically sophisticated servers buckle under the pressure. My group’s latest attempt to get back into this game netted us server crashes and pings in excess of4k - 10k for one player simply attacking a Pirate station.  Not some sort of galactic struggle for dominance, but a simple PvE interaction between one player.I’d love to spend a hefty amount of time here to write more, but it just doesn’t feel worth my time. The developers seem to still be making updates, but are focusing on non-critical items to this game such as the problem mentioned above. This game would be quite a bit of fun if the core mechanics worked properly and it is a darn shame that they don’t.

number of helpful: 11 of 28 people (39%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game came just before a slew of others of the same idea did---a builder game with space ships/stations.  I'd bought this with another one that's since died, called "Blockade Runner".  Thing is, Space Engineers came along, then a couple years after Empyrion.Yes, this is comparable to those two---which have the same idea behind them but better execution.  This feels like a messy cluster of the same idea that's harder to do stuff in, and less pretty.Edit: Seems my review is being voted down as "Not being helpful", fair enough.  There's a lot of people that like this game---but simply put?  I don't.  And I think there is better.Also after playing for some time, I can state---my opinion of the game has not changed.  The tutorial was an absolute mess---it doesn't explain well some of the mechanics of the game like how to roll your ship so it's level.  Speaking of that, having to constantly align yourself to everything to even get your bearings is a frustrating mess.The bulding in itself is simplistic---that's nice enough, however it gets frustrating when you realize everything kind of has a bland block look to it.  Everything.  From the weapons, to the mechanical blocks.There's also a distinct lack of sound in regards to doing things---it becomes very noticeable as you go on.The upside is that there -is- things to do in this game.  It seems large, and I'm sure if you're able to get past the clunky mechanics, the bland textures, and the lack-luster physics (I'm looking at you, wonky ships and the "Aligning" mechanic), that there's fun to be had...However I couldn't get past it.

content:

Early Access Review
								Where do I even start with this game...I played this back when it was free. It was very laggy and kinda hard to really understand, so I got rid of it.A few years later, I see that it's now on Steam, and has a price! "Gee!" I thought, "A price and everything! Maybe the preformance is better!"But no, it got worse.The game still lags its♥♥♥♥♥off in the 64 Bit version. 32 Bit is fine, but that apparently has its problems too. Like NOT BEING ABLE TO SAVE PROPERLY.The most suggested solution was to move the Installation folder. SO I did this. 3 Times. and all 3 times, it didn't work. All to make sure I can save properly.But then, I was told by the Tech Support team, when I submitted a ticket, that I had to disable some stuff in my AV program, Kaspersky, and install Java 64 Bit in order to fix stuff. But that just made it worse, as now, the game is so laggy it's a struggle to play, and the last time I played it, It crashed when I tried to move.DOn't get this game until this♥♥♥♥♥♥s fixed. In my experience, this was Starforge all over again. Brilliant Concept,♥♥♥♥♥♥Poor execution. Don't spend 10 bucks until the devteam makes it so that this game doesn't come in on life support.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game offers the opportunity to spend hundreds of hours awkwardly assembing ships only to let you down with soul-crushing bugs that invaidate your designs. Or, if you do get your hull off the ground, by watching your hard-wrought creations get basically oneshotted by somone that's built bigger than you. The development roadmap seems wildly unrealistic, given the glacial pace of new features and consistent introduction of new bugs. I'd love to be proven wrong, but I feel like the true potential of this game is well beyond the development team's current capabilites.Even if you get this game free, I wouldn't advise investing your time into it. Go play a game on a better development trajectory, and you'll be far less likely to be let down. Maybe it'll get better next release... but I've been telling myself that for far too long already.

number of helpful: 0 of 6 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								So you want a spaceship building/flying simulator, you take a look at this and it looks pretty cool. You buy it with high expectations, but as soon as you start playing you are thrown into the game with a choice to participate in a tutorial. You decide to try the tutorial so you can get a solid footing in the game. You go through the tutorial finding out you're more confused than ever and not sure what you're doing. Eventually you leave the tutorial and decide to start trying the game yourself. you get to a point where you can't make anything without some kind of factory block. You build said factory block only to find you need a direct power source, so you build a power source but can't figure out how to connect it despite what the control tips say. You end up stranded on a planet not sure what to do next until you eventually get bored and quit.This has been pretty much the extent of my experience with this game. It seemed to have potential, but if the game interface is so user-unfriendly that you're pretty much just playing a "drift through space with only a space helmet and some blocks which can make a shoddy ship" sim, you're bound to get REALLY BORED!To make matters worse everything is done with blocks, and the only difference between those blocks besides the function, is the color. I mean, you want to fly a ship? sure! just stuff your body into this block! (who do you think we are? solid snake?) oh but it gets more amusing when you notice there is a money system in the game. Sure, not the worst idea in voxel games, but how are you supposed to make money when you only ship you can ever make is a 3D version of the space invaders starfighter?Ultimately I find this game to be an utter disappointment. Don't waste your money on this game!

content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Starmade is a small game in a massive world. There is building and designing to be had, fighting (apparently) and lots of other stuff. Unfortunately, the game as a whole seems hollow. The only aspect I can really see in it is large scale coop or PvP. If that's your thing, go ahead and don't let me stop you. But if you're looking for something interesting and easy to play in your spare time, find something else.19th Feb 16In a more detailed analysis.When I said "small game in a massive world" I meant that like any procedurally generated game (see Terraria for an example of what I'm talking about here), there is a limited amount of things you can have generated in an infinite universe. The asteroids and planets are almost identical throughout the galaxy. This not only makes no sense but gets quite boring. There are only a few colors (atmosphere color and dirt color / flora) of planets; there is yellow (desert), purple, green (Earth-like), and white (ice). Each of these has about four or so generation algorithms. So the terrain is essentially four types on planets. There is floating weird stuff that looks like noodles, there's plateau, hills, and spires. That's about it for planets.Then there's the asteroids, which are hardly worth talking about since they have the same shape. They too have different colors (and different types of materials to harvest). But that's it.There are about 6 (?) types of pirate station in the game. I have never seen them do anything at all. Just sit there. There are some abandoned derelict stations which are incredibly well designed, but since walking around in them is so damn slow, you probably won't bother to explore them. The crafting and the building is always on a massive scale. You will find yourself eventually using about a thousand (at least) factory enhancers (meaning 1000x the speed to craft items) for basically everything. You'll eventually text edit your config files so you can place 10000 blocks at a time instead of 100. The combat and ships designed for combat are simplistic. In this game, the more functional blocks you put on your ship, the more invincible it is. If you have shields that recharge at 2k a second and the enemy can only deal 1.99k a second, you literally cannot ever die. In combat the enemy AI basically works off these principles only: Go towards enemy. In you don't have any weapons run away. Fire weapons at enemy, repeat.In non-combat situations, the AI is just not even there. There are seemingly no random attacks, patrols, factions, retaliations, or anything. There's a bunch of static stuff that shoots at you when you get too close and calls for drones. The complexity of the game wears off extremely quickly. Unless you jump head first into logic (and get drowned in it), you'll know everything about how the game works and how to do just about anything that is possible in ~60 hours. Then there is no longer complexity. You'll realise the only reason you created a working airlock is because it looks cool when it opens. In my opinion, this is – what a surprise – another case of “wait for it to be released”. I have not had a single early access game turn out to be any good. I'm hoping this will be different, but if they're releasing updates just to change the tool models, I don't know how likely that will be.

								If you like minecraft creative mode without infinite blocks, you'll like this. Imagine floating in endless space with nobody around and you'll have some idea of how dull this game is. At least in Minecraft, there's a threat of death that creates suspense. In this game you could fly around for hours and see nothing. The planets are tiny polygons that totally break any immersion, ship building is slow and tedious, pvp is the exact opposite of rewarding and is mostly avoided by anyone but server admins because if you wanna repair your ship, you're most like gonna have to travel half way across the galaxy to find the materials. This is also why you'll most likely never see anyone on a server. The one good side to this is it makes a much friendlier community, since nobody wants to pvp. But that doesn't make for a fun game.Good concept, failed execution. Don't bother.

Early Access Review
								I'm not going into any length with this review; the game simply isn't worth the time for that.30+ hours in the game and 1/3 of that has been spent in a state of constant technical troubleshooting. To make matters worse, once you get past these "glitches" you'll play for a bit, get bored, stop the game and come back a few months later to have to go through all of the same techncial troublshooting you intially went through.White screens, black screens, memory errors, constant loading screens, you name your error and chances are, you'll probably find it! Two or three years ago, maybe I'd forgive this... but that was 2 or 3 years ago already.Then the game itself is just plain boring. It's full of doing nothing but the same thing over and over again for no real gain or advancement. Eventually I just said "f*ck it" and built a huge ship of nothign but mining lasers and blasted the hell out of all the planets I found, because... why not??The controls are clunky. The ship building is counterintuitive. The immersion is non-existent. The tutorials are useless. The interface is too complex. There's really nothing in this game that hooks you in and says "Play me!".

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Intially I thought. Oh hey intel drivers break this game therefore unplayable. So the community or the devs(dont know which one) were quick to respond and help me out. A plus on that. tThen i tried the game and OH my god is it just as bad as i hoped it not to be.This game in its current state is filled to the brink with a large amount of bugs and is quite shame because from the trailers i expected large ships and stations filled with people to be a common core element of the game. Sadly the footage in the trailer was either impossible to get normally, takes WAY too much time to aquire as there is no way to increase building speed, and or multiplayer. One of the features of the game, factions is present in only in multiplayer. There is no AI factions within the game. Well.. The two that are there are basically enemy faction and nuetrals. Otherwise known as standard generic name 1 : pirates( really pirates? couldnt be more like Space dudes or anything else?) and the generic nuetral faction trading guild. These are the only two NPC factions currently in the game. So then factions come down to multiplayer.Thats where the problem lies, because this a java coded sandbox game or a sandbox game in general, to get the most out of the game you must join a high pop server. Bingo. There is already a massive problem. Finding a good high pop server in any sandbox is not only tedious but requires a large amount of time from the player to get anything done. you must make sure the server has no greifers, protection against greifers, is constantly up, does not have troll admins, is not filleld with jackasses. The devs have not implemented anything in their game to let the player know which servers could be recommend or which servers the player should avoid. It works exactly like minecraft ip multiplayer connecting. Where every server you join has that equal chance of being a gem in a sea of turds or exaclty what you would expect. The game itself also plays quite horribly. To fly a ship you must enter the ships core, this warps you into a small space giving no visual indiction of what just happened. There is also the nice feature of switching into build mode using space. I cannot tell you exaclty how much hate i have for this design choice. Why would you make it so the building a ship requires to enter you ship itself  and make one of the most common keys for going up the one to send you into a mode REQUIRED for buildiing the ship. You dont need to do this for stations, only for ships. ITS ANNOYING AS HELL!!! Your character LITERRALY becomes the ship block. To make matters worse once inside the ship, flying becomes terrible. The ships wobble and spin all over the place as you fly and trying to rotate the ship with the slightest tap from the  c or v keys (i think thats the one) cause you to spin uncontrobble for about 45 degrees a second. So the controls suck. The ship flying sucks. Well that already ruins one of the MAJOR ASPECTS about this game. You would think in game about SPACESHIPS the devs would go ahead and make it a priority to make controls in your spaceships as good as possible. Well alright then maybe building should be fun you say. NOPE. Getting materials is literally brain dead boring and therefore construction becomes brain dead boring. To gather materials , right click. material will be gathered by a random laser that sticks out your face and with the magic of blue box shrinking "salavages". You then collect said ore with overly complicated name that every time you wanna build something your forced to alt tab the game and go look it up on the wiki. Oh and since the deves dont wanna give someway to view a long crafting tree and or how to make certain componenets and what not, your forced to ALT TAB the friggin game every time you wanna make something. So then crafting items which is a core element of the game becomes very tedious and thus makes building boring. Also if you have played minecraft for an extended period of time you will get bored very quickly as there is no depth to the blocks. When your blocks break they splinter. While at least in minecraft out of all things, breaking block is more interactive , there is a sound to the blocks breaking, the block itself will drop as an item. As you break the block the block begins to crack. There is a feeling of life to the blocks. While in starmade the way the block building and destroying system works makes them incredibly boring. They feel and look like godamn cardboard with not effort to them whatsoever. On planets the prodcedual generation can get pretty cool from a distance. However in a game about space, and granted this is early access there is NOTHING about the planets that indicate any excitement or uniquess whatsover.The planets range from ice planet, grass planet, rock planet. Really more like, purple planet, green planet, blue planet. It gets boring very fast. In fact the whole game becomes a repeative drag very quickly. Now this expierence might change on multiplayer. Good luck with that. This game does have some potential however, and granted its early access i might give it some leway considring its also free. I would have really liked to get into the game as it has really cool complicated and innovated game play mechanics some how advertised. But the gameplay itself, the UI, everything about the game feels like a giant waste of tme at first which makes it REALLY difficult to play. You have to, get used to the game. Which could take SEVERAL hours of gameplay before the game would start to shine. Is it worth it? Is it worth going through that hassle just to get ready for the game. NO. Its not and im not sure it well ever be. I wouldnt recommend this to most people. Regardless of early access and or its potenetial , the devs current decisions on how the game operates is just terrible. Maybe there is no workaround due ot how the game code works. In that case alot more thought should have been put forth before developing this game on its core mechanics, UI, basic elements... In its current state its impossbile to really get into. Unless the dev decides to overhaul the basics and resdign come core compents of the game to simply put play better, do not get this game. It fits a very small niche auidence .

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Note: Just tried to play again today, and I couldn't connect to any servers because 'runtime encryption error'. So, that should tell you at least something about what a struggle it is.Now, my opinion on Early Access games comes with a warning. I'm not gonna ♥♥♥♥♥foot around. I'm going to review the game AS IS, and I'm going to completely disregard everything that is promised or expected for this game. When you buy an Early Access game you don't buy a promise for a good game, you buy the game as it is in it's current state. I'm going to tell you what you'll get for your money.Now, I didn't spend an overly large amount of time on this game. Not at all, in fact. But it doesn't need an overly large amount of playtime to see what this game is.This game is not an exploration game. This is not a massively multiplayer game. This is a ship-builder. You build ships. Maybe you make a factory to get ship components, or maybe you salvage components from the pirate ships that just kind of fly around and generally do nothing. But really, you build ships. Don't get me wrong, that's really fun, and playing with the logic system and all the guns is really great. Heck, I even had a good time figuring out how to power my massive freaking behemoth destroyer. But all you really do is build ships.Occasionally it's possible to fly around and screw with other players, which is a kick, and there's the pirate stations to destroy, but the lack of other content in this game is grating. It has a few really good systems, but there is almost nothing besides those. Flying around in a huge ship shaped like a phallus is great and all, but there's next to nothing to do but just that. Fly around.There are NPCs in StarMade, but really NPC describes them for almost exactly what they are. Non-player characters. Nothing more, nothing less. There are pirates, but they're just computers in some outdated drone ships. Pirate stations have no pirate NPCs to fight, just ships and defenses. There're shops, but they're entirely player operated and stocked, basically. All of this just adds to the lack of depth.The description promises epic fleet battles, but really there is none of that unless you're a really good organizer or can find a group that regularly arranges those. The biggest battle I've ever been in was with one aggravating player and 2 of his friends. There's not really anything to fight over anyway. (Unless you really value hunks of rock floating in space.)There's a mountainous learning curve to all this, and although I managed to conquer it, some won't.It's tough, no doubt about it, but mostly worth it if you manage to figure it out. Most of the fun of this game is learning, but once you exhaust that, it's just shipbuilding and flying from there.Now, I've so far not mentioned any of the glitches this game boasts. I'll list these here, but don't cry to me about how 'the game is Early Access and it's going to have SOME bugs, come on', because Jesus H. Christ on a bike, there is a lot more than 'some bugs'. It is because of this and the fact that there is NO GAURANTEE that the game will have them fixed that I am going to gripe about them. They've persisted this long, and I know, the developer fixes bugs. But the lack of additional content I've seen added to this game gives me this sinking feeling that there is not really going to be anything major done to this game. (Please, oh PLEASE developer, prove me wrong.)Launching the game for the first time is a battle. If it doesn't work, there's a mile's long list of the things that could have caused it. Java out of date? Oh, you have the x64 AND x32 versions of Java? Have a slight headache? Good luck trying to get it to cooperate. Really. The worst part is, once you solve one problem there is almost ALWAYS going to be another. If you hate a game crashing, then you'll really hate StarMade, because this game has crashes GALORE. They happen almost randomly, which is the most frustrating thing when playing. The best part? There's no gaurantee that that thing you did to launch the game last time is gonna work again.TL;DRThe game is buggy as hell, the dev 'works' on the game, but not really in any significant capacity, and the game has about as much depth as a puddle of water on a hot summer day. In it's current state, I do not reccomend it. Maybe  wait around, see if the dev really does anything, and if they do, THEN cash in. But until then, I can't say this game is worth 15$.But hey, if you like building ships and rigging super complex logic boards, then give it a try. The demo IS free, after all.But don't say I didn't warn you.Edit: Yes, I know you don't have to buy the game. That's why I'm posting the review here and not on the demo page. Also, the launcher just dropped yesterday and it fixes a big complaint of mine.P.S. If you're thinking about posting a negative review, apparently that is looked down upon, as I have recieved multiple messages (Yes, messages, not comments) on how my opinion was♥♥♥♥♥♥and I shouldn't have posted this. If you have read this and are thinking of messaging me, please refrain from doing so, as that is a step BEYOND the line of suggestion.

number of helpful: 3 of 15 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is an early access review and may change as the game progresses.  Also I ONLY tried the single player game.I really really wanted to love this game, and even now I'm struggling to give it a thumbs down because it has such promise and potential.  I want to support the developers so they make this the game that I hoped it would be.  I just don't feel it's right for me yet.based on the comments I will add some amendments to my review.  I only played single player and thus had no explanations outside of the tutorial.  I'm not big on pvp and didn't want to spend as much time on a wikki as I did playing, but love space exploration type games.  It sounds like multiplayer is more fun.  I didn't know about cameras, shields, ect... because I dove into single player and was never able to survive long enough to upgrade my tech far enough to get any of those things.--Space is big and I LOVE that aspect.  Some people were complaining that it takes too long to get anywhere but I felt that helped with the emersion.--Ship building is an awesome idea but the controls let it down.  Movement is not intuitive and I'm not sure how to fix that.--In "battle" I often accidentally switched to build mode making the slaughter even worse.--I've never won a fight against the AI.  They always seem to hit my critical systems with amazing accuracy.--The game universe is huge, but feels empty.  The only thing to do is build a target for the AIs and mine on large asteroids that I think are supposed to be planets.  If they are planets they are very small.  I guess you can build a base on one if you wanted.  There's not much else going on.--I had trouble figuring out how to set a waypoint marker so I could come back to a world I liked.  Never did figure it out.--The map is practically useless.  I couldn't tell where I was, which direction I was going, and whether it even mattered if I went that way.--You have to put your most important piece of the ship in the front or try to fly with the ship right in your face in 3rd person mode (taking up most of the screen) because you can't see anything if the core is buried.  (apparently there are cameras that help with the view.  I never survived long enough to advance my tech that far).  Perhaps if I understood the map better I could mine and advance in safe territories before fighting.--it doesn't matter where you put your most important piece of the ship because the random enemies that attack for no reason will crush right through any armor you put over it.  (apparently there are shields that help keep them from disabling you before you realize you're being attacked but once again I never got that far.)I wanted to love it, and I still want to love it.  Please developers make the single player better!  As for the multiplayer, I can't speak for it at all.  Sounds like a good game for people who like pvp, or don't mind spending some time studying the wikki.  For me, I'll wait till a few updates roll in and give it another shot.

content:

Early Access Review
								I don't know if the other reviews are pranks or if my copy of the game is just bugged to hell or what, but this is not a fun game. So I build a ship, give it cannons, give it an engine, fly out into space. Dead. Why? Not a clue. There was no sound, no visual cues, nothing.Alright, maybe it was just a mistake of some sort - try it again, this time with only a hull and engines since I lost all my good stuff when I died. Fly for about ten minutes, trying to navigate by the map provided. Space is *empty*. I mean, totally empty. No asteroids, not other passing ships, nothing. There is you, there is an "Undiscovered thing" and the "Shop". Period. So I go to this undiscovered thing. Oh look, it's a ship with green, welcoming lights! I will do well here-... and I'm dead.Between the boring treck in a straight line from the shop to the ship of death, to the surprise of death, to the one time I found an asteroid, tried to mine it and all colours went eye-burning neon - I would give this game a miss. I would maybe play it on Kongregate for ten minutes.

								Had high hopes for this game. When I first started playing I went through all of the tutorials possible in the game, spawned in multiplayer and start into space. Going good at 350-380 FPS. Come up to a planet and warnings start flashing that my memory ins't sufficient enough and to raise it. So i exit the game, raise my memory to 4 gb out of 8 gb ram. Finally get back on and don't recieve the memory warning. Going good on a planet, have all my stuff stored up. Running 130-150 FPS until 4 people or pirates came down on my planet, dropped me immediatley down to 1 FPS, wait around for 10 minutes and nothing changed. Rage quite because i find it hard to believe that my Nvidea GTX 860m can run BF4, Simcity 5, Tropico 5, Civ 5 all on ultra around 60 FPS but cant run some game that has some of the most simple geometry when events start to happen. Oh and my internet has an average of 30 mbps  . So in short, wait for this game to be finished, and for all the bugs to be fixed so you can enjoy the game without the freezes and crashes.EDIT (After installing 64 bit Java)Okay after installing java 64 bit and increasing my memory to 6 GB, the game runs around 40 FPS in intence scenes. If you buy this game, make sure you are running 64 bit Java, or your pretty much boned, and if you have nvidea graphics card and are on a laptop, make sure to go to your graphics panel and into 3d models to control which graphics card runs Java.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								StarMade is less appealing today than it was in 2013. The best memories I have of this game are building evil harvesting ships, going to abandoned planets and eating up damaged bases and old satellites where there was once war. I remember starting my own planet and building a factory to produce a resource, made from some plant we grew in fields.None of that is really possible anymore. Planets have been redesigned into dodecahedrons, with visible gaps on the edges and glitchy gravity. I find this disgusting and a massive step backwards, but some have defended it as "more realistic" which is odd, given very little about the game is or needs to be. Harvesting old materials is now severely limited. You can't go and eat up an abandoned space station anymore, according to a friend who tried. StarMade feels like the work of a programmer, and not an all-round developer. The textures are still odd. The player model looks disturbing. Overall it lacks the creative substance to feel satisfying. I suspect this kind of design focus isn't of priority to the developer.I fear that the community around the game is too accepting of progress for the sake of progress, instead of working forwards to make the game feel right. I waited ages for it to come to Steam, and now I've lost my love for it.I can't recommend this game on the basis that I'm not convinced it will evolve into the game it should be. I feel it will continue to change, for better or worse, and end up a niche game, that neither wins as a sandbox or an exploration adventure. I think it is too abstract and awkwardly executed to have mass appeal, and you really need to have enthusiasm for space games to enjoy it currently.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								The interface is terrible, the lag is terrible, the (default) controls are terrible. Get ready to notice that the devs haven't quite figured out the difference between "breaking" and "braking" - which is probably the least of their grammer, English, and general text formatting errors, There is an atmosphere in the vacuum of space, you'll constantly find yourself fighting to get oriented the right way due to the devs forcing an up and down IN SPACE (because screw logic), and the mouse sensitivity is insanely low by default (I've got it around 1.3, it starts at 0.5).The graphical options (which you find when you press 'Start Game', as opposed to 'Options...') are probably the most competent part of the entire game, which isn't saying much. The resolutions and refresh rates seem to be a fixed list (despite knowing for a fact that Java can poll the OS for a list of available screen resolutions and refresh rates); antialiasing and v-sync (competently named 'Vertical Synch') are hidden (check 'Settings->Show Advanced Settings' to get them), while anisotropic filtering is still AWOL; and the launcher is more than happy to bring your computer to a grinding halt to get you to the options menu in the first place (don't you just love Java?).As for the actual gameplay, you mostly find yourself wandering aimlessly and taking a long time (due to the aforementioned "the vacuum of space, now with ∞% more atmosphere") to get somewhere to do something so that you can make your tiny ship a little bigger, and continue rinsing and repeating.Noting that this is in early alpha, most of this is fixable, while some of it should have never been a problem in the first place. At the moment I'd recommend staying away.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								So much potential, yet so little effort and planning.This game has a great potential, really, but it's badly developed. The controls are so badly implemented and unconfortable that they pose a huge obstacle when starting the game. Rotating a block should be a very easy and basic task, but it's not. Rotating the ship while flying should be easy, but it's spread on "z" and "x" keys that on some keyboard layout are too far from the usual WASD. Same for the external camera. Guess how you do that? Hold left shift, press right shift and...with your nose, third hand or p***s you scroll the mousewhell!! WTF??Usually you open the map with the "m", like in 99% of the games, but in Starmade you don't! You have to press..."p", and the map is complicated as f**k to read and navigate. I've seen many space games being a lot easier to handle. I've tried to visit a planet with a friend, and I ended up falling in a crater without a way out because I could build or destroy due to the planet owned by my faction. Problem is: we weren't even in a faction! We left the "no faction" just to be sure, and it say we were still in a faction.So, the easiest tasks are more aggravating than fun, and only in the first hour of the game.Add lag spikes, a counter intuitive server joining system, sluggish as s**t mouse controls without a real way to fix it, glitchy lighting effects and a lot more problems that I don't even want to mention.Yes, it's early access, but it's not an excuse. At least release it after the most basic options are actually working!Minecraft is a huge success for just one reason: it controls really easy and it's playable.Apart from this, I repeat, the game has a lot of potential. Wait months or years to have a finished product and it might become a very good title. I may rewrite this review after I a see a playable game.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Oh my GOD is this game♥♥♥♥♥♥or what? JAVA? This is not 1999 where java is a thing this is 2016 and this is supposed to be a PC game. Does not detect my Steam Controller in GamePad mode at all since it relies on using the Windows gamepads and NOT any normal Xinput or Dinput API. The launcher is terribly cluttered and made by a 12-year-old and the game itself can't even set half the options present in the settings. If I had not gotten this game as part of a bundle I would have refunded this immediately. AVOID LIKE THE PLAGUE! DO NOT BUY!UPDATE: Out of principal, I will not remove this review. My statements are accurate. If the game is SO early development it can't even be played then it should not be sold for money. Give away a free demo to try out and don't try and sell it.EDIT: For those without and clue, when I say windows gamepads I mean it relies on there being a gamepad device in the Windows gamepads dialog for detection. This means the SC and quite a few other devices, including most virtual gamepad devices can and do have problems here. If they were using, say an API (Application program interface) like Xinput or even the older Dinput it would work without fail. Let's just hope they can figure out how to not use Java, for security reasons, and how to use an API before the world is graced with this for real.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ah, Starmade. Where to start, where to start...Let's start off with the fact that it isn't friendly at all to new users. Poorly laid-out tutorial and abstract navigation, in all aspects, hits a new player like a freight train. Not to mention the incredibly confusing movement mechanics, high learning curve, and lack of direction.Yes, it is a sandbox. Yes, there are such things as 'quests'. Yes, there is multiplayer, but it is so lacking in 'oomph' that, after playing a little while, you sit back and think "What the hell am I accomplishing?" The very existence of this thought is a red flag that maybe buying this game wasn't the best choice.Not to mention the voxel-based sandbox genre that's now getting kind of old. Yes, I knew when buying the game that it would have this 'style', but at the time I thought that it would be toned down a notch, like Space Engineers. Sadly, I was dead wrong. Not that I should complain, just a nitpick.StarMade, in its Alpha, has quite of a bit of a journey to make in its development.For now, StarMade sits in the dark corner of my game library, waiting to be re-installed when I feel like it's worthy of another try.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Would I recommend this game to my best friend in its current state? No, not unless I intend to have us be frustrated at one another.This game isn't ready yet, so I suggest you demo it and get it for free off of their website. This is painfully hard to use, the controls and UI is kind of a mess. I got a private server up and running, only to have the audio in the game go through a permanent loop. Possible improvement ideas:-A notification if two actions are bound to the same key-Audio loop fix-A way to restart the game without going through task manager and ending the process   -BTW you have to run the game twice to start a dedicated server and play the game yourself, but     steam won't let you run the game twice-Better and Cleaner UI-Ability to spawn another ship in case you lose yours without having to reset the server or being stranded in the middle of nowhere.-Creative mode so I can start building starships right away instead of sandbox-If you suicide it respawns you near your last ship-Improve tutorial lightingAre the developers good? Yes. Will the game be good eventually? Yes. Is it there yet? Not quite.Is the game BAD? No.Is it easy to pick up and play immediately? No.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								So, I have played this game for a few hours now and i have to say it is an excellent game for early access. Although it may feel like minecraft, it is NOT minecraft. It has a few bugs that need to be figured out and I think I would prefer an actual in game engine. It definitly be better optimized for mac, which by the way I suggest getting this game for PC and not Mac. The developers may have fixed optimization for mac for some bugs but, it still falls flat. Especially when I try running it on my mac. It either crashes or is slow starting up or when I actually manage get it running mac the framerate is all over the place. If you plan to get this game I recommend you get it but run it on PC because mac simply doesn't run very well especially this early. I would like to add that this game is stingy when it comes to RAM. Allow me to explain: My PC has an intel extreme motherboard, a Geforce GT 9800, and 8GB of RAM(it had 4). When I upgraded to 8GB from for the reason was because the game said to and I quote "increase the max memory." Of course I upgrade to 8GB(it was time anyway). So, I upgraded and I got the same message just after I upgraded. Please fix this. The messages are annoying especially when it should have fixed itself with the upgrade. PS: if anyone has any thoughts on trying to get a quick fix, I welcome the assistance. UPDATE: I haven't played this game in weeks and I wanted to give a quick update for my review. I have change my rating of this game from recommend to not recommend. Why? because they changed the price to $14.99. That price is simply not reasonable especially for a game that isn't nearly complete nor does it have a proper starting menu! It has planets to explore but no creatures to fight. I don't use muliplayer but the last time I tried to the servers kept craching on me. Until, they can have thi game no longer in beta, I DO NOT Recommend this game. I will keep my copy and update it as they roll out but, I will not be playing his game unil it has come out of beta. Also, my mac isn't the most powerful thing the world and my PC the one with 9800 GT doesn't show picture anymore so, I need a new PC to play this game anyway. In addition, the recommended specs and minimum specs listed are too vague to even consider trying the game out. UPDATE 4/7/2016: I am recommending this game because I have found a way to fix the RAM issue that I had earlier. I would have prefered NOT to edit the amount of RAM allocated as I thought it would be automatic, but it works and that is what matters now. I am very pleased with the recent updates to the logic system and I hope that more will roll out as I continue my support for this game as it has a lot of potential. I hope that a new launcher gets introduced as soon as possible and that future players won't have to edit the RAM allocation as most games have it on automatic anyway. I hope that new detail options, new ship templates and new Space Station templates to give more creativity and options. I would also like to see a small drop in price as $14.99 is still a bit much for a game in beta. I still stand by my thoughts on the price as said in the previous update. So until the next update, buy this game to let your creative mind loose.UPDATE 3/10/2017: Now that the main menu has gotten a major overhall, and the game has gotten some major improvements I still keep my review of this game to recommended. Now, it isn't perfect but, I never expected it to be. With the massive improvements to the menu and an easier way to allocate memory to the game it seem like once the game game is finished I will be playing more and more. Keep up the good work. Also, for those interested in early access on steam this is how you do it. This is an excellent example of how to do EA.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								To start off, I will announce that I am a space enthusiast who has played and relatively enjoyed other space games that are in the gaming market as of right now. I can honestly say that this game seems to be more exciting than almost all of them. If you are looking for a complete game, re-direct youself to the Early-Access Notice on the Starmade store page and realize what that means. If it seems like I am being abrasive it is only because I do not want people  to judge this game as being a full game and I also want you to spend your money on a complete game if that is what you want.That being said, I will attempt to break up this review into 2 seciton's of the Pro's and Con's of this game with a summary at the end for all of the TL:DR's.Pro's:- Complete Freewill with building and a massive sandbox to test your creation's.- you can Build and Create your own Station's in space and on the surface of planets.- Faction wars if you choose to get involved in them.- Your Mind is the only limit to your creation's. (ie. If you want an explorer ship to fly around the galaxy, a Massive Dreadnought to take on the Pirate plague the infects the universe, a Mining ship to tear apart planets and asteroids for materials to fuel your coffers of either your own or your factions you may.)- The game doesn't really seem to get boring unlike other sandboxes (especially with friends.)- The mechanics of the game are smooth and have a great basis for improvement.- The Dev's seem devoted, creative, and extremely passionate about this game.- It is still within its Alpha stage and already feels very complete.Con's- Could be better building mechanics such as switching out blocks for another (on larger ships) in an easier fashion rather than just setting your x,y,z to 100 and clicking away.- The UI could be a enhanced a tad to not only look better but also provide wider control over various aspects of your ship/character/info panels (faction, ship, navigation, etc.).- Needs more content that allow us as the player to impact to the universe around us. (again, Alpha state.)- A bit of a learning curve which either takes asking questions, watching tutorials, or simply tampering around and experimenting on your own (I would suggest the others if you are looking to get up to speed quick.)- I found this game just as college was swinging back around to hit me in the face.Overall, Great game with a solid base for improvement and a galaxy and a Dev team that allow for it expand. In my opinion, the fact that this game in in its alpha state suprises my and also gets me just as excited and crazed as a girl going to starbucks. TL:DR- Minecraft in space, but it doesn't feel like all you are doing is slapping chickens and punching wood. Instead, you can phaser a planet and watch its molten core be exposed and your storage start teeming with loot. That can help you on your way to becoming a mogul and or fueling your passion to build Fleet of your own creations. Or you can inhabit that planet and build your very own colony that people can visit and shop at. Or you can be sucked into that planet never to enter space again because you didn't put enough thrust to your♥♥♥♥♥and thus you cant escape the planets gravity. Your Choice.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is deceptively simple but is in fact, extremely deep and complex.  If you simply did a bullet point summation of it's features, you'd have a game description that would have almost any PC gamer salivating.  But the modest graphics may lead some gamers to dismiss it out of simple ignorance to what's under the hood.- Fully realized 3D engine with first person perspectives- Massive Universe spanning more solar systems than we'll ever visit- Space Combat- Resource gathering- Trading- Crafting (and this one is key)- Complex divers ship systems that allows for unique gameplay experiences- Player Factions with complex ranks and privileges- Player controlled systems and sectors- The ability to land on the surface of planets ;)- Private servers with the ability to set game parameters and all the coolness that offersHell, this game delivers more than Star Citizen has promised with the except for graphic fidelity and animations.  Oh, and you can build whatever you want.  Space stations, fighters, dreadnaughts, asteroid hangers, plantery bunkers, whatever you can think of.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								StarMade is one of the coolest games I have ever plain. Although it has it's bugs *Cough* Planet Gravity *Cough*, It is one of the best and most fluent games on Steam. What starts out to seem like a boring game, turns into an amazing (possibly face paced), beautiful, and scientific game. The fights that you can make or join in can sometimes be thrilling, and the things that you can make are amazing! I can right a very, very long list about all of the things that I like about this game; but the list of bad things would be minimal. I recommend this game to anyone that even remotely likes space and/or science fiction, and can deal with bugs and glitches. (It is still currently in Alpha, so you'll have to get used to that stuff.)

Early Access Review
								This game is really awesome. If you have a Minecraft / builder game itch, this will sate you. The only limit is really your imagination if you like space-type themes. The ability to single-player sandbox with admin-spawned blocks, then export your designs to multiplayer servers and just work on getting the mats to make your badass ship is really nice.It IS alpha, with some alpha bugs and you do have to do a bit of Google / Forum searching to answer some questions. That said, the devs and community are very helpful.Oh and you can try for free too, but it is well worth $10. Catch it on sale for $5 for a great deal.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Amazing game. Infinite gameplay, provided your computer is good enough.  There are multiple ways to play. The easiest but least efficient way of playing is to sell all of the ores you mine and buy parts with the money. To be more efficient, though, you can play the more complex way, which is to build factory blocks and refine ores to create all of the different blocks. You can engage the pirates early in a small fighter in an attempt to get a headstart by salvaging their ships, or you can bide your time on a claimed planet, building a warship to eliminate the pirates. You can decide to just not engage the pirates in general, and just see what kind of builds you can make. So many things to do, I'm not even a billionth into the gameplay hours you could play if you lived long enough.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game is deceptively simple but is in fact, extremely deep and complex.  If you simply did a bullet point summation of it's features, you'd have a game description that would have almost any PC gamer salivating.  But the modest graphics may lead some gamers to dismiss it out of simple ignorance to what's under the hood.- Fully realized 3D engine with first person perspectives- Massive Universe spanning more solar systems than we'll ever visit- Space Combat- Resource gathering- Trading- Crafting (and this one is key)- Complex divers ship systems that allows for unique gameplay experiences- Player Factions with complex ranks and privileges- Player controlled systems and sectors- The ability to land on the surface of planets ;)- Private servers with the ability to set game parameters and all the coolness that offersHell, this game delivers more than Star Citizen has promised with the except for graphic fidelity and animations.  Oh, and you can build whatever you want.  Space stations, fighters, dreadnaughts, asteroid hangers, plantery bunkers, whatever you can think of.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Very cool concept. All things considered, I'd say it's pretty well done too.Stepping into the game is a bit overwhelming. The tutorial throws a lot of info at you pretty fast, and due to typos and some parts that are poorly explained, you may find yourself scratching your head thinking "wtf am i supposed to do?"Stick with it.This game is basically Minecraft in space. However, where Minecraft doesn't really have any direction to it, this game does. Minecraft is a hodge podge of whatever stuff the devs thought might be cool to have, this game is all about mining and crafting for the purpose of building space ships. You can do more than that, but it all comes back to the ships. Due to the amount of creativity that it possible with the building system, this is NOT a bad thing.I have barely scratched the surface of all the possibilities this game provides, and I'm already having fun. Building ships is fun. The crafting is interesting. The exploring can leave you with genuine feelings of intrigue when you come across a new planet. There are downsides, however. I did experience repeated crashes caused by an error that was only able to be resolved by reinstalling the game. The launcher does streamline this process, though. The tutorial needs another look, especially the typos in it, as they make an already confusing subject matter that much more confusing. The controls are pretty clunky. It's kind of born out of necessity, though, because there are a lot of actions that each need a key. My personal recommendation would be for the devs to remove some of the less necessary actions (can't remember an example off the top of my head, but i know i saw some) and implement the ability to customize keybindings ASAP to lessen the awkwardness. All in all, this is literally the only early access game i have ever played that I felt was worth the money, and fully entertaining this early in developement. It's also the only early access game i have ever clicked the "yes, i recommend this" button for in a review. I spent almost 2 hours in this game, and it felt like 20 mins. Very engaging, and I look forward to seeing great things from this game. If you're on a budget, you can play the alpha for free. Just know that this game is worth the current price of $9 in it's current state, so buying it while it's cheap could be a really good deal. The devs have said the price will go up as features are added, and the game nears completion, so bear that in mind if you like it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								              I may not have many hours on Steam for this game, but that is because I just transfered my purchase. I fell in love with this game from the start. Let me make it clear that I was drawn to this game from an ancient Yogscast video and with what compartatively little that it held then. Since that time the game has just been everything I could ask for in a ... well, there really isn't a short and easy way to say it: A voxel-building (they have made no attempt that it was inspired by Minecraft) space sim; with an open and persistent universe; that has a solid multiplayer* aspect that can easily replicate the singleplayer, or even make a voxel version of any science fiction space universe you want to pull from.             The fact that I can either create, import to my own game, or log into a multiplayer server and see anything from Halo to Firefly to Andromeda is all well and dandy, but I would have to say one of the primary positives of this game so far has been the creativity from the player's themselves and the ingenious way they can take an ordinary set of virtual blocks and have anyone that climbs aboard their creations so immersed is outstanding.             The building and creative flow of the game is not overpowering however. That is not to say that it isn't a main component, it most certainly is, but with a simple download and few clicks you can have someone else's creation in your world and drive it like you stole it across an ever-generating universe. Running and gunning the AI can be fun for a few minutes, but online is where this game shines when it comes to epic tales of space battles and glory.              All of the amazing features that I could go on and on and on and on about that this game has it still cannot outrun the goblin warband of mischief. Sadly, one of the goblins this game has is that multiplayer is multiplayer, and not just that, but can be Minecraft-level of multiplayer. On a public server griefing can get out of hand during peak hours, lag may become an issue for some. Especially if you are like me and think your ISP connects you via massive distances of string, cans, and a series of tubes.            Another negative that has been getting some recent TLC from the Dev is the optimization. It still isn't perfect (mostly large objects and high population** servers), but they are working on it. It no longer takes me 10-15 actual minutes of my life to wait for the station my friends and me built orbiting a desert planet to load in and for my game to stop freezing, but the occasional stutter persists as does the VERY VERY VERY rare crash^.            All-in-all I recommend this product, even as an Early Access Game, because the content of most games that promise these same things is here and with an overall awesome community already in place it shouldn't take long for new players to find their stride and enjoy this lego-space sim.*By solid multiplayer I am referring not just to the general community around the game, but also to the performance itself for a localized (LAN), or low-population whitelisted server^ I have not had this game crash on me in about 6 months (Nov 2014-Apr 2015). I have had one friend that crashes on this game once a month. Your mileage may vary.** My experience of a high population server is about 35+ individuals on a public server.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Starmade is a nice addition to spacegames. Personally i always wanted to create and design my own ships and now i  can! :)The first thing you need to do is place the ship's core. This is the most important piece of your ship. If its destroyed, your ship is destroyed. To protect it you can put shields, armor and hull on your ship. To get these you can mine arsteriods for materials and install factories in order to produce the neccesary materials. Everything can be created with factories. If you wish you can also salvage materials from other player owned ships. Besides this you have pirate bases you can attack aswell and for that you need weapons. You can install a variety of weapons which can work together to create more powerful ones, for instance primary weapons are missiles and as secundary weapon again missiles. When you link them they shoot a swarm of heat seeking missiles as opposed to only 1 missile. When your ship is big enough you can create a hangarbay and dock more ships or you can create automated turrets. You can also install drones and let the AI control them. But where do you dock such an immense ship? You can build your own stations! If you create your own faction (or join one) the first station you create can become your "homebase". It and all ships docked to it are indestructable, but this only goes for 1 base!. Unfortunatly space is huge! and it takes way too long to travel. The max speed depends on the server you are on.At times the server(red shift) im on has 30+ people on it, but usually is pretty quiet (unfortunatly). I had problems with memory in the beginning. Apparently there is a setting that lets you put how much memory you want the game to use. after this i had no problems. To sumarize:The process of creating/building your ship is really great! pve is fun, but pvp is not really present. The game has a lot of potential, but for that more people need to start playing.

								You know what? This is addictive. A call to all peace loving warriors!We spent a week or so building a faction and a spacestation. Our group was mining in order to build proper defenses including a massive carrier to take the fight to the enemy. One quiet morning, all chaos let loose and another faction staged an unprovoked sneak attack. We weathered that attack only to discover a massive swarm of pirate ships has noticed the comotion and moved in for the kill. The human offenders beat a hasty retreat as the overwhelming pirate forces laid siege to our modest outpost. Several casualties including our faction leader and countless valiant soldiers did not stop us from our mission. When the smoke cleared, our station remains standing and the hull is intact. We live to fight another day. We live to return vengeance on our sworn enemies. Word has gone out and war has officially been declared on a fearsome foe. He will strengthen his forces but now we weaponize. With a full range of devastating weaponry, our wrath will be legendary. Come join us as we clear this universe of rabble and decay. content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								I bought this game five days ago, played it a while and was so frustrated at the lack of FPS, especially heading towards planets to the point that my computer lagged/ froze and I had to reboot. I’m by no way a geek in the internals of computer’s, my computer runs Warcraft real easy on max settings and my thoughts as I looked at my rig “how is this possible” as I raised a fist at my screen.I didn't give up though and after some headache research, I found that my Java was 32 bit and my comp is 64 bit I got the correct Java for my computer.Launched game went to the options tab played with the memory settings…………Re-launched Star Made, keeping my finger’s crossed as I approached the first planet I could see, keeping an eye on my FPS it was stable very stable, I right clicked my mouse in my very over the top mining vessel, looked once again at my FPS, stable running at just over 30 FPS. I left it running all night sat in an orbit over the planet, flicked on my screen a few hours ago turned and looked at the planet, I smiled runs beautiful now.I have posted this here as some of you guys seem as frustrated as I was, hope this helps……Delta Quadrant here I come…………….10/10

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Anyone who dislikes anything about this game has either a bad computer or an outdated version. StarMade is an alpha game, so it isn't super advanced, but already, the possibilites are limitless. If Minecraft was a higher-res game, in space, have some FPS mechanics, and dodecohedron shaped planets, this would be it. All of your spaceships and space stations are customizable down to the last block, so you can have as many weapons, engines, jump drives, storage, mning beams, whatever. The Devs are extremely helpful and update the game a ton, and pay attention to anything that's trending. Also, the space battles are incredible- dozens of million-block ships flying through space, bombarding each other with missiles, turrets, cannons, etc., it's like something straight out of Star Wars or Star Trek.
