number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								Starmade is a nice addition to spacegames. Personally i always wanted to create and design my own ships and now i  can! :)The first thing you need to do is place the ship's core. This is the most important piece of your ship. If its destroyed, your ship is destroyed. To protect it you can put shields, armor and hull on your ship. To get these you can mine arsteriods for materials and install factories in order to produce the neccesary materials. Everything can be created with factories. If you wish you can also salvage materials from other player owned ships. Besides this you have pirate bases you can attack aswell and for that you need weapons. You can install a variety of weapons which can work together to create more powerful ones, for instance primary weapons are missiles and as secundary weapon again missiles. When you link them they shoot a swarm of heat seeking missiles as opposed to only 1 missile. When your ship is big enough you can create a hangarbay and dock more ships or you can create automated turrets. You can also install drones and let the AI control them. But where do you dock such an immense ship? You can build your own stations! If you create your own faction (or join one) the first station you create can become your "homebase". It and all ships docked to it are indestructable, but this only goes for 1 base!. Unfortunatly space is huge! and it takes way too long to travel. The max speed depends on the server you are on.At times the server(red shift) im on has 30+ people on it, but usually is pretty quiet (unfortunatly). I had problems with memory in the beginning. Apparently there is a setting that lets you put how much memory you want the game to use. after this i had no problems. To sumarize:The process of creating/building your ship is really great! pve is fun, but pvp is not really present. The game has a lot of potential, but for that more people need to start playing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								Very cool concept. All things considered, I'd say it's pretty well done too.Stepping into the game is a bit overwhelming. The tutorial throws a lot of info at you pretty fast, and due to typos and some parts that are poorly explained, you may find yourself scratching your head thinking "wtf am i supposed to do?"Stick with it.This game is basically Minecraft in space. However, where Minecraft doesn't really have any direction to it, this game does. Minecraft is a hodge podge of whatever stuff the devs thought might be cool to have, this game is all about mining and crafting for the purpose of building space ships. You can do more than that, but it all comes back to the ships. Due to the amount of creativity that it possible with the building system, this is NOT a bad thing.I have barely scratched the surface of all the possibilities this game provides, and I'm already having fun. Building ships is fun. The crafting is interesting. The exploring can leave you with genuine feelings of intrigue when you come across a new planet. There are downsides, however. I did experience repeated crashes caused by an error that was only able to be resolved by reinstalling the game. The launcher does streamline this process, though. The tutorial needs another look, especially the typos in it, as they make an already confusing subject matter that much more confusing. The controls are pretty clunky. It's kind of born out of necessity, though, because there are a lot of actions that each need a key. My personal recommendation would be for the devs to remove some of the less necessary actions (can't remember an example off the top of my head, but i know i saw some) and implement the ability to customize keybindings ASAP to lessen the awkwardness. All in all, this is literally the only early access game i have ever played that I felt was worth the money, and fully entertaining this early in developement. It's also the only early access game i have ever clicked the "yes, i recommend this" button for in a review. I spent almost 2 hours in this game, and it felt like 20 mins. Very engaging, and I look forward to seeing great things from this game. If you're on a budget, you can play the alpha for free. Just know that this game is worth the current price of $9 in it's current state, so buying it while it's cheap could be a really good deal. The devs have said the price will go up as features are added, and the game nears completion, so bear that in mind if you like it.

Early Access Review
								StarMade is one of the coolest games I have ever plain. Although it has it's bugs *Cough* Planet Gravity *Cough*, It is one of the best and most fluent games on Steam. What starts out to seem like a boring game, turns into an amazing (possibly face paced), beautiful, and scientific game. The fights that you can make or join in can sometimes be thrilling, and the things that you can make are amazing! I can right a very, very long list about all of the things that I like about this game; but the list of bad things would be minimal. I recommend this game to anyone that even remotely likes space and/or science fiction, and can deal with bugs and glitches. (It is still currently in Alpha, so you'll have to get used to that stuff.)

Apparently there is a setting that lets you put how much memory you want the game to use. after this i had no problems. To sumarize:The process of creating/building your ship is really great! pve is fun, but pvp is not really present. The game has a lot of potential, but for that more people need to start playing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								To start off, I will announce that I am a space enthusiast who has played and relatively enjoyed other space games that are in the gaming market as of right now. I can honestly say that this game seems to be more exciting than almost all of them. If you are looking for a complete game, re-direct youself to the Early-Access Notice on the Starmade store page and realize what that means. If it seems like I am being abrasive it is only because I do not want people  to judge this game as being a full game and I also want you to spend your money on a complete game if that is what you want.That being said, I will attempt to break up this review into 2 seciton's of the Pro's and Con's of this game with a summary at the end for all of the TL:DR's.Pro's:- Complete Freewill with building and a massive sandbox to test your creation's.- you can Build and Create your own Station's in space and on the surface of planets.- Faction wars if you choose to get involved in them.- Your Mind is the only limit to your creation's. (ie. If you want an explorer ship to fly around the galaxy, a Massive Dreadnought to take on the Pirate plague the infects the universe, a Mining ship to tear apart planets and asteroids for materials to fuel your coffers of either your own or your factions you may.)- The game doesn't really seem to get boring unlike other sandboxes (especially with friends.)- The mechanics of the game are smooth and have a great basis for improvement.- The Dev's seem devoted, creative, and extremely passionate about this game.- It is still within its Alpha stage and already feels very complete.Con's- Could be better building mechanics such as switching out blocks for another (on larger ships) in an easier fashion rather than just setting your x,y,z to 100 and clicking away.- The UI could be a enhanced a tad to not only look better but also provide wider control over various aspects of your ship/character/info panels (faction, ship, navigation, etc.).- Needs more content that allow us as the player to impact to the universe around us. (again, Alpha state.)- A bit of a learning curve which either takes asking questions, watching tutorials, or simply tampering around and experimenting on your own (I would suggest the others if you are looking to get up to speed quick.)- I found this game just as college was swinging back around to hit me in the face.Overall, Great game with a solid base for improvement and a galaxy and a Dev team that allow for it expand. In my opinion, the fact that this game in in its alpha state suprises my and also gets me just as excited and crazed as a girl going to starbucks. TL:DR- Minecraft in space, but it doesn't feel like all you are doing is slapping chickens and punching wood. Instead, you can phaser a planet and watch its molten core be exposed and your storage start teeming with loot. That can help you on your way to becoming a mogul and or fueling your passion to build Fleet of your own creations. Or you can inhabit that planet and build your very own colony that people can visit and shop at. Or you can be sucked into that planet never to enter space again because you didn't put enough thrust to your♥♥♥♥♥and thus you cant escape the planets gravity. Your Choice.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is deceptively simple but is in fact, extremely deep and complex.  If you simply did a bullet point summation of it's features, you'd have a game description that would have almost any PC gamer salivating.  But the modest graphics may lead some gamers to dismiss it out of simple ignorance to what's under the hood.- Fully realized 3D engine with first person perspectives- Massive Universe spanning more solar systems than we'll ever visit- Space Combat- Resource gathering- Trading- Crafting (and this one is key)- Complex divers ship systems that allows for unique gameplay experiences- Player Factions with complex ranks and privileges- Player controlled systems and sectors- The ability to land on the surface of planets ;)- Private servers with the ability to set game parameters and all the coolness that offersHell, this game delivers more than Star Citizen has promised with the except for graphic fidelity and animations.  Oh, and you can build whatever you want.  Space stations, fighters, dreadnaughts, asteroid hangers, plantery bunkers, whatever you can think of.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has a demo version that is FREE so if you like it then you can buy it.  If not then you can not buy it.Don't mind the negative reviews they're just mad that the game isn't going in the direction they think is best for the game.  Which is fine, but the majority of the community wants it to go in this direction so it will continue to regardless.As for bugs, I seem to have been lucky because I don't experience as many problems as others do.  This does run off Java, so make sure to keep that up to date.This is minecraft in space on steroids, it is a procedurally created universe.  There are many galaxies you can visit and now there are factions.  The development of the game is a slow but steady pace since the features/content generation is rather complex for this game, but there is a roadmap on trello if you want to see what they plan on doing for each phase of the game.This game allows you to fully customize block by block your ship and weapons.  The build mode is a bit odd to get used to at first but when you figure it out, it's pretty much limitless.The bigger the ship, the bigger your turrets/gun and the bigger your ship systems will be, so of course bigger ships typically win.  You spent all that time mining and refining resources for it, so why let somoene who barely did anything be capable of easily destroying it?Fleet AI is in the game and being worked on for improvment, so soon many small ships can take on few large ships.I have had problems with the community (forums) but still support the game, because overall it's going in a good direction and the Devs are good at filtering out the bad ones  of the community.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Having been playing this game for a while, I can say that I would not recommend it in its current state unless you love to build.Expanding on that idea of loving to build, Starmade has one of the best set of tools for building whatever the fudge you want in this game. The not horribly demanding placement of blocks in order for a ship to work allows for a fair bit of flexibility in making a ship that works alright, all you really have to do is place the more finicky things in lines and the rest everywhere else. The inclusion of the advanced build mode features accessible by HOLDING down lcontrol allow one to define symmetry planes, place hundreds of blocks at once, copy n' paste and more! Various systems such as rails and logic also give a player the ability to make various functioning mechanisms as simple as an elevator or password-protected door or as complicated as Space Monopoly (yes, someone did do that). It's even possible to create a basic OS on your ships to execute commands from a console in order to lock down, flash red alerts, undock drones, and whatever else you would want to do!However, the ship design system does have one glaring flaw. The way power works has a weird, non-intuitive pattern of construction in order to work effectively. One has to create groupings with an emphasis of covering large dimensions to generate more power per block, or else end up placing way more blocks than needed and making a relatively underpowered ship. This forces design choices centering around large power crosses or large lines of power and is overall not very interesting to create. Hopefully this will be fixed in the power overhaul that the devs have annouced will take place.Another issue with the game is the lack of survival gameplay. The devs certainly are working on it, and that's great, one can certainly see that with the addition of basic NPC Faction generation, but there still is not much to do. There's no real reason to explore after seeing all the different ships and stations because everything that is randomly generated is pretty much the same old stuff. There's no nebulae or ion storms that could provide navigational challenge or special gaseous resources, crashed ships with flight data or blueprints, or dangerous pirate territory stacked with loot (pirates now don't count because the danger level of pirates is pretty much constant wherever anyone goes, and there's no real reason to raid them). Nothing is there to push a player or provide danger in the universe either. There's no hunger or oxygen mechanics to drive one to gather resources, and the act of gathering resources to gather stuff is super boring, amounting only to pointing your ship at an asteroid, turning on your radar jammer to negate any and all danger, and holding down left-click for a while.Manufacturing, industry, and diplomacy is super boring as well. Crafting stuff is just typing in what you want to make, looking at the recipie, and putting the stuff in the factory. No player will actually buy something another player makes because it's way more efficent just to mine it yourself through the boring process of holding down left-click on an asteroid until it disappears. Interactions between player factions boils down to either talking in chat or blowing each other up becuase of these reasons. Being a merchant is further frustrated by NPC factions only buying from a player in small amounts. Communication with these factions to make them buy more is also impossible, simply because they are in such a basic state.With a lack of strong content in terms of exploration, manufacturing, interaction and survival, I cannot recommend the game in its current state to others unless you absolutely love building. If you do like to build there are exceptional tools available with endless possibility.Though, please do note that the game is completely free in its early access stages. Just click the "download demo" button to get the full version. You may as well try it out to judge it for yourself, and if you don't like it stop by after a while. The devs are extremely active and pushing out new updates to fix these issues fairly often!

Early Access Review
 Has not made any significant progress in development since steam early release.  Other games are farther along with this concept and have better graphics and mechanics. I would not recommend this game now. I would wait until it is completed. I don't feel like my investment to this company was the right decision. I should have waited until it was completed, however after seeing other companies’ products I don't think I would have supported this product. after coming back and checking the progress of the game I am impressed with the direction the game is taken. If the momentum of the current development is sustained then I see strong potential for a great success on this team's hard work. I hope they continue with the direction of development and look forward to the end product. I have since changed my recommendation from no to yes as the game now is playable with a slew of creative and combat mechanics already implemented. (FYI:   this is a personal review, not a debate. please take any and all fanboy crap to the discussion pages. I will delete comments as I see fit, because I am tired of all the cry babies and snowflakes who can't accept that other people might not enjoy this game. I know it goes against your perceived reality and its seems harsh, but dont worry im sure you can find solace and comfort in the discussion pages with others who agree with your perceived reality.)
